PETITION.TITLE: Senate Elections: Abolition of Compulsory Preferential Voting
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That on the 10th December 1948, the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted and proclaimed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which declares that, 'Everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth in the Declaration. . . .' (Article 2) that 'Everyone has the right to take part in the government of his country, directly or through freely chosen representatives . . . The will of the people shall be the basis of the authority of government; this will shall be expressed in periodic and genuine elections which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and shall be held by secret vote or equivalent free voting procedures.' (Article 21 (1) and (3).)

Elections for Senators meet all requirements except one. Senators are elected periodically, by secret ballot, with universal franchise, and the quota-preferential method of proportional representation ensures that the vote values within states are equal as nearly as can be.
However the provision of the Electoral Act that compels voters to show preferences for ALL candidates on the ballot paper interferes with the free expression of the will of the voters, and is unjust.
Australia, as a Member State of the United Nations, is pledged to achieve observance of Human Rights and Freedoms.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, therefore humbly pray that the Senate will fulfil the pledge of a Member State of the United Nations and take steps to remove the compulsion from the Electoral Act in order to allow freedom of expression for everyone who has the right to vote for Senators.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPORT OF THE ROYAL COMMISSION ON HUMAN RELATIONSHIPS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to an address given by Justice Elizabeth Evatt in the National Press Club on 24 September 1980 and, in particular, to her comments regarding the Royal Commission on Human Relationships. In view of Justice Evatt's comments on the time which has elapsed since the commissioners presented their report to the Governor-General, I ask the Minister: Firstly, why has there been no official response by the Government to the report of the Royal Commission on Human Relationships; and, secondly, what proposal has been made by the interdepartmental committee set up in 1978 to consider the report? Does the Minister agree that the matters dealt with in the report remain important issues for our society? Does the Minister also agree with Justice Evatt's claim that 'it is the concern of governments to develop effective social policies, not only because these may improve the quality of life, but also because Government and the community often have to deal with the consequences of the breakdown of relationships and the lack of proper social planning'? If so, will the Minister inform the Senate when we can expect to know which of the Royal Commission recommendations are accepted and which will be implemented?

—The report of the Royal Commission on Human Relationships which was presented to the Government in 1977 dealt with a very wide range of issues which impact on today's society. The matters considered by the Royal Commission were complex. The recommendations relate to many areas which are the responsibility of the Commonwealth, of the States and, indeed, of individuals themselves. As honourable senators will know, some of the report's recommendations are considered to be controversial. In accordance with usual practice, the States' views were sought on the recommendations. Not all States have as yet responded. The Government has, of course, continued to be active in the broad areas of policy covered by the report. We have a record second to none in supporting the family and providing assistance for those most in need. Reports such as that of the Royal Commission and a wide range of other reports which the Government has commissioned are an important input in developing and furthering our policies in that area.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer I ask him whether efforts will be made to expedite the answer from the States which apparently after many years still have not responded to the Government's request.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SUSPECTED OUTBREAK OF FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Speaking as a member of the high-powered Estimates Committee C, I inform the Senate that we have been regaled with reports regarding the top level efficiency of our animal quarantine section. I do not disagree with that, but I wonder, in the light of the recent alarm about a suspected outbreak of foot and mouth disease in New Zealand, whether we should be satisfied that the operations of the animal quarantine section have been adequate and whether there are any limitations or faults due to a lack of early advice from the New Zealand Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asked some questions about departmental procedures in relation to animal quarantine. He did not ask particularly about the recent episode in New Zealand.
—Oh yes; that is within the ambit of the question.

—If that is within the ambit of the question, I can advise that what happened recently indicates the seriousness with which the Government regards any suspected outbreak of a disease which could be of importance to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: At 11.30 a.m. on 12 February reports of a suspected vesicular disease outbreak in New Zealand were confirmed with New Zealand veterinary authorities. They advised then that 28 pigs on an 850-animal piggery had displayed clinical signs of vesicular disease; the affected animals had been destroyed and samples had been sent for diagnosis to the world reference laboratory at Pirbright in the United Kingdom; the remaining animals were being destroyed and all appropriate disease control measures had been implemented. Immediate action was taken by Australian quarantine authorities to implement precautionary measures to prevent the possible spread of any disease to this country. I think that is the point which interested the honourable senator.

These measures included the following: An immediate halt to the importation of live animals other than cats and dogs and of all relevant animal products from New Zealand; an increase in passenger and baggage screening for incoming flights from New Zealand to the same level as for arrivals from foot and mouth disease countries; and the quarantining on arrival of all relevant animal products in transit between the two countries. In the event the ensuing tests were negative, and we were able to call off these procedures.

It is clear that the procedures which are in place are quite complex. They are designed to protect this country, as far as we can, from the importation of any exotic diseases. If there are particular matters in relation to the procedures which the honourable senator still requires I will be glad to get them from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I think an article in the Australian Financial Review implied a lag between the time the suspected disease was detected in New Zealand and when the New Zealand authorities advised the Australian authorities. I am not questioning the Minister's advice. I am visualising a delay of 24 hours and some pig meat being in transit to Australia. Could any have got through? How efficient were the New Zealand authorities in alerting us to what was happening?
—I have indicated one time and date to the honourable senator. In order to answer his question I will need to get further information. I will see whether I can have it by the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AID FOR ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs confirm a report in yesterday's Canberra Times that the Federal Government has rejected a case to take part in a five-year plan to upgrade basic facilities at Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory at a cost of $150m? The Northern Territory plan, announced last April, would have provided for the construction and upgrading of electricity and water supplies, sewerage works, public lavatories, air communications, roadworks and drainage, cyclone shelters, barge landings and camp improvements. If the Federal Government has rejected this five-year plan, does this mean that there will be no upgrading of the facilities which I have enumerated? Will the Minister say how he sees the Federal Government's responsibilities to the Aboriginals of the Northern Territory in these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the newspaper story to which the honourable senator refers but I have heard about it and I am able to provide some information to the honourable senator.
—It was mentioned on Tuesday.

—All I am saying is that I have not seen the newspaper but I know of the story. I remind the honourable senator that on 31 July 1980 Mr Everingham sought funds from the Commonwealth totalling $120m over five years for a program of improvements to environmental health facilities at Aboriginal communities and later he put forward a revised estimate of $154.1m as the amount he would need. The Chief Minister's main arguments to support the requests were twofold: Firstly, that improvements to environmental health in Aboriginal communities were sorely needed and, secondly, that when the Commonwealth transferred responsibility to the Northern Territory Government the Commonwealth offered insufficient ongoing finance to meet the backlog in environmental health needs.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree that Aboriginal needs are substantial and acute. The Commonwealth has already made a commitment of $50m over five years to help improve environmental health, and that is a practical example of the Commonwealth's commitment to do more in this area. I do not agree that the Northern Territory is being poorly treated financially or that it is necessary for it to make the request it has made. The relatively high per capita costs of providing services to Aboriginals were taken into account and were reflected in the level of general purpose funding agreed to at the time of self-government. Despite the transfer to the Northern Territory of financial responsibility for several major programs and although the Northern Territory contains only 15 per cent of the total Aboriginal population of Australia, 24 per cent of the grants made available by my Department in 1980-81 were made to the Northern Territory Government, and the Aboriginal organisations in the Northern Territory will receive that money. I am saying that a small percentage of the Aboriginal population got a larger percentage of the grants because of special need. I suppose the answer is that whilst we sympathise with Mr Everingham we ask him to look to his own set of priorities within his own budgeting to determine how he spends States grants money.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Carrick, mainly in his capacity as Vice-President of the Executive Council but also as the Minister representing the Minister for Education. I refer to a report that there is employment discrimination in Australian universities in that half of all academics holding the position of lecturer or above either are foreign born or have overseas qualifications, that discrimination against women, Australian or not, is even greater and that the proportion of women academics ranges from less than 7 per cent at the University of Tasmania to 24 per cent at Macquarie University. I ask: Will the Government consider introducing detailed regulations to control the percentages of Australians in general and women in particular who must be given academic appointments in Australian universities in an endeavour to give academics some feeling of the sorts of constrictions which have been imposed on Australian industry and enterprise by a free-ranging bureaucracy, or will the Government leave it to the good sense of the universities to determine their own appointments? If it does the latter, will it remember this principle in relation to its expensive and detailed over-regulation of Australian industry?

—I have not seen the statements which give the statistics that Senator Lewis has revealed. I accept that he has a basic source for those figures and I would be very interested if he would let me have them. Of course I will direct the whole substance of his question to the Minister for Education whose direct responsibility this matter is. In general the Government and governments of all political faiths have accepted that universities and colleges should be autonomous in the discharge of their functions, specifically in order to give them what is called academic freedom. The appointment of academics to their staffs would, I think, be regarded as such. Nevertheless, if there is an apparent discrimination there are various ways in which that can be, firstly, exposed and, secondly, rectified while maintaining that academic freedom. For example, the matter could be drawn to the attention of the Tertiary Education Commission which is a statutory body and which, if it were to study the matter, might wish to draw attention to it or to make comment to the individual institutions on that basis. So there are a number of ways in which a government could act, assuming it thought it meritorious to do so. But, as it is basically a matter for the Minister for Education, I will make sure that Mr Fife peruses the question and gives consideration to it.

The television earth station to be established at Streaky Bay is part of the remote area television program. It will bring Australian Broadcasting Commission television to 76 remote communities. The Intelsat IV international communications satellite is being used to bring programs to 52 of these remote communities. Remote locations in Western Australia receiving satellite-fed programs will receive ABC programs from Perth. The Streaky Bay station will therefore relay Sydney-produced ABC programs. I am not certain that that answer deals with all the points for the honourable senator, but if there are any questions remaining unanswered I will undertake to get more information from my colleague.

—I do not have information on the range of transmission. I will get that information for the honourable senator.

—There is no office to make it available, that is the problem.
—Senator Robertson interjects. To clarify the matter for him I make the point that the regional medical officer within the Department of Health will be the contact officer in each case.
—But the patient has to be referred to him.

In relation to the various ex-service organisations in Darwin and the broader matter as to whether a wider counselling service will be established, I am in the process of negotiating with various bodies, particularly the Returned Services League and the Vietnam Veterans' Action Association, in the establishment of the counselling service on a more permanent basis than those arrangements which I have just outlined.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I do not know of the particular case to which the honourable senator referred. I believe I could obtain fairly quickly some general information in relation to the question of payment of benefits during a patient's absence from a nursing home. What progress has been made by the Government in its review of the report of the Bureau of Transport Economics on the issue of inward duty free shopping in Australia? One of the outstanding things is that despite Australia's relatively small population we have been able to get people of very high quality to come forward. The Holcroft inquiry is an example of that. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the last part of the honourable senator's question I repeat that the Government is very conscious of the need to preserve academic freedom and that all those matters which impinge upon the right to academic freedom are very rightly those of the senates or councils of the institutions concerned. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Webster did cross my mind as well as the minds of the interjectors. By the merest chance I do have some information on the biological control of blackberry. In fact, the biological control of blackberry by parasitic fungi is being investigated by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation which in turn is receiving the co-operation of the Victorian Department of Crown Lands and Survey. My advice is that no other States have been involved to this point.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the fungi cause dieback at the cane tips and reduce seed formation and allow other vegetation to invade thickets. This work has been going on since 1977 and is being carried out at the CSIRO laboratory in France where a suitable strain of fungi is being tested for effectiveness as well as specificity to blackberry. As a member of the Commission on Human Rights, Australia will participate in discussions on El Salvador at the Commission's current meeting in Geneva. That policy was announced in 1973 by the then Minister for Social Security, Mr Hayden, and has continued to apply. All proprietors were made aware of the policy in 1973 and again in 1977.

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1973 proprietors have been able to charge a bed retention fee during a patient's absence from a nursing home where the patient requests that the bed be retained. The fee is determined by the proprietor but is not allowed to exceed the approved day fee. Proprietors are held responsible for advising a patient of the fee if he or she wishes to have the bed retained.

Representations have been received from a number of patients, both insured and uninsured, who have been asked by proprietors to repay amounts which the proprietor incorrectly claimed as Commonwealth and fund benefits in respect of periods when the patient was absent from the nursing home. I think this is the area where some of the trouble has arisen. It would appear from the number of days and amounts involved that the patients may not have been advised by the proprietor that benefits were not payable during periods of absence. The amounts of Commonwealth benefit involved have been recovered. Recovery of fund benefits is a matter between the proprietor and the fund.

There are a number of matters of concern here, including the position of nursing home patients who may be required to enter a public hospital, say, for treatment of an acute illness. In view of all these matters the Department of Health is reviewing the position with a view to setting out a number of options for ministerial considerations. I think it is proper that the honourable senator has raised the matter. If he wishes, I will draw to the Minister's attention the details of the case to which he has referred.

This is perhaps an appropriate time to take stock of the way in which this Government has effectively withdrawn funding from much needed projects in the areas of urban and regional development. The sharp decline of support by the Federal Government for urban and regional development is one indicator of the difficulties being faced in country areas, and particularly in areas at the forefront of the resources boom, as was mentioned yesterday during the matter of public importance debate in the Senate. It is instructive to measure the way in which this Government has retreated from the area of funding and the provision of financial assistance generally to places such as Albury-Wodonga.

At constant prices, Federal expenditure on urban and regional development in 1974-75 was $205m; this year it is just $65m. Expenditure on decentralisation assistance has been cut by 70 per cent. This year's allocation is down 16 per cent on 1979-80. Of the money spent on decentralisation, figures for housing, which is one of the areas of most concern in regional centres, confirm this trend. In real terms, Federal spending on housing this financial year is one-third of the amount allocated six years ago, in spite of a burgeoning housing problem. Real net payments to the States for housing have fallen from $515m in 1974-75 to $76m in the current year. Victoria, for instance, is receiving now only one-seventh of the amount it was allocated seven years ago. These are brief examples of the way in which regional areas have been deprived by this Government.

It is appropriate, while we are alluding to the Albury-Wodonga growth area, to reflect on the shoddy way in which this Government broke all its promises about another growth centre, that is, the growth centre of Bathurst-Orange. Initially Bathurst-Orange was the brainchild of the New South Wales Country Party. However, the Whitlam Government accepted that it warranted Federal assistance and during the 1975 election campaign members of this Government indicated that this assistance would continue. This promise became just one of a long list of undertakings that were promptly broken when this Government took office. Virtually since 1976 Bathurst-Orange which is in the large Federal electorate of Calare, has been carried solely by the New South Wales Government.

Country people are entitled to look soberly at matters such as broken promises about growth centres, decentralisation, which has always been strong in conservative rhetoric in this country, and urban and regional development. Country people cannot be blamed for concluding that this Government has no interest in breaking down the inequalities that exist and flourish in country areas as compared with the cities. It is encouraging to note, however, that in connection with Albury-Wodonga steady growth is still taking place. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

I have read through the report which makes it evident that the development of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is at a formative stage, and this leads me to float an idea for consideration which could make the Great Barrier Reef a more valuable and significant tourist attraction in world terms, a revenue earner of great potential for Australia and an asset of some value to our own people. In a number of visits to the reef area I have been struck by the lack of a suitable underwater facility of suitable potential for viewing the authentic reef. There are underwater observatories at Hook Island and Green Island, and perhaps elsewhere. I do not denigrate the efforts of private enterprise in establishing those observatories but it is a fact that many overseas visitors to the area are disappointed with them. I recall a conversation I had at Shute Harbour with a group of American tourists who were quite acid in their comments. They said: 'We came here to see your reef and we could not see it at all. We are not going to recommend that anybody else ever come here'. I suggest that that is a bad situation.

These facilities do not really meet the expectations of people who come all this way to see the reef. That is what they want to do-see the reef. These present facilities are less than adequate because the cost of creating a really good facility in a suitable place which would disturb the environment as little as possible and which would provide really comprehensive viewing would be very expensive and certainly run into many millions of dollars. However, I would forecast that its appeal over the years would be so great that it would prove to be an excellent investment for this country from a money point of view alone. Beyond that, it would seem appropriate that Australia should be planning a permanent asset of great national significance for the 1988 Bicentenary which will outlast the dancing and the fireworks. I do not really see the new and permanent Parliament House in that light. The really important tourist potential of Australia in world terms, the thing that everybody knows is in Australia, apart from kangaroos, is the Great Barrier Reef.

I suggest that we have a certain duty to develop it discreetly so that people can come to it from all over the world and genuinely appreciate it. I have spoken to some of the people in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority about this proposal and, generally, they see nothing against it. They make the point that if we want to see the reef properly we really need a viewing area at three levels. Perhaps we could have the viewing area built down the side of a bank so that we could see the reef at three separate levels, not just from the surface. We need a concrete structure of a very permanent nature, inconspicuous from sea level, taking genuine account of minimum disturbance of the environment and offering room for many people to have a wide range of viewing. I believe this would attract people from all over the world. I merely wanted to make that point. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE EFFICIENCY AND ADMINISTRATION OF HOSPITALS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report is otherwise known as the Jamison report. The Commission of Inquiry was set up by State and Federal governments as a means of bringing some rationality into the funding and functioning of the hospital systems in Australia. As such, one cannot complain about the introduction of such an important inquiry. My first point is that the report has been tabled in this Parliament after having been widely discussed in the Press and by interested parties in the medical profession, the hospital business and the paramedical professions in this country. It was clearly leaked to the Press before the Opposition or anyone else in the Parliament had access to it. It was obviously made available to a selected and privileged group of interested parties as was evidenced by their detailed statements and comments on this report when the first Press reports appeared.

I make the comment on this report as I have on other reports presented in this Parliament that only after these Press reports and after Opposition protests were made were copies made available to members of this Parliament, particularly back bench members on either side. We have seen this practice with many important reports such as this one, the glaring example being the report of the Royal Commission on Human Relationships which was spoken about this morning. It is a discourteous practice. It makes a travesty of the parliamentary system and, quite frankly, it makes those of us on this side of the chamber consider whether we should have any regard for the conventions and regulations of parliamentary procedure when it seems that the Government considers that it can disregard these conventions, regulations and procedures at will.

This is an important report because what we all need and seek in this country, I believe, is a national health scheme and, specifically in this case, a national hospitals policy, a policy which provides hospital care, which is accessible to those who need it and which provides a wide range of services for those who are ill when and where they are ill. Of course, economy and containment of hospital costs are important but not of such importance that they should interfere with these principles and not to the exclusion of needs of individuals in this community. We will achieve such a policy only if we rationally look at the system and in this regard the report is significant.

The commissioners certainly had limited terms of reference. They certainly had a limited time to look at such a vast area. But one can breathe a sigh of relief that nowhere in the report do they indulge in the nonsensical and inaccurate rhetoric that we hear from some Government members and some medical professionals in this country stating that the introduction of Medibank was the cause of the rapidly increasing health costs in this country. It is worth while pointing out, I believe, that health costs and hospital costs were a concern of governments in this country in the late 1960s and that the then Mr John Gorton, the Liberal-National Country Party Prime Minister of this country, instituted the Nimmo inquiry because at that time, in 1968, there was considerable concern about increasing health costs. That inquiry was the basis of future planning from then until now. That inquiry was the inquiry which pointed out the health problems and the problems facing hospitals in this country.

It is also a fact that the most rapid period of increase in health costs in this country preceded the introduction of Medibank in July 1975. To blame Medibank and to blame a universal health insurance scheme or the hospital schemes which are associated with it, for such increases is nonsense. The fact that this report does not indulge in that sort of nonsense is, at least, a help to us all, I believe, in taking a rational look at the system. The report, in volume 1 on page 47, draws attention to the present situation.
Recent changes to the health insurance system have done little to improve the health system.

One would have thought that this was a masterly understatement of the situation which has occurred as a result of the annual and, sometimes, biannual changes to the health insurance system which have occurred since December 1975. As the Opposition's health spokesman in the Senate I have had to debate repeated amendments to the legislation which have made contradictory and confusing changes to the system. The only people who have suffered have been the patients in the community, particularly the poor and patients on low incomes in the community.

Unfortunately, however, in the view of the Opposition and in the view of some of those people involved in health planning and health delivery in this country, the report does not give a satisfactory blueprint for the future. Like so many reports of this type, it raises as many questions as answers. But the danger in such reports lies in the fact that the Government, in its zeal for cost cutting, may selectively pick out those proposals which result in reduction in government expenditure and ignore concurrent recommendations which would, in fact, improve hospital and health care in the community. The Australian Medical Association for instance, through its spokesman, Dr Lionel Wilson, has described the report as lacking a coherent plan. The Australian Hospitals Association has been disturbed at what it sees as a lack of a consistent theme in the report. But one theme in the report, and a theme which I may add is common to other reports in the health and welfare field in this country which have been presented to this Parliament, is the need for rational planning. An associated theme which runs through the report is the reason for the difficulties which face us in planning a rational health and hospital system. First of all, planning is hampered, as it is throughout the health and welfare field, by a lack of information, by a deplorable lack of statistics which we can use for planning building, for planning facilities, for developing the manpower necessary, and by a lack of statistics and a lack of information which makes even the distribution of available funds under the present system a problem.
The AMA echoed the sentiments of the report. Dr Wilson stated:

There is no rational information system allowing meaningful comparisons of the efficiency and effectiveness of health care delivery in the various States. Without such a system allocation of money will continue to be arbitrary.

This is the problem: Allocation of funds in this very large area of government expenditure is arbitrary. It can be nothing else but arbitrary because of the lack of statistics and the lack of knowledge which we have of the system that we are allegedly trying to set up and control. Therefore, we can only welcome the report's call for the need for the proper collection of statistics and the proper assessment and collection of information in general.

However, we must also, because of the difficulties faced in planning, be wary of recommendations which call for radical changes to the training of personnel where a long lead time is involved. Many of us are aware that, as a result of cuts in nurses' training some four or five years ago because of what seemed to be a gross oversupply, in some States we now have a shortage of nurses. Many of us in this place-I believe I expressed it in this place some four or five years ago-have expressed the concern of a number of cardiac surgeons and cardiac units in this country who suggested that if we proceeded the way we were we would have an oversupply. As a result of one new procedure developed recently we now have, certainly in Victoria, a shortage of cardiac surgeons and patients are suffering as a result. Similarly, an uncritical acceptance of the present harsh immigration restrictions on doctors may be rational so far as most Australians are concerned, but it will not be welcomed by isolated areas which are largely dependent on immigrant doctors. The Australian Hospitals Association and the report itself point out the difficulties because of restrictions on the number of doctors in training. These recommendations are based on, what is, at the least, dubious evidence and, at times, non-existent evidence.

Some recommendations of the report are contradictory and at times, I must say, surprising. There is a general theme throughout the report encouraging patients into private insurance and private medicine which we do not believe is desirable. We can find no evidence to back such recommendations in the report. At the same time, however, the report recommends the cessation of private practice by salaried practitioners. It makes the welcome, but surprising, recommendation 139. This states:
Consideration be given to the wisdom of continuing to use subsidised privately owned for profit organisations for the care of the aged, or mentally and/or physically handicapped people.

This is a practice which has been questioned by Opposition members for many, many years. It is a recommendation, which I must say, stands in isolation to other recommendations in the report. One wonders how the inquiry made the other recommendations when this recommendation is quite contrary to the usual run. The report recommends also means to prop up private funds and private hospitals. But, as my colleague in another place, Dr Blewett, has pointed out, while the report recognises that public bed numbers have been held in recent years-in fact, in some hospitals, public bed numbers have been reduced-at the same time, private bed numbers, being not controlled, have increased.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many are owned by multinationals.

—Many, particularly in recent years, have been owned by multinationals. As a result of this uncontrolled increase, there are empty private beds. The Jamison solution to this problem is to introduce subsidies and incentives to fill these private beds. In other words, we will use public funds to cover the planning mistakes of private enterprises and, as Senator Chipp says, frequently enterprises which are not Australian and frequently enterprises which are, in fact, fronts for organisations whose main aim is to sell hospital equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is difficult to come to grips with the Jamison report because of its inconsistencies and, in some cases, its vagueness on some of the important issues. On the positive side, it certainly gives a clear recognition of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for funding, for monitoring and for the setting of standards in some areas. As I said before, we welcome the omission of the expected recommendation which was widely touted in the Press that public hospital beds should be means tested. Of course, this may be because of the apparent refusal of State health Ministers to reintroduce such means testing. Such an arrangement would call into status the question of a wide range of benefits outside the health area and would cause great difficulties in administration.

The report, at one stage, suggests a new way of collecting money for patients in public hospitals, that of taxing the underlying benefits which people receive in kind. We oppose this as, I believe, most people in the community do, on the grounds that such taxing, of course, would be inequitable, would disadvantage the ill and would advantage tax avoiders, but it would also be an administrative nightmare, as the report admits. It is also one of the many proposals that are designed to force people back into the private health insurance funds. Other proposals are designed to do this too. Recommendation 22 states:
Payment of medical benefits be limited to the insured.
Recommendation 23 states:
The uninsured to be able to obtain Commonwealth benefits by contributing for those benefits in relation to medical and hospital costs only . . .
Recommendation 29 states:
Health insurance premiums be structured so as to allow a discount for those who take both forms of cover . . .
Recommendation 30 states:
A charge be raised for non-urgent outpatient attendances.

Some of the proposals have been designed to benefit both the private funds and the private hospitals. Recommendation 50, for example, advocates additional direct bed-day subsidies to be paid on a confidential basis on direct claims from the hospitals. This is a procedure in which I would have little or no confidence at all. Recommendation 51 advocates the right to admit pensioners and veterans to private hospitals at private hospital prices, which is an expensive way of treating people who are adequately treated now in the public hospitals.

We support some recommendations of the report namely those we believe would result in real savings. We support the recommendation to phase out the right of private practice for salaried specialists and the surprising recommendation questioning the wisdom of continuing to use public funds to subsidise privately-owned profit-making homes for the aged and handicapped, et cetera. Many recommendations deal with accountability, accreditation and improvement in hospital efficiency. Some will cost money in the short term; many of them will have long term beneficial effects. There are many recommendations on cost sharing and funding allocations to the States which are just too inexact and too complicated for anyone to argue without a careful discussion with the States and careful consideration of the long term effects.

We are concerned that the whole direction of the report is to force people back into private funds. Although the report states that provision must be made for the disadvantaged in a way which is easily understood, this is contradicted in other recommendations such as the recommendation that benefits go only to the insured, the proposal to tax benefits in kind and the proposal that increased charges be levied for out-patients. These would put people in specifically low income families in financial hardship by making private fund membership almost compulsory. There is no definition of disadvantaged, there is no elaboration of safeguards in such a system, which I suggest is a considerable omission. I believe we need a national approach. We need equality of opportunity and access to hospitals for all Australians. We need funding based on the ability to pay; that is a system I believe that is probably best funded from taxation or a levy on taxation. We do not need a rigid centralised system obsessed with economic factors. We do not need to be guided by the special pleading of specialist medical groups, private funds or hospital proprietors, be they Australian or multinationals, whose interests are not necessarily those of the patients or those of the public. We need information and, on that basis, we need proper planning. The Jamison report does not give us the answers we need, but that is not all the fault of the commissioners. In future we must be sure that they have proper terms of reference and that they have the information they need to make decisions.

Finally, what we certainly do not need is the erratic, incoherent policy changes of previous years. I fear that in view of the events of previous years this will be much too much to expect. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDEPENDENT PUBLIC INQUIRY INTO DOMESTIC AIR FARES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Senator Chipp has already adverted to the enormous issues of great importance and urgency which are contained in the heavy volumes of the report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares chaired by Mr Holcroft. It is not, I think, competent for any party, whether big or small-unless it be composed of geniuses-to debate immediately the issues arising from the report. Some important issues of government arise from the report, and it is with those that I will deal very briefly.

Honourable senators should be gravely dis- turbed at the course of events that has led to the early conclusion of this very important inquiry and to the tabling of the report. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is on record as saying that the Government has difficulty in getting competent, highly trained and qualified people to conduct inquiries of this kind on behalf of the Government. On this occasion the Government was able to persuade three men-two of them from the business community and one an academic-of great competence to devote their time to an exhaustive inquiry into domestic air fares in Australia. I refer to Mr Warwick Holcroft, chief executive of one of our largest companies, Dr Harold Bell of the AMP Society and Professor Warren Hogan of Sydney University. When honourable senators finally are able to read the report they will note-they will not have to read very much to pick up this-that Mr Holcroft, Dr Bell and Professor Hogan complained in the strongest terms at the way in which they have been treated by the Government. In a letter to the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) they stated:

We submit the Report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. We do so with considerable misgivings. It is a matter for regret that the decision of the Government taken on 26 November 1980 for this Inquiry to report on its investigations by 31 January 1981 caused us to cancel public hearings scheduled for Queensland, South Australia and Victoria and precluded further desirable public examination of the submissions of the two major domestic airlines.

So much for this Government's commitment to the notion of public inquiry and to the notion of receiving the views of the people and of the consumers. These are very strong words from the three members of the inquiry. Later in the letter they refer to the attitude of the Department of Transport and state:

As the Department of Transport is the regulatory authority for domestic air fares determination in Australia we also found it quite unhelpful that its submission was not received until 10 December, that is, some two weeks after the Government had already moved to curtail the Inquiry. This made it impracticable to examine the Department in public hearing. Nor was any written submission received from the Bureau of Transport Economics.

The members of the inquiry quite properly complained that on 9 September last year, while the inquiry was under way, they learned through the Press, the newspapers, that the Government was to negotiate a new 10-year two-airline agreement. This occurrence, say the members of the inquiry, caused them to feel 'misplaced'. That is the understatement of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good word.

—That is perhaps putting too fine a point on it. In addition to all the other obvious capabilities and virtues of the members of this committee of inquiry, they are courteous in the extreme in describing themselves as feeling 'misplaced'.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the inquiry's report is a scathing condemnation of the Government's cavalier treatment of a subject that is of great seriousness for thousands and thousands of Australians. After the Government's treatment of this inquiry there can be no confidence that it will take seriously any of the recommendations made by the inquiry itself. One wonders whether that means that Ansett Airlines of Australia will continue to dictate airline policy in this country. I ask that by way of a rhetorical question to which I am not able to give an answer immediately.

There are very serious questions about the way in which the Government tolerates Ansett's involvement in non-airline activities and the extent to which that involvement affects the scale of domestic air fares in Australia. There are serious questions about the refusal to utilise 2,000 empty Qantas seats each week between Perth and the eastern States. Western Australians are being discriminated against not only in the failure to use this space capacity but also in the scale of fares between Perth and the east. We are entitled to know from the Government why it has effectively rubber stamped proposals for air fare increases in the past.

There are some other important points which emerge from the report and which can be briefly raised. Why was the inquiry effectively pre-empted by the Minister for Transport in signing this new two-airline agreement before the inquiry which was designed to obtain the views of the travelling Australian public and of experts in relation to the operations of the airline industry in this country was completed? The inquiry was in fact wound up by the Government. Why was there such haste in the completion of the inquiry before there could be a proper public examination of the submissions by Ansett and Trans-Australia Airlines, the two major domestic airlines? How does the Government expect to coerce people with suitable qualifications-outstanding qualifications in this case-to take part in public inquiries after the treatment meted out to Mr Holcroft, Dr Bell and Professor Hogan? Furthermore, the most important question of all is: What action is to be taken by the Minister for Transport in relation to the conduct of the Department of Transport in the way in which it treated this inquiry? Of course, the ultimate question to be asked is: Does the Minister for Transport accept responsibility for the conduct of his Department, as he ought to do? I ask a question which has become ridiculous in the context of this Government: Does the Minister for Transport in this circumstance intend to follow the great Westminster tradition and resign because of the total failure of his Department to co-operate with an important inquiry of this kind? I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a few remarks in relation to the report of the Holcroft Committee of Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, to direct attention to some matters which I believe are of very great significance to this chamber in a consideration of the likely impact of the recommendations which have been made, including some of the shortcomings forced upon the members of that inquiry as a result of the curtailment of the time and the effect of that, and to ask whether some consideration should not be given to a further inquiry so that some of the areas left undone can be covered. One of the principal factors which the inquiry discovered and which is no surprise to anybody familiar with the operation of transport in Australia and in other countries is that in relation to air transport, as in relation to ground and sea transport, forms of cross-subsidisation have been taking place. That is not novel, but it is something which the inquiry quite legitimately pointed out has been taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry raised the whole question of the fare formula and structure and asked whether they should be approached simply from the point of view of a direct cost for service or whether there is room for consideration of philosophies which relate to social welfare, such as concessions for pensions or for other sectors of the community. It raised the question of compensation to areas of Australia, including in particular Tasmania which is not provided with as much expenditure in relation to road and rail services. The inquiry asked whether there should be some compensation for that State in consideration of the only practical available means of transport to it for the largest percentage of the population. There are considerations of national development and whether some areas of Australia should not receive some form of cross-subsidisation in the interests of national development. There is the overall question of whether equalisation should apply and the extent to which it should apply.

We find that unfortunately there has been no full investigation of the cost structures of the airlines. There are suggestions that the cost structures of the major Australian domestic airlines do not compare favourably with those of similar airlines in other countries, particularly the United States. Whether or not that is a fact, it is something which I believe would be of greater significance for future domestic airline policy. It is unfortunate that the inquiry was not able to complete its investigation in that respect. At the moment we are without any real information as to the cost structures of the airlines and, therefore, as to the reasonableness or otherwise of the submissions which they make for fares and fare increases.

We are also confronted with debating a two-airline agreement which has been negotiated and signed when we have not at this stage before us a report from the Australian National Airlines Commission in relation to the operation of one of the two major domestic airlines. As in previous years, and through no fault of TAA itself, that report is very last in being presented to the Parliament. The annual report of TAA for the financial year ended 30 June last year is still not available. In previous years TAA's reports have been presented at any time between May and November of the year following the completion of the previous financial year, having made their way through the morass, it appears, of the Department of Transport and of the Executive Government. I emphasise that I say that not critically of TAA because I am informed, and believe, that TAA has been able to get its financial statements prepared and presented to the sections of government quite early after the completion of the financial year and certainly by October. It is unfortunate, when people are expected to consider questions to do with the operations of our domestic airlines, that information is either not available or is presented to the Parliament in a very tardy way. Many other matters could be referred to, but in taking up what Senator Button referred to in relation to the Holcroft inquiry I wanted to add those further matters at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I listened with interest to what Senator Rae has just said and was very disappointed that he did not join with Senator Button in condemning the Government on this extraordinary action because Senator Rae of all senators has been the senator who has stood out in criticising the Government for-and Senator Button has properly described them as such in this instance-cavalier actions of the worst kind. PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to complaints made in respect of members of the Australian Federal Police, and for related purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will apply to complaints in respect of members of the Australian Federal Police; its purpose, to use the words of the Law Reform Commission in its first report on complaints against police, 'is to establish a system which permits just and thorough investigation of complaints against police, while at the same time upholding morale and discipline in the difficult work police have to do'. Establishment of such a system is clearly one of the most effective ways of maintaining and improving good relations between members of the public and a police force and the respect in which that force is generally held.

In large measure, the Bill implements the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission in its supplementary report on complaints against police furnished in April 1978 at the request of Attorney-General Ellicott. Thus, the Bill recognises the need identified by the Commission for certain elements of independence in the receipt, handling, investigation and determination of complaints against police. The first of these elements is use of the Ombudsman as 'neutral territory' for the receipt of complaints, as the investigator of last resort and as public guardian to ensure that adequate and proper steps are taken in relation to complaints. The second element is establishment by statute of a special unit of the Police Force titled the 'Internal Investigation Division' with a specialised and independent function of investigating complaints by members of the public against police. Investigation of complaints against police will normally be carried out by this unit. I mention that a unit of this nature has already been established by the Commissioner by administrative action. The third element of independence will be the establishment of a police disciplinary tribunal whose president will be a judge to hear charges against police officers of breaches of the disciplinary code. However, as recommended by the Commission, criminal charges against police will continue to be dealt with in the ordinary criminal courts.

The Bill lays down detailed procedures for the handling of complaints against police directed to ensuring that any complaint is thoroughly and effectively investigated. I now describe these procedures:
A complaint by a member of the public as to police conduct may be made to a police officer or to the Ombudsman; where made to a police officer, the Ombudsman must be notified.
Complaints as to practices and procedures of the Force will ordinarily be investigated by the Ombudsman.
Other complaints as to the police, that is to say, complaints as to conduct of individual officers, will be investigated initially by the Internal Investigation Division previously mentioned.

If the Ombudsman is dissatisfied with the report of the Investigation Division on a complaint, he may ask for a further investigation by the Investigation Division or he may carry out an investigation by his own office.

In special circumstances, the Commissioner and the Ombudsman may agree that either the Ombudsman or a person outside the Investigation Division should make the initial investigation of a complaint; if the Ombudsman and the Commissioner cannot agree on this matter, the Minister shall decide.
The Minister may, on his own initiative, establish a special inquiry into any matter relating to the Force.

After considering the report of the Investigation Division or the report of his own investigation, the Ombudsman may recommend that criminal or disciplinary charges should be brought against a member; if the Commissioner does not agree with the recommendation, the matter shall be referred to the Attorney-General, who shall decide what charges, if any, should be brought.

Criminal charges against a police officer will be brought in the ordinary courts; disciplinary charges originating from a complaint from a member of the public will be dealt with by the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal to be established under the legislation; other disciplinary charges will also be heard by the Tribunal if the member so requests or the Commissioner so determines.
The Tribunal will be constituted by a judge of the Federal Court or Supreme Court of a State or Territory or magistrate or legal practitioner.
When the Tribunal is constituted by a judge, it will determine guilt and punishment.
When the Tribunal is not constituted by a judge, it will determine guilt and refer the question of punishment to the Commissioner.
There will be an appeal to the Tribunal constituted by a judge from a penalty imposed by the Commissioner.
The Attorney-General may appeal to the Tribunal from a decision of the Commissioner as to penalty on the grounds that the penalty imposed is inadequate.
There will be an appeal to the Federal Court on a question of law, which is defined to include a question whether there is sufficient evidence to justify a finding of fact.
A police officer may be required by a person proposing to complain to furnish his name and place of duty.

Mr Deputy President, on the details of the scheme, there were extensive consultations within Government and with the Ombudsman and the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police. The Law Reform Commission proposals were made before the establishment of the Australian Federal Police and this development in itself made necessary some variation of the Commission's proposals. As a result of the consultations, the Bill incorporates a number of variations in detail from the Commission's recommendations. These variations will, in the Government's view, improve the general effectiveness of the proposed system while in no way detracting from the objectives identified by the Commission. Dealing with the first of these variations, the Commission contemplated that the Ombudsman would retain his existing jurisdiction under the Ombudsman Act 1976 in relation to the police force in parallel with the new jurisdiction to be given to him under the proposed legislation. The Government, however, concluded that such an arrangement could produce uncertainty and confusion and it would be preferable for the relevant provisions of the Ombudsman Act to be incorporated in the new legislation so that the Ombudsman's role in relation to complaints against police will be dealt with in the one Act. However, whilst the variations should produce greater convenience and certainty, the end result will be substantially the same as that intended by the Commission.

The second variation concerns the Commission's recommendation that the Ombudsman would be empowered to conduct his own investigations in certain limited cases. As I have explained, the Bill will empower the Ombudsman in all cases to conduct his own investigation if dissatisfied with the Investigation Division's report. Further, the Ombudsman will conduct the initial investigation when the complaint is as to the practices and procedures of the force. Additionally, in special cases, when the Ombudsman and Commissioner so agree or the Minister determines, the Ombudsman may conduct the initial investigation. Thus, in total result, the Ombudsman will be given an effective and meaningful role in investigation of complaints against police. Pending the introduction of legislation, the Commissioner and the Ombudsman have, by administrative steps, put into effect arrangements similar in effect to these provisions of the Bill and I understand that these arrangements are operating effectively and satisfactorily.

The next variation concerns the Commission's recommendation that 'in extreme circumstances' the Ombudsman should be in a position to ensure that a charge is laid against a police officer by making a formal recommendation to such effect. On consideration of this proposal, the Government concluded that a more effective arrangement would be to provide that, following an appropriate investigation, the Ombudsman may recommend to the Commissioner what charges, if any, should be laid against a police officer and confer with the Commissioner on this matter. Failing agreement between the Ombudsman and the Commissioner, the matter will be referred to the Attorney-General, who will decide what action, if any, should be taken as regards charging the police officer. A further variation concerns the Commission's recommendations that provision should be made for conciliation by the Ombudsman but not only by the Commissioner. The Government considered that it would be appropriate to provide for conciliation by the Commissioner as well as the Ombudsman, subject to appropriate safeguards such as notification to the Ombudsman, who may require the complaint to be investigated in spite of the Commissioner's conciliation action.

In dealing with the jurisdiction of the proposed Disciplinary Tribunal, the Commission recommended that the Tribunal should in all cases determine the penalty as well as the guilt of the defendant. Recognising the need for the Commissioner to be, and to be seen to be, the source of discipline within the force, the Government concluded, as I have explained, that the Tribunal, when constituted by other than a judge should determine only guilt, the penalty being remitted to the Commissioner for determination. However, when the Tribunal is constituted by a judge, the Bill provides that it should determine both guilt and penalty. Further, the Attorney-General may appeal to the Disciplinary Tribunal if he is of the opinion that the punishment imposed by the Commissioner is inadequate.

The Commission recommended provision of a right of appeal to the Federal Court on questions of law from decisions of the Disciplinary Tribunal. The Bill makes it clear that this right of appeal extends to questions whether there is sufficient evidence to justify a finding of fact by the Tribunal. The final variation from the Commission's recommendations that I shall mention at this stage concerns the Commission's recommendations that the complainant might, with leave of the Tribunal, participate as a party in the hearing. Under the Bill, the complainant may be a witness in proceedings against the police officer and would participate in the proceedings in that capacity but, because the Government concluded that addition of a third party to disciplinary proceedings against a police officer would be an undesirable complication, more likely to create practical difficulties and extend hearing time than assist in the achieving of justice, it did not follow the Commission's recommendation that the complainant might be joined as a party.

The Bill should be regarded as in no way a reflection on the Australian Federal Police or its members who, with the fewest possible exceptions, perform their difficult tasks with honesty, zeal and devotion to duty. However, for the reasons I have explained, it is necessary that an effective and just system of investigating complaints by members of the public against police officers should be established. This Bill will establish such a system and the minor variations from the Commission's proposals that I have indicated in no way detract from the great credit due to the Commission for its evolution of the basic concept on which this Bill is constructed. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill complements the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill 1981 in that it implements further important recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission in its supplementary report on complaints against police. The first was a recommendation for removal of the long-standing anomaly in relation to the vicarious responsibility of the Commonwealth for the acts of police officers. For many years the Commonwealth has been vicariously responsible for the wrongful acts of its officers, servants or agents but, except in the circumstances covered by the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act 1959, the Commonwealth has not been so responsible for the acts of police officers in the course of their duties.

There is no sufficient reason why a police officer should, in this regard, be placed in a different position to that of any other officer of the Commonwealth. Accordingly, the Government was glad to accept the Commission's recommendation in this regard and the Bill will make the Commonwealth liable for civil wrongs committed by police officers in the performance of their duties. The result will be more satisfactory, not only from the point of view of the citizen claiming damages, but also the police officer in question.

The Law Reform Commission pointed out that absence of identification numbers in the dress of uniformed police reduced the capacity of a complainant to make a meaningful complaint. To remedy this, the Commission recommended imposition of a requirement for members of certain ranks of the police force to wear identification numbers. The Bill implements this recommendation. The Bill thus plays an important part in the general implementation of the recommendations of the Commission and I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 August 1980 Senator Walters used the same device and directed a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. However, an honourable senator is not able to follow up the matter then.

If a somewhat considered answer is given by the Minister at the end of Question Time, an honourable senator is not in the same situation as he would be in if he asked that question and got an answer earlier in Question Time. Of course, he then could ask a supplementary question. Because the information is given at the end of Question Time, an honourable senator cannot ask a supplementary question. To my thinking that is absolute nonsense. Why should it matter when the answer is given or whether the Minister chooses not to answer the question in the first place but wants to check his facts and answer it later? Why should honourable senators be denied the opportunity of asking a supplementary question?

Supplementary questions are important in making this place intelligible and useful. They are important in enabling us to check the material and to point out the places where Ministers have not-whether by accident or by design-answered part of the question. It should be possible to do so. I regret to say that the Standing Orders Committee has passed up an opportunity. It states that one can ask for leave or one can ask the question on a subsequent day. It fails to recognise the value of being able to ask supplementary questions when the further information is given. I regret very much its answer to this matter. Therefore, I shall vote against noting this item.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak to item 1 (ii)-'Supplementary Questions on Deferred Answers'. I take up that item firstly because Senator Missen has put a case that honourable senators should be able to ask supplementary questions on deferred answers. However, I believe the report of the Senate Standing Orders Committee points to a way in which honourable senators can seek leave to ask a supplementary question. Possibly Senator Missen would like the automatic right of asking a supplementary question about an answer which has been deferred. However, leave would very seldom be refused in this place if an honourable senator were to seek leave to ask a supplementary question at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a further means of which an honourable senator may avail himself, and that is to seek leave to make a statement on the answer that was just given. He cannot do that during Question Time, but he can do that after Question Time is completed and Ministers are giving answers to questions asked previously. So really there is flexibility in that area. There is the ability of the honourable senator to have an added right and to take advantage of that right by seeking leave to make a statement on the answer. Perhaps that would be of even greater use than asking a supplementary question.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can do that now.

—I know you can do that now and I would say that that would possibly be sufficient. However, I would agree with Senator Missen that if we could have an automatic right to ask a supplementary question to a deferred answer, that may be of some assistance. I would be prepared to support the idea if other honourable senators feel strongly about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to item 1 (i)-'Giving Notice of Questions'. We are considering a matter of degree. Senator McLaren has taken a view that it ought not to happen. Senator Missen says it is an advisable practice and that it is an advantage to the Minister to have some foreknowledge of the question. Generally speaking, Government members do give some indication to the Minister that they are going to ask a question. They might say: 'Look, I will be asking a question on Noonkanbah in some general terms'. I do not think there is anything wrong with Government senators saying that to the Minister, at least to free the Minister from the tensions of the unexpected. However, from the Opposition side it is not wise for any honourable senator to give prior notice to Ministers. The Opposition is not here to improve the performance of Ministers. The Opposition is here to seek to disadvantage, and often does disadvantage, a Minister and Ministers are aware of that. I do not think it is wise or desirable for honourable senators from the Opposition side to give prior notice even in the most general terms.

Senator McLaren has to be listened to when he brings forward examples of questions being given to a Minister in sufficient time for that Minister to get a prepared answer from the relevant department. That question really becomes a question on notice and should be treated as such, particularly if the question seeks a detailed answer. In many cases a question has been asked by an honourable senator on the Government side and a lengthy answer with much information is given which should not be given during Question Time which is for the asking of questions without notice. The question really should be placed on notice. That is the type of question to which I think Senator McLaren is objecting. He is objecting to that practice which, on one occasion, was abused to the extent of one senator being responsible for not only posing the question but also for giving the information for the answer. That is really abusing the system and that is what Senator McLaren is pointing at. He objects to prior notice of questions being given in such a way that great detail is given in the answer.

The Opposition often suspects that the reason it has been asked in a lengthy form and answered in an extra lengthy way is to take up time. If that device is used to take up time, of course, the Opposition is seriously disadvantaged, particularly when one considers sub-item (iii), regarding the Government always asking for further questions to be placed on notice after one hour has lapsed. That means that if the Government wants to do so and if the Whips intend to, Government senators can give prior notice of a whole series of questions with the answers prepared and put them in the hands of Ministers to bat out time. I do not think that is of advantage to anyone in this place.

I suggest that the Standing Orders Committee may take a look at some way in which a question can be placed on notice so that that question can be asked or answered after Question Time. I am suggesting that there ought to be some provision by which, if a senator believes a question to be very important but it requires a detailed or researched answer from the Minister's staff, that question is placed on notice for answer that day. That would obviate these rather lengthy prepared questions and answers being read out which takes up most of Question Time which is for the asking of questions without notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —There should be a third category.

—That is what I am saying. There should be a category for honourable senators who want information on the day the question is asked. The question could be important and require detailed information. It could need to be researched or perhaps referred back to the Department of Foreign Affairs, for example, for the supply of an answer. There should be some means whereby we can place questions on notice and have an answer supplied that day. If the facility is also then given for a supplementary question to be asked on that deferred answer then perhaps we could, in some way, prevent the misuse of Question Time by Ministers having prepared questions and prepared answers.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet I want to talk about item 1(iii). I have objected strongly to anyone in the Senate taking over the right of the Senate to determine any matter. It is the practice for senators to seek leave. It does not matter who happens to be seeking to do something; he must have the leave of the Senate. The practice in this place is that the Leader of the Government stands up and says: 'I ask that all further questions be placed on notice'. He does not seek leave to bring that about. My view about that has always been that the Leader of the Government should ask for leave to place all further questions on notice. If that leave is refused then, of course, Ministers can simply suggest that every other question that is asked of them be placed on notice. The point I am trying to make is that nothing should be done here by anyone, and especially by a member of the Executive, without first obtaining leave of the Senate. I suggest that we devise some means whereby the Leader of the Government should seek leave of the Senate for all further questions to be placed on notice. If he is refused leave then the obvious device for Ministers is to have all further questions placed on notice. That right of the Senate to determine its business should not be taken away from it. I believe that in the instance I gave it has been taken away. I will continue to object to such practices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with item 1, sub-items (i), (ii) and (iii) of the Standing Orders Committee fifth report for the 59th session. Are we all being honest when we say that the purpose of our questions is to obtain information? Since I became a senator I have fought very hard against recommendations of the Standing Orders Committee. During my time as a senator, the Committee has done nothing but bring down reports aimed at taking away the rights and the freedoms of individual members of this Parliament. I have continually opposed such reports. In fact, I have welcomed reports which have proposed no change. On those occasions our rights have been preserved.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of Question Time is a very complicated one. I strongly support Standing Orders 99 and 100. They are adequate for proper administration of Question Time. What I am about to say may be misinterpreted by men for whom I have great admiration, but Standing Orders, whatever they may say, are ineffective if they are not interpreted and policed as it was intended that they should be when they were implemented. Some members of my party think I have a good knowledge of the Standing Orders. However, I find that I do not. Although I do not think I am stupid in my understanding of the Standing Orders, on occasions when I have raised a point of order on what I have considered a breach of the Standing Orders it has not been upheld. So obviously I am an idiot and I was wrong in my belief that the Standing Orders had been breached. Therefore, if we feel we will solve anything by altering the Standing Orders we have a responsibility to ensure that the new Standing Orders are rigidly enforced-and it is the President who should enforce them. I accept that when Question Time has been broadcast it has never been a time used to seek information. If Government members had to seek information from their Ministers at Question Time they might show a lack of confidence in their Government and their Ministers. They know that they can get the information they seek directly from a Minister or his Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the public interest.

—Is it in the public interest? We had a question the other day about what Mr Bannon said and whether it represented a change in Labor's policy in South Australia. Did the honourable senator who asked the question endeavour to obtain information to serve the people who elected him or did he want the Minister to say that Bannon was a renegade from the Labor Party who was trying to twist the wrist of the Labor Party? The reason for such questions is obvious. Many members are frustrated at times by an inability to put questions. They may feel that they have been overlooked or that someone else is getting preference. There is not sufficient time for answers to be given to all the questions honourable senators may wish to ask.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Standing Orders Committee has erred greatly. It has not gone into the detail of what has happened in past years. I have read in its report that from 1967 to 1973, for some six years, there was no time limit on Question Time. My recollection of that time is that most days Question Time finished within an hour. So, limiting Question Time will not necessarily shorten Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —There may be more long-winded senators now than there were then.

—No. I will tell the honourable senator what happened. It is true that some days Question Time lasted an hour and a half but everyone who wanted to ask a question asked it and asked it as many times as he desired.
