In this way many questions were asked in one day. However, it was rare that Question Time lasted longer than an hour. Many times-I remember the times-Question Time finished in 20 minutes. Question Time was accepted as a procedure for the Opposition to get its propaganda over to the nation. It was a time for grievances, a time to embarrass a Minister or a time to get some point over to the public about a Minister's neglect. Everybody was satisfied to give the Opposition this time for airing grievances and for publicity reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1973 that was altered. At that time the great reformer, Senator Murphy, was the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He got the idea that some limitation must be placed on Question Time. He proposed a limit of one hour. The Chairman of the Committee upheld his right to limit Question Time. He asked: 'Why should our Ministers be shot at for an hour during Question Time? Why can't we take up at least half of that time in putting our propaganda over the air? It then became the practice not for members to give questions to Ministers for Ministers to prepare answers but for Ministers to write out questions and answers and give the questions to members to ask. That practice is still going on today. I give Senator Missen some credit. I think he asks questions, as do others, to show his concern for human rights and his concern for law reform. The practice is designed to limit the obligation of Ministers to answer the criticisms which are forthcoming if there is a barrage of questions from the Opposition from time to time. With no limitation on Question Time, the Opposition had the say, but there was no advantage in Government senators asking questions unless they wanted information. The only time a Government senator asked a question was when he wanted information. Of course, he then asked it. Very few Government senators wanted information that they could not get by approaching the Minister in the lobby, so they did not ask their questions at Question Time. This caused a reduction in the length of Question Time. Everyone was happy and satisfied with Question Time.

I refer now to supplementary questions and deferred answers. I think that serious consideration should be given to whether supplementary questions should be permitted to be asked at all. The practice of asking supplementary questions was introduced only in the time that Sir Magnus Cormack was President. Although the practice had some advantages no one in the chamber can say that it has not been abused.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not been what?

—Not been abused. If I were pointing a finger of guilt, Senator Walsh might be in trouble. When a supplementary question is asked it can be entirely different from the one asked originally. It was intended that if insufficient information were given in the Minister's answer to the first question one could ask for elaboration. Now a supplementary question takes this form: 'Do I take it from the Minister's answer that he means so and so?' Where does one go? This is such a waste of time, such an abuse of the practice of asking supplementary questions, that I think all honourable senators should be forced, if they want to use further propaganda in questions, to raise their supplementary question the next day rather than get the opportunity to ask their question at that time and take the time of back benchers.

—It seems to me that some of the points raised by Senator Georges and others would be of value. Could the Senate Standing Orders Committee not consider a situation in which there is perhaps a set time of questions without notice which indeed are questions without notice and immediately following that a category of questions on notice for answer that day? It seems to me if that device were provided it would avoid many of the difficulties that have been complained of by honourable senators and would certainly remove completely any suggestion that Question Time was being padded out with prepared answers. It seems to me that additional time should be set aside for prepared answers. After all, the length of that additional time would be pretty much at the discretion of the Government. The Government would decide the length of those answers. If the Government wished to devote a lengthy period to such answers that would take from the time in which honourable senators might be engaged in other business of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is re-examining the problems that existed in 1979, which continued right through to 1980 and which to some extent may continue through 1981. We are dealing with a problem which I think we can say probably affects the Opposition more than it does the government. It is a question then of establishing the parameters by which Question Time should operate. Is the purpose of Question Time solely to seek information? Is not the purpose of Question Time also to test the capacity of Ministers and the Government? It seems to me that other considerations have allowed Question Time to be developed in the Westminster system. As I understand it, at the time of its commencement the Westminster system was largely designed to provide for all members to put the Government or the Executive in a situation where their actions had to be defended.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that we have seen evolve in Western-style democracies a system of rigid party development. So with the evolution of time a system has developed where the rights of honourable senators and members in the other place have changed somewhat, to the point where now the original concept no longer operates-that is, all members putting members of the Executive on their mettle, testing them in respect of their knowledge and capacities properly to fulfil their public functions. I suppose because of the way in which our party systems operate it is understandable that Government members would be seeking to do nothing that would embarrass their own Government, whereas the Opposition would do everything it could to establish either the veracity or the capacity of the Ministers on the other side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that a simplistic view, though?

—It is true that some Government members-I pay tribute to them from time to time; some of them are present in the chamber-still test Ministers by putting forward questions because they really want information. But it must surely be conceded by Government members that we have seen develop a system to which we object and one which has been abused. I certainly would have no objection if Government senators were to say-my colleague Senator Georges has indicated this-that they propose to ask a question in respect of Aboriginals at Noonkanbah, Arnhem Land or whatever you like. I think that is fair enough. If they were to say to a Minister: 'We propose to ask you a question specifically about A, B and C in respect of those matters', it is no longer a matter of asking questions without notice. It is establishing an undue influence and creating an unfair situation so far as the Opposition is concerned because it has the effect of arming the Government with another means by which it can defend its political position.

SPEECH.PARA: When Opposition senators ask Ministers questions for the purpose of testing the Government, testing a Minister, of course we find time and again that the Minister gives us brief and unsatisfactory answers which do not in any way meet the requirements of giving information. I grant that on some occasions that happens because the Minister does not have intimate knowledge of the matter, particularly when it is concerned with an area in relation to which he only represents the Minister. Subsequent to such an answer being given we see a Government senator asking a question which clearly would come within the same category as the previous question-that is to say, it seeks information which is not readily available to the Minister insofar as it deals with an area in relation to which the Minister only represents the responsible Minister-but in respect of which the Minister has information because he has been well and truly briefed in respect of the matter.

In 1979 we saw continued abuse of the system whereby one or two fairly newly appointed Ministers-I do not want to make an issue of this because honourable senators will concede that I am not interested in personalities-were asked technical questions and would then speak for five minutes, obviously from a prepared brief. Of course, that practice led the Opposition to raise an objection and to have this matter referred to the Standing Orders Committee. We really need some refinement. Perhaps it should be the refinement suggested by Senator Mason or perhaps it should be left for the President to establish whether a senator has indicated to the Minister that he intends to raise a certain subject matter or has asked a detailed question for which an answer has already been provided by the Department. This practice negates the whole principle of questions without notice. I think we have seen a continuation of it although I must admit that in the brief life of this new Parliament practically every Minister has attempted to give me some sort of answer to the questions I have asked.

I found during 1979-80 that when I asked a question without notice not only to seek information but also to test the capacity of a Minister I was just getting a twenty-word reply, and that was the end of the matter. I would then get a written reply three or four months later which would have completely lost its relevance. I find the way in which the Standing Orders Committee has dealt with this matter unsatisfactory as indeed other honourable senators from both sides of the House have suggested. Committee members have thought: 'The problem is there. It has probably been with us for a long time. It is too hard to work out a refinement so we will just maintain the status quo'. I do not think that is a particularly satisfactory way to handle the problem. I think we ought to say to the Ministers on the present front bench: 'We want much shorter answers to questions, particularly those asked by Government senators. We want less provocative answers than were given in the previous Parliament and we look forward to you really giving the sort of information that defends the Government's actions'. I think that is fair enough. We certainly do not look forward to a continuation of the attitude that existed in the previous Parliament when sometimes a Minister would take five minutes in which to attack everything from A to Z in the Australian Labor Party from one part of the continent to another. That is really not what Question Time is about. The preamble to the Notice of Question paper-this relates to what Senator Cavanagh said-states:

Questions addressed to a Minister should relate to the public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in Parliament, or to any matter of administration for which the Minister is responsible.

I think honourable senators will agree with me that we have seen time and again that this has been offended against. This has happened, as Senator Cavanagh stated, in respect to Mr Bannon. In no way could the question asked in respect of Mr Bannon be said to have anything to do with public affairs with which the Minister is connected or with any matters pending in Parliament or any matters of administration for which the Minister is responsible. Yet, that question was permitted to be answered. We really must look toward a better way to proceed with questions without notice.

I also take up the point of Question Time itself, a matter which Senator Georges raised. One hour has crept in as the maximum period for Question Time. I do not know what is so magical about one hour, or even half an hour for that matter. Once we had 60 members in the Senate but now we have 64. If we just talk about the mathematics of the situation we could argue that the time should be stretched. Question Time is an important issue. Every time there is some matter of controversy in the community members of the public at large say, 'Ask a question', and they believe that I will get an answer. I have this raised with me every week of my political life. I am sure every honourable senator has had the same experience. I have to point out that, of course, it depends upon the Minister. If the Government does not want to answer such a question it will not do so. Certainly, it is the Opposition's experience to get unsatisfactory answers to questions. Yet the public at large really believes that we have been putting the Minister on his mettle and that the question has been asked because it is vexed and controversial. It is a question that the public wants an answer to. But subterfuge is resorted to by the Minister because he or she is on the spot and the honourable senator asking the question gets a cursory answer that does not in any way satisfy himself or the person or group outside which asked him to pose that question.

I concede that this probably happened in the period in which the Whitlam Government was in office; but if that was one of our misdemeanours we probably had good masters. Certainly I saw what I am now complaining about happen from the moment that I came into the Parliament. If we really want to have Question Time for the purpose for which it was originally established in the Westminster system we ought to look at the matter in a much more objective way and not in a way that everything on one side is right and everything on the other side is wrong. From time to time I have heard Government senators expressing their concern about the role of the Executive. I know, of course, that if an honourable senator on the Government side does anything that might embarrass his government he is in all sorts of trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he?

—Yes, Senator Missen. That applies to both sides. I am not attempting to score points. I am attempting to point out the absurdity of the situation in which our rights are being restricted because we must not dare ask a question that might embarrass a Minister. Of course, that negates part of the fundamental principle upon which the Parliament operates. I would like to get a reply not just on this issue but on all of the issues because now we are virtually in a stand-still position. We are not making very much progress at all. I think that is a matter for regret. I think we ought to say to the Standing Orders Committee: 'Let us have a look at the matter to see whether we can get a better understanding so that the role of individual senators is protected from the processes that have grown up as a result of the rigidity of the party system as it has developed in this place'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the much maligned Senate Standing Orders Committee I point out regrettably to those who suggested that the response in relation to the matter of Question Time has been less specific than it might have been that it has been more specific than most of the other responses. In fact, it is quite specific. It has been a long established practice for honourable senators to give Ministers informal advice of their questions prior to Questions Time on the subjects they propose to ask questions. Nobody has taken issue with that as far as I know. The practice has gone on for the twelve and a half years or more that I have been here. I think it happens on both sides. In fact, it would be quite interesting-Senator McLaren may wish to suggest that this is something done only by Government senators and never by Opposition senators-if Ministers were to publish a list of all honourable senators who had given prior notice of questions in the last six months.
—I would not be on that list.

—Nor would I. It might be quite interesting to find who was on it, Senator McLaren. I am just trying to emphasise the point that it has been established practice, as stated by the Standing Orders Committee, for some informal advice to be given. The Committee has pointed out that, particularly when Ministers are in a representative capacity, that practice enables there to be a more effective use of Question Time. It is also pointed out by the Standing Orders Committee that it is a destruction of the concept of Question Time for that informal advice to be substituted by total written notice. I would have thought that Senator McLaren would have been quite happy with the reply of the Standing Orders Committee, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee reiterates, however, the distinction between this practice of giving informal advice of the subject of a question to be asked and the giving of written notice of the precise terms of a question calling for a detailed answer. The latter ought to be done by placing the question on the notice paper, in accordance with Standing Order 101.
The very matters that Senator McLaren complained about--

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be, but it is not.

—May I just go on? The very matters that Senator McLaren complained about have been dealt with by the Standing Orders Committee which has said that it is not a practice which should be permitted. That means that if this report were accepted there would be a capacity in this chamber clearly to prevent that happening in the future. I would have thought that was as much as Senator McLaren would have hoped to get from the Standing Orders Committee in relation to that aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to acknowledge the problems which have been raised by a number of other honourable senators. I think Question Time is far from being as satisfactory as it should be. It is an important aspect of the operation of responsible government. It is an important aspect of the accountability of the executive government of the day to the whole of the Parliament-not to one side or the other but to the whole of the Parliament and to the people. I believe there is a clear public interest to be served in ensuring that questions are answered, are answered promptly and are answered publicly and that the information is available to all and is not limited to one side of the Parliament or to one section of the community. Otherwise responsible government, as a concept and as a practice, becomes a farce.

A number of aspects about the operation of Question Time concern me because they do not follow the criteria that I have just suggested. I have suggested that one practice should be changed, but I have not had much success. So let me bring it up again. It is not uncommon for an honourable senator to ask a question without notice and for the Minister then to say: 'I have not got the information but I will get it and let the honourable senator have it as soon as possible'. The honourable senator receives a letter a week, a month or a couple of months later. That letter is posted to the honourable senator privately. It never appears in Hansard. There would be a whole performance to go through to get it into Hansard, but it is an answer to a question which is publicly asked as part of this responsible government accountability process. I believe that is one of the things we can change and ought to change. The process should be that, whilst as a matter of courtesy the answer is posted direct to the honourable senator, it ought also to be processed through the clerks for tabling and incorporated in Hansard. That is just one aspect.

Another procedure that I suggest could improve the whole operation of Question Time quite considerably is a change to the absurd-I use that word quite deliberately-and in many cases disgraceful delay that takes place between the placing of a question on notice and the answer being given. It is quite inexcusable in most circumstances. I know that some honourable senators perhaps ask for information which could be better obtained in other ways and that that perhaps overloads the Notice Paper with matters which are not really part of the accountability process or which need not be put on the public record. Perhaps there is some sympathy to be given to the Executive when there is some overloading with unnecessary questions, but there can be no excuse for the fact that the average question takes so long to be answered. They are sometimes answered in what can be described only as an entirely unsatisfactory way, but if after such a delay an honourable senator tries to follow up with a further question to get a satisfactory answer he can find that it takes two years from the time he first asked the question until he gets the final information.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you don't put it on notice.

—So he does not put it on notice; that was the point I was coming to. Because of the delays in providing answers to questions on notice honourable senators tend to try to ask questions concerning something that is relatively urgent at Question Time as a question without notice.
—Or whack them on the adjournment and keep them up.

—Senator Mulvihill suggests another approach. He can only be regarded as the Senate's qualified expert to give that suggestion to us. I believe that if the Government is concerned at all about needing to limit the length of Question Time so that it can get its business through, it ought to respond to the interests of this chamber by saying: 'We will be a lot more efficient in answering questions that have been put on notice so that we can more readily tell honourable senators that if they put a question on notice they will get an answer very quickly'. It may be that one should even consider the introduction of a new process. I listened to Senator Mason's suggestion for a third category of questions. I would like to suggest another one for consideration; that is, when a Minister is asked a question in a representative capacity the question should be placed on notice automatically. It can be asked in the chamber and then automatically go on notice for answer within two sitting days. That happens in other parliaments of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In some parliaments questions are asked and responses are given within one, two or a limited number of sitting days. That would quite considerably relieve the pressure on Question Time when we could expect Ministers to give answers directly available to them in reply to questions concerning their own ministerial responsibilities.

Question Time is far more likely to be effective as a system of ministerial responsibility and accountability if the answers given to questions asked of Ministers in a representative capacity are given by the Minister who is actually responsible and not by the one in a representative capacity. The danger that exists is that if an honourable senator puts a question on notice he can forget it very often for 3, 6 or 12 months. I believe that rather than complaining about the mere fact that Question Time gets overcrowded we should look at limiting the time for ministerial replies to questions on notice as one of the possible ways of relieving the pressure on Question Time. That is just one of a number of suggestions of things which I believe could be done. I believe Senator Cavanagh's recollection of the practice at Question Time between 1967 and 1973 is one on which he could reflect. Whilst on some occasions there may have been relatively short Question Times, the average length was about one hour and eight minutes to one hour and 15 minutes until Question Time was brought back to an hour in 1973.

TALK.START.PARA: —That wasn't excessive though, was it?

—I did not regard it as excessive. I objected strongly when it was reduced to an hour, and I still object. I am trying to look at other ways for the pressure to be taken off Question Time and for it to be made more efficient. I have made one or two suggestions. I do not want to take up too much time of the Committee of the Whole this afternoon but I would be very happy, as a member of the Standing Orders Committee, to see the matter referred back for some further consideration by the Standing Orders Committee, taking into account the various suggestions that have been made here this afternoon and any others which may come forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -I have to take up two matters, one raised by Senator Missen and the other by Senator Rae. I will deal with Senator Rae first. Senator Rae said that I ought to have taken notice of sub-item 5 of item 1 of the Committee's recommendations which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee reiterates, however, the distinction between this practice of giving informal advice of the subject of a question to be asked and the giving of written notice of the precise terms of a question calling for a detailed answer. The latter ought to be done by placing the question on the notice paper, in accordance with Standing Order 101.

There is no specific recommendation there from the Standing Orders Committee. All the Committee is saying is that the matter ought to be done. Had that word 'ought' been altered to 'should', I think Senator Rae might have had some credence in questioning what I had been talking about. All he is saying is that it ought to be done. It will not be done because when we look at Standing Order 101 we see that it states in part:
Notice of Question shall be given by a Senator delivering the same at the Table, fairly written . . .

It is left to the good sense of honourable senators to do that. I think I have proved here today that written notices of questions are given to Ministers. I am reminded in particular of a written question from Senator Walters. The answer to that question was on the same sheet of paper which was tabled at my request. So I say to Senator Rae that the recommendations need to be stronger if we are to get away from this practice that is being adopted by honourable senators opposite of giving written questions to Ministers and Ministers then coming into this chamber with prepared answers. Senator Missen said that what I said was all nonsense. He completely gave the game away by way of interjection to another honourable senator about this matter of giving notice when he said that it was all in the public interest. He admitted that the only reason for his giving a written or a verbal question to a Minister was to get some publicity for the answer he received in this chamber. That is the very thing that senators on this side of the chamber are complaining about. We have matters of public interest to raise too, just as Government senators do. Whereas Government members can forewarn a Minister of a question and get an answer which they are able to use to political advantage, members of the Opposition do not get an answer so they are at a disadvantage. If honourable senators take the time to read what I have said, they will see that the whole thrust of my argument is that the practice they are adopting-it has gone on for a long time; in fact, ever since 1975 or early 1976-is that the back bench members on the Government side get the kudos for getting answers when they do not really need to come into this chamber and ask questions in the public interest because they have easy access to the Minister and can go to the Department, no matter how curly the question is, and get an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is on the public record.
—Government senators can still put it on the public record and not take up the time of the Senate to the disadvantage of Opposition senators. That is what I am complaining about.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cavanagh spoke about the curtailing of Question Time to one hour. I think he was right in his remarks. I think it was Senator Georges who said that the Leader of the Government in the Senate should seek leave for further questions to be placed on the Notice Paper. If one is sharp in this place sometimes one can catch the Leader of the Government in the Senate out. I recall one occasion last year when the Leader of the Government was not quite on the ball and he moved that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. I jumped to my feet in an attempt to debate the motion but he quickly retreated. I was not quite happy that he was able to do that because he had moved a motion and I felt that I was entitled to speak to it. However, I was not allowed to do so and I think either Senator Georges' or Senator Cavanagh's proposition that the Leader of the Government seek leave to have further questions placed on notice is a good one and ought to be incorporated in the Standing Orders.

Another matter that Senator Rae raised was one which I raised with the President last year-I am still waiting for some action to be taken on it-and that is, the written replies we get to questions. I have a whole heap of them. They are written replies to questions which I asked during the debate on the Appropriation Bills and which have never appeared in Hansard. We get these written replies in the mail during the recess and the only way in which we can get those answers on the public record is to take up the time of the Senate on the first reading of a money Bill, to read them into the Hansard record during the adjournment debate at night or to get permission to incorporate them in Hansard. Senator Rae suggested that action ought to be taken and I am pleased that he and I are on the same wavelength in this regard because on so many occasions we are on the opposite wavelength.

With regard to prepared questions and the lengthy answers that are given I recall one instance here in 1978 involving an answer from former Senator Webster. I think he is on record as giving the longest-winded answers to any questions, no matter what side of the chamber they came from. He was also well known for farming out questions for senators on his own side of the chamber to ask. On this occasion when Senator Brown was in this chamber he spent some time devising a name for an insect and he then asked Senator Webster about the habits of that insect. On 12 April, Senator Brown asked, in part:

Is the Minister aware of a recent report about a pest by the name of servan'i grapier which entomologists uniquely describe as a gum leaf, grass root eating grub, capable of devastating vegetable crops and pastures if protective measures are not taken?
Senator Webster, in a prompt reply, and it was a long one, said in part:

Mr President, I find myself in a very difficult situation. I do not seek your help in this matter but you have heard the points of order raised . . . that questions posed to me on scientific matters are too long and that the answers I attempt to give to those questions are too long.
Senator Brown's question was not very long-winded, but Senator Webster went on to say:

I have several pages of information on this matter. It has taken some time for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to investigate the problems in relation to this important matter.

Honourable senators on this side of the chamber thought Senator Brown had served up a Dorothy Dixer to Senator Webster because of the answer given by Senator Webster. On the next day, that is, 13 April-I give Senator Webster some credit for his expediency-Senator Webster came into this chamber and gave further information on servan'i grapier. He said, in part:

Following a question asked of me yesterday by Senator Brown relating to a particular species of bug, I have been advised by my scientific advisers, after an investigation of the matter raised in his question, as recorded in Hansard, that they are unable to identify any pest species with a name like the one Senator Brown committed to Hansard . . .

So there we are. Senator Webster said that he had pages and pages of detail about that grub; yet the next day he came into this chamber and said that, after investigation by his Department or by the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organisation, or whatever, the grub did not exist. Of course it did not exist because it took Senator Brown several hours the night before he asked the question to make up the name of the bug. That is how the time of the Senate was taken up and and that was the type of thing we had to put up with, with Ministers purporting that they had full knowledge and trying to big-note themselves in their electorate. This is what is going on now with these questions we are complaining about. They are served up to Ministers in written form and the Minister is able to come in to the chamber with an answer. Everyone then thinks 'My word, he is a capable Minister', just like they used to think Senator Webster was. Ministers get the answer off pat and can tell the world at large the answer to every problem. Of course we on this side of the chamber are completely disadvantaged.

Another matter I want to raise on this item in the Standing Orders Committee report concerns the time taken in the giving and answering of questions without notice. This matter was raised last year and the President put down a statement on 23 May last year in which he gave some figures on the time taken in asking questions and the time taken in answering them. But the times are correlated so that one cannot dissect the time taken to ask the question and the time taken to answer a question. It would appear from the dates specified in the schedule that the President put down that members of the Oppostion get far more opportunity to ask questions and to get answers than do members of the Government. The first list was for the period from 19 February 1980 to 28 February 1980, a period of six days; while the next period was from 21 May to 25 May, another period of six days. If we try to take an analysis whereby members on the Government side and members on the Opposition side ask the same number of questions, the results are very revealing. We find that on 21 February last year Government members asked 12 questions and the time taken in asking those questions and the time taken in answering them was 29 minutes. On the same day members of the Opposition asked 12 questions and the time taken to answer them was 21 minutes. So Government members had an advantage of 8 minutes over senators on the Opposition side. The only other day which I can find where we had an equal number of questions was 27 February. On that day 17 questions were asked by Government members and the time taken in asking and answering them was 32 minutes 10 seconds; while for the 17 questions asked by members of the Opposition, not taking into account the Australian Democrats, the time taken was 23 minutes 20 seconds. There is written proof. If honourable senators could go through that in detail they might find that what we have been complaining about is quite legitimate.

We can see clearly that when the same number of questions have been asked by each side the time given to the government senators has been greater-in one instance, eight minutes more and on another day about nine minutes more. So government senators have an advantage over the Opposition on just about every occasion. That is something about which we are complaining. Of course, the President has no jurisdiction in regard to many of these matters. A person on the other side asks a long question and the Minister gives a long detailed answer, which Opposition senators have often complained about. A good part of the answer is not pertinent to the question but the opportunity is taken by Ministers, particularly by Senator Carrick, to make a political speech. He has not started that practice this year because we have not got into full momentum, but I expect it to happen as time goes on and as Senator Carrick starts to get tired and we start to embarrass him. He will then trot out the old rhetoric about it being the fault of the Whitlam Government, and then go on and on. His answers often have nothing to do with the question which, in the public interest, Opposition senators try to put. I hope that the Standing Orders Committee in its next report makes some worthwhile recommendations or gives directions to the Senate to take certain action, instead of just saying, as Senator Rae pointed out, that written questions ought to be put on notice. I would rather see a direction from the Standing Orders Committee to the Senate that certain things should be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some remarks to this problem of the Senate's Question Time, the problem of giving notice of questions. What is being attempted in giving notice of questions is to make Question Time more effective than it can be without notice being given. I think it is quite clear that Ministers frequently do and must have notice of questions because of the present nature of Question Time. This raises the issue of whether our present Question Time is an appropriate method of getting information from the Executive into the public domain. I submit that it is not.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not appropriate for three reasons. Firstly, of course, three-quarters of the Ministers whom one wishes to question are not, under our present system, available for direct questioning by senators. Secondly, although it is better than it is in the House of Representatives, our procedure of supplementary questioning is quite inadequate. One supplementary question is normally allowed but the procedure does not really permit the pursuit of an issue until a satisfactory answer is produced. Thirdly, if it is a complex issue, it is unreasonable to expect the Minister to have all the matters in his mind. If, on the other hand, the question is put on the Notice Paper, as is suggested by paragraph 5 of the Standing Orders Committee report, months will normally pass-in some cases years-before one gets an answer to the issue which one raised.

I should like to see the Standing Orders Committee look closely at the procedure used by the British House of Commons to see whether this would not be a better method for us to adopt at Question Time. If one used the British House of Commons procedure, the process here would be this: Notice would be given of questions to which an honourable senator wanted oral answers from a Minister. The Minister would have a short period-a few days at most-in which to consider his answer. He would publicly give his answer to the Senate and then supplementary questions would be permitted until, in the opinion of the President, that subject had been exhausted. Fewer questions would be asked, of course, but they would be pursued in more detail. As the question is printed on the Notice Paper it would not be necessary to go through the questions. The number of the question on the Notice Paper should just need to be referred to and the Minister could give his prepared answer, and that subject would then be pursued in detail through supplementary questions until that topic was exhausted.

TALK.START.PARA: —But most of the questions on the Notice Paper are just non-questions put there to book a spot. You know the way the system works.

—They may be, but the key to the way in which the system works is that it is by means of the supplementary questions that the issue is really investigated and answers have to be forthcoming from the Minister. I further suggest, and this is touched on elsewhere in the Standing Orders Committee report, that Question Time is of very little value until we can arrange for the Ministers of the House of Representatives, who are supposed to be responsible to both Houses of Parliament, to be available for questioning by senators. I urge that the Standing Orders Committee have a really thorough look at what we are trying to achieve from our Question Time and how best we can achieve it. I think a modification of the British House of Commons procedure would work very much better than the procedure we have at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My intrusion into this debate will be brief. Senator Cavanagh put his finger on the pulse earlier when he spoke about the length of Question Time. I balance that against the emergence of the supplementary question. I think what Senator Hamer said about the introduction of the British House of Commons practice has a lot of merit. We realise, of course, that some weeks we may be faced with some burning issue and other matters may have to be put aside. Supplementary questions reduce the number of questions but obviously they have a valuable role. The answer to the original question may get to the brink of the matter, and a follow-up question can wrap up the subject at that point.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another point which I think is significant. Senator Rae, who usually chairs an Estimates Committee, would know the value of questioning a Minister. For a couple of years now Senator Bishop and Senator Tate have probed matters relating to employment retraining methods and apprenticeship intakes. Even if the Minister for Industrial Relations were present at the Estimates Committee, I would not expect him to have available a string of figures in regard to those matters. However, unless honourable senators have the relevant information they cannot apply a litmus test, as it were, to determine the effectiveness of the Government's programs. Some of the load could be taken away from Question Time by having on-going Estimates committees. Each year Estimates committees deal with Supplementary Estimates and normal Estimates. Each senator usually has a particular interest in two or three areas. An honourable senator may also have a pipeline to some organisations which expects him to probe matters and to get prompt responses.

I believe that the Estimates committees could be expanded and have on-going hearings. I say that for a particular reason. Say the Government made a decision to accept political refugees from a number of countries. There would be a justifiable howl about the importance of the family reunion policy and the acceptance of immigrants according to job categories. An honourable senator may ask a question in the Senate and the answer may be given a couple of weeks later. When Estimates or Supplementary Estimates are before Estimates committees one can get excellent responses if one has done one's homework. I have proved this in relation to my two areas of particular interest. As Senator Bishop could testify, answers given to questions on industrial relations, for example, can be indexed and sent to the Australian Council of Trade Unions or to the National Labour Consultative Council. They give a feedback and there is a top level debate or further questions are asked. But success hinges on the responses to Estimates committees.

In the immigration area there is some concern amongst Latin Americans as to whether they are treated as well as South East Asians are treated. A string of questions may be directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration. The United States Congress-I know the United States has a slightly different form of government-has full Senate inquiries into such matters. People testify, and answers are given. If there were Estimates committees there would be fewer questions from me at Question Time about immigration or industrial relations and more opportunity for honourable senators to ask questions on other topics. I throw that innovation in for consideration. Senator Hamer suggested that we should adopt the House of Commons format for Question Time. I believe the expansion of the Estimates committees into an on-going operation would be equally valuable. At least the two areas that I mentioned, industrial relations and ethnic affairs, would be taken out of the Senate at large. With the Minister and his specialist advisers present answers could be obtained. That is my addendum to all the suggestions that have been made about improving Question Time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of this debate many suggestions have been made and many dissatisfactions have been expressed about Question Time and the report of the Standing Orders Committee. I think it is quite clear that we may have different views as to what the solution might be, but we are not at all satisfied with the questioning process and the way in which it works. From Senator Mason, Senator Georges, Senator Rae, Senator Hamer, Senator Mulvihill and a number of other senators have come suggestions which I think need a lot more consideration and ought to be considered as possibilities for improving the process in the work that we are doing. The motion before the Senate is that the Senate note the item. I said that I was going to oppose it. I do not know what use there would be in just noting the item. To the motion before the Senate I wish to move an amendment of which I have given notice. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add
'but requests the Standing Orders Committee to look again at the improvement of the questioning process in the Senate in the light of suggestions made during this debate'.

I suggest, putting it in simple language, that that means that what has been said today would provide the basis for the committee to consider the dissatisfaction which has been expressed by Senator McLaren and others-there are grounds for dissatisfaction-and the suggestions which have been made, which may or may not be practical. The matter obviously needs a lot more serious and urgent consideration by the Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment proposed by Senator Missen. I think enough has been said today at least to warrant further consideration. I was particularly impressed by Senator Rae's contribution. Like him, I am not concerned about the someone who wants information giving a Minister prior knowledge of a question to allow him to provide an answer. I am concerned about a Minister supplying the question and the answer. It is done. This practice was introduced by then Senator Murphy, now Mr Justice Murphy, and it still goes on. I am indebted to Senator McLaren for giving me a copy of a question which he had tabled and which was asked by Senator Walters on 20 August 1980. She asked:

SPEECH.PARA: My question . . . is in two parts.

Senator Walters wanted publicity to be given to the fact that the Commonwealth was financing the functions of the International Cultural Corporation of Australia Ltd. She wanted a big statement from the Government that it was funding that Corporation. Of course, the question and the answer are printed on the one sheet of paper. Obviously, the Minister wanted to attract publicity by telling the world that the Commonwealth was funding the International Cultural Corporation. The answer which appeared on the same page as the question consisted of 6 paragraphs to explain that in effect the Commonwealth was funding the International Cultural Corporation. One takes the view that such a question should have been put on notice.

Questions asked during Question Time are supposed to be questions without notice. Because of my misinterpretation of the Standing Orders I thought that the question should have been put on notice. When I raised the matter with Senator McLaren I found I was wrong. The question did not call for details and should not have been put on notice. I liked Senator Rae's suggestion that there should be an arrangement for the automatic incorporation in Hansard of questions answered by correspondence. I disagree that the solution is to ask questions in the adjournment debate. If we were to ask a series of questions in an adjournment debate we would wait a lot longer to receive an answer, if we ever got it.

Senator Rae also suggested that questions on notice should be answered within two sitting days. Whilst that may be too short a period I think there should be a requirement that in the event of a Minister's failing to supply an answer within a reasonable period he provide a reason to the Senate for not having done so. I have suggested that the Committee should consider this matter further. Senator Rae disagrees with me as to the length of Question Time prior to our placing a time limit on it. I may be wrong. I suggest that the Committee should find out what the length of Question Time was and what time we are saving now in Question Time in trying to get on the record as much propaganda as we can for and against the Government.

I think many good suggestions have been made. Obviously, there are complaints about the present system. I think the Committee should look at the matter and consider the suggestions that have been made-Senator Hamer's suggestion may be worth taking up, although I do not like it-to see whether we can improve the system.
Amendment agreed to.
Item 1, as amended, noted.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMPANIES AND SECURITIES COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1981COMPANIES (ACQUISITION OF SHARES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981SECURITIES INDUSTRY AMENDMENT BILL 1981COMPANIES AND SECURITIES (INTERPRETATION AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was initially tempted to expostulate a little about these Bills being brought on for debate so early in the session. They were introduced into the Senate only yesterday. But I must concede that my anguish in this respect was somewhat tempered by the recollection that this Parliament as a whole has in fact had notice of these measures since August 1980. Indeed, the real complaint in respect of these Bills is the lugubrious slowness of the whole process of bringing them to fruition. I will refer again to that aspect in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose these Bills. They are all directed to amending, largely as to various machinery matters, a package of legislation which was passed early in 1980 as part of the national co-operative companies and securities scheme. That is not, however, to say that the Opposition is any happier with the legislative approach embodied in this scheme than it was when the co-operative arrangements were first mooted. Our attitude is embodied in our proposed amendment to the motion 'That the Bill be now read a second time', which amendment has been circulated to honourable senators. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate:

(a) expresses its concern at the Government's abdication of its responsibility to make national laws for corporations and the securities industry pursuant to the Commonwealth's own constitutional powers, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in 1974 (the Rae Report);
(b) notes that the legislative scheme places uniformity before reform, and creates both the danger and the likelihood that lowest common denominator standards will prevail;

(c) expresses its concern at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission, to either the Government or the Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected government or parliament;

(d) notes that amendments to close loopholes in company law are continually necessary, but while acknowledging that pursuant to the Formal Agreement, any proposed amendment may need to be the subject of consultation with the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities before final acceptance by the Government, nonetheless insists upon this Parliament's right to properly scrutinise and amend all legislation put before it by the Executive; and

(e) calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme embodied in the Bills, to proceed immediately to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of the acquisition of shares.'.

The speech that I made in respect of the National Companies and Securities Commission Bill on 19 November 1979 amounted to a very detailed discussion of the implications of the amendment involved and the reason for our moving it in the terms in which we did. For that reason I will not repeat on this occasion all the detail of the Opposition's argument. Nonetheless, we cannot repeat too often the basic points that are in issue with this whole package of companies and securities legislation. The first paragraph of the Opposition's amendment states that the Senate:

(a) expresses its concern at the Government's abdication of its responsibility to make national laws for corporations and the securities industry pursuant to the Commonwealth's own constitutional powers, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in 1974 (the Rae Report);

There is no doubt that the Commonwealth has the constitutional power under section 51(xx) of the Constitution and a miscellany of other provisions to enact unilaterally the kind of legislation which is in issue here. Furthermore, there is no doubt that that power should be exercised as was the conclusion of the Senate Standing Committee on Securities and Exchange chaired by Senator Rae in 1974. Nothing has changed since the bringing down of the Rae Committee report to alter that situation. The States of New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia got together in the early 1970s to form the interstate Corporate Affairs Commission, as their own co-operative arrangement, to ward off the anticipated onslaught of Commonwealth unilateral legislation in the exercise of the Commonwealth's own powers. The result of that co-operative endeavour at the State level has been such that the States in question have been able to achieve neither compete uniformity nor efficiency in the pursuit of commercial and corporate integrity in the company law and securities areas.

The Negri River affair, to which I referred in giving a notice of motion today and which will be the subject of further debate in this place next week, indicates that highly questionable practices with respect to the flotation of mining or exploration companies are alive and well as a phenomenon in this community. The matter does raise squarely all over again the spectres of the Poseidon, Minsec and Tasminex companies. If anything, the need for national overriding legislation allowing no opportunity for the development of idiosyncratic, local course rules at the expense of the national interest is even more apparent than it was in the early 1970s. I am referring to the phenomenon with which we have all become familiar, regrettably, in the last few months; that is, the extraordinary performance of Queensland in its endeavours, which can only be described as bizarre, to ward off the acquisition by interstate corporations of companies owned and managed by Queenslanders. I refer in particular to the affairs of companies such as Evans-Deakin Industries Limited and Walkers Limited.

TALK.START.PARA: —And CSR.

—And the Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Limited, within the context of the Thiess Bros. Pty Ltd takeover, was an even more spectacular example, as I am reminded by Senator Rae. I am not sure whether Senator Rae will agree with my next point that if these were to be regarded as genuine exercises in socialism representing a desire by the Queensland Government to bring into public ownership enterprises hitherto devoted to private profit, then this kind of exercise might, in our view, be defensible. It is clear, however, that they represent no more than a demonstration of that unlovely and Deep North phenomenon of xenophobia, reinforced in this instance by the personal paranoia of the Premier, about which Mr John Hodges spoke so eloquently in the other place earlier this week. The second paragraph of the amendment to the motion for the second reading states that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) notes that the legislative scheme places uniformity before reform, and creates both the danger and the likelihood that lowest common denominator standards will prevail;

This is the basic problem in the corporations and securities scheme of co-operative legislation with which we have again been presented, especially at this establishment stage when unanimity is the requirement in the putting together of these packages of legislation as distinct from the majority of the members of the Ministerial Council which would be the requirement for subsequent amendments. The requirement of unanimity at this initial packaging stage is one of the things, perhaps the most obvious thing, that has resulted in the grindingly slow pace of the changes which have been occurring up to now. Putting it the other way around, the slowness of the implementation of this scheme is the best evidence of the validity of the concern that is embodied in this paragraph of the Opposition's amendment.

It will be recalled that this so-called co-operative exercise was set in train initially after the Fraser Government came to power. The Fraser Government abandoned Labor's national scheme, the Commonwealth scheme, which was embodied in our attempted legislation in 1974 and 1975. The co-operative scheme thus set in train by the Fraser Government culminated initially in the Maroochydore agreement of December 1978. It was not until May 1980 that we reached the first stage of the actual implementation of the Maroochydore agreement, with the proclamation coming into effect of the National Companies and Securities Commission legislation.

Although the Commission is exercising various administrative functions and is gearing itself up for future activity, getting on for a year later it is still exercising no substantive functions under legislation because none of the other legislation, including the Securities Industry Act 1980 and the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980, is in effect because, amongst other things, the States, whose complementary legislation is necessary to the bringing of them into effect on a national basis, has not yet been passed. It will not be the case that all this legislation is in effect, with the NCSC actually having something to do, until the Companies Bill itself-that huge keystone of the arch constituted by the scheme-is finally lowered into place, whenever that might prove to be. The date of 1 January is the deadline being set. The trouble is that the years keep changing.

It is evident that there is very little significant reform or change embodied in the newly packaged legislation which has either been passed so far or of which advance notice has been given. It is true that getting real uniformity is in itself something of a reform, but the current state of corporate play-if I can put it in those terms-and the operation of securities industries, suggests that the process of reform in a legislative and regulatory sense still has a very long way to go. Even when that process of reform is accomplished in some visible and effective way, the worst feature of this scheme will remain. The problem is that when that stage is reached there is no guarantee whatsoever that the national scheme will be able to hold the line against those outbursts of parochial adventurism of the kind with which we have become all too familiar. The third paragraph of the Opposition's amendment seeks to add another dimension to our concern about the way in which this whole scheme is proceeding. The paragraph states that the Senate:

(c) expresses its concern at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission, to either the Government or the Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected government or parliament;

That is a point that cannot be repeated too often. We have had enough trouble with the Commonwealth's own statutory authorities in ensuring the kind of accountability that is necessary in the public interest. Senator Rae for one will not need any reminding about the affairs of the Australian Wheat Board or the Australian Dairy Corporation in this respect. It is infinitely more difficult to ensure any kind of reasonable accountability of statutory authorities of this kind in the public interest when multiplicity of governments are involved. It becomes impossible under those circumstances to sheet home the blame for maladministration or anything else to any one of them. Passing the buck becomes an administrative art form in that situation. So much is openly acknowledged and articulated by all those participating in the creation of this legislative scheme.
I refer, as I have in the past, once again to paragraph 38 (1) of the Maroochydore Agreement which makes this problem graphically clear. The paragraph reads:

The policy direction and general control over the administration of company law and the regulation of the securities industry throughout Australia by the Ministerial Council and by the Commission in accordance with this Agreement shall . . . be exercised to the exclusion of . . . Ministerial direction and control by the responsible Minister of the Commonwealth or of the State.

In other words, the only direct line of responsibility is to the Ministerial Council as a whole. No single governmental component of that Council is answerable to any government of any parliament in this nation. It is an inherent characteristic, I suppose, of co-operative schemes of this kind, but it does not make them any easier to live with and the problems that these kinds of arrangements store up are fine while the weather is fine but much less so when the weather becomes stormy. Problems of accountability or maladministration do rear their heads, as unfortunately they do from time to time, and it is under those circumstances that one becomes aware of the inherent structural weakness in this kind of Rube Goldberg device of co-operative federalism that is embodied in these arrangements.
Paragraph (d) of the Opposition's amendment raises yet another fundamental problem with legislative arrangements of this kind. The paragraph states that the Senate:

(d) notes that amendments to close loopholes in company law are continually necessary, but while acknowledging that pursuant to the Formal Agreement, any proposed amendment may need to be the subject of consultation with the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities before final acceptance by the Government, nonetheless insists upon this Parliament's right to properly scrutinise and amend all legislation put before it by the Executive; . . .

That embodies the proposition that with a cry of pain so far as this Parliament is concerned that, however much detailed scrutiny and attention we may give to the Bills which come forward now and in the future as part of this scheme in the form of amendments and identify faults or flaws which we as a parliament want to correct as the subject of a reasoned amendment, our hands are tied because the very nature of the legislative process in a co-operative arrangement of this kind is that the Parliament is presented with these Bills on a take-it or leave-it basis. The most one can do is to make something in the nature of a parliamentary recommendation to the Ministerial Council which may or may not be taken into account when the next round of amending legislation is in fact being put together.

There is no opportunity, given the very nature of the legislative process involved here where at the present time the Bills themselves must be the subject of prior unanimous agreement by the Ministerial Council, for flaws which do come to notice while a Bill in question is going through this Parliament or the complementary legislation is going through another parliament and consistent with the obligations into which the Commonwealth has entered, to get agreement through the Ministerial Council for the terms of this legislation. There is no opportunity for amendments to be properly dealt with. That does represent a complete abdication not in this instance of national legislative authority but of any legislative authority. We are simply not behaving like a parliament. What is, all too unfortunately, normally something of a charade becomes a total and unmitigated charade as a legislative process when we are confronted with Bills of this kind. It is hard enough normally to get governments to accept amendments, but in this sort of situation it is absolutely impossible.

This issue is not one of immediate significance with the present small package of amending Bills because the contents of each of the Bills, looked at in isolation, is, as far as the Opposition is concerned, generally acceptable. But it is a problem which we will certainly, as a legislature, as a parliament, strike acutely with the Companies Bill to be introduced later this year. I make this point and utter this cry of legislative pain not simply on behalf of the Opposition but on behalf of all members of this Parliament, on the Government side as well as on our side, who are equally impotent when confronted by an agreed package with a ribbon around it of the kind that is constituted by these Bills coming forward from the Ministerial Council.
The final point which speaks for itself and does not need any gloss is contained in paragraph (e) of the Opposition's amendment which states that the Senate:

(e) calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme embodied in the Bills, to proceed immediately to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of the acquisition of shares;

We on the Opposition side certainly hope that the Commonwealth will continue to acknowledge the existence of a relevant batch of constitutional powers in this area and will continue to make it clear to those States which may be tempted to be somewhat less than co-operative in their willingness to achieve genuine reform in this area that the Commonwealth will move in with unilateral legislation to control this important area if genuine momentum is not in fact sustained in this respect.

Let me turn more briefly to the Bills before us; let me note their content and the Opposition's reaction to them. The first in the package of four Bills is the National Companies and Securities Commission Amendment Bill. It is primarily aimed at facilitating the administration of the National Companies and Securities Commission in various non-controversial ways and, further, in making arrangements for the establishment of a secretariat for the Ministerial Council. I make only one comment in respect of this Bill, and that is that it is an interesting but as yet somewhat unresolved question as to whether the Council on the one hand and the Commission on the other hand will become, by virtue of their location in separate cities with separate administrative and policy-making apparatus attached to each of them-that separation being the product of political settlement that was recently reached-co-operative organisations working in genuine harmony for the improvement of the substance and practice of companies and securities law in this country or whether, more unfortunately, they will become rival organisations operating with a tension between them that is somewhat less than creative. One hopes that the former option will be the one that proves to eventuate. But it is a matter of some concern to anyone concerned with the effective administration of companies and securities law in this country that there is a potential for unconstructive rivalry between the two essential elements in the new machinery.

The second Bill in the package is the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill. This Bill contains a number of amendments-some of then of genuine substantive significance-to the legislative takeover code embodied in the parent Act. May I say that the most pleasing of the amendments contained in this Bill from the Opposition's point of view is clause 18 which amends the Schedule to the parent Act and which requires offerors to make, under Part A or under Part C, the on-market statements, a declaration of intentions in respect of the continuation or otherwise of the business of the target company such as major changes that are anticipated in respect of the operations of that company and in particular the redeployment of its fixed assets, if any is contemplated, and further, and crucially important, the intentions in respect of the future employment of the present employees of the target company. There are United Kingdom and the United States precedents for this kind of required declaration but the insertion of the provisions in the Bill is a tribute to the persistence, among others, of Mr Jacobi, the Labor Party member for Hawker, and Mr Chris Hurford, the Labor front bench member representing the division of Adelaide. It is very pleasing to the Opposition that the Government-and, indeed, the Ministerial Council-has picked up this proposal and embodied it in the legislation.

There are other important changes worth mentioning very much in passing. Clause 7, which was introduced, one notices, against the opposition of the brokers, extends the prohibition against crossings, that is, transactions whereby the same broker acts for buyers as well as sellers, and extends that prohibition to on-market takeover offers. Clause 8 of the Bill requires the NCSC's consent to expert reports in relation to profit forecasts and asset valuations being included in Part B statements. They are both important and substantive matters and ones which the Opposition again very much welcomes.

The third Bill in the sequence is the Securities Industry Amendment Bill. Most of the provisions in this Bill are designed to bring the enforcement provisions of the parent Securities Industry Act into line with present and proposed new company law provisions of a similar kind. To that extent they are uncontroversial and again they are welcomed by the Opposition. That is not to say that we should necessarily regard these provisions as being the last word on the enforcement subject. There may well be room for going further in some respects, but certainly there is no opposition to these proposals as they presently stand. We notice in particular that some powers are extended by this Bill. In this respect I note especially clause 10, which confers power on the NCSC to require quick disclosures of key items of information to enable the Commission to operate quickly, efficiently and effectively in relation to various kinds of suspect market activity, especially with respect to takeovers. We welcome this additional flexibility which is provided by these provisions and the acknowledgment of the real commercial world that is inherent in them.

I make a further point about this Bill which is not quite so approving. That is that there is quite a deal of what can be described only as legal nonsense cluttering up the Bill unnecessarily-notionally for clarification purposes but in reality clearly being inserted only to soothe the neuroses of various lobby groups and critics. I refer especially to clause 5 of the Bill, which in orotund terms states that production of books shall be required only for the purposes of the legislation of the scheme. That is manifestly a redundant provision as it is inconceivable that any court would regard the authorities as being entitled to require the production of books for any other purpose than that related to the scheme.

In clause 9 it is provided with due gravity that legal practitioners shall be required to disclose a relevant person's name and address only if the practitioner in question knows that person's name and address. One is delighted to see the tenderness of legislative concern for the legal profession but as a practical matter it is inconceivable that any such prosecution would be launched if there was not very good grounds for believing that there was, in fact, knowledge by the practitioner of the name and address of the person in question.

In clause 6 there is an absolutely extraordinary amendment, one I have never seen the likes of in the time that I have been following these matters. It is something that can be described only as a nutty exercise in pedantry. I refer to the clause 6 provision which includes an amendment designed solely to correct a spelling error in the original printing of the Bill in what is a spectacularly obvious typographical error. The word 'aircraft' is shown as 'airtcraft' with a 't' instead of a hypen at the end of the line. Again, the time and energy of the draftsman-not to mention the Ministerial Council-seem to have been spent in correcting what is manifestly a typographical error of the most trivial and unconfusing kind.

I note also, incidentally, another one of these nonsensical provisions in clause 6 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill, in which it is again gravely provided that it is not necessary for an offeror holding shares in a target company to dispatch a takeover offer to himself. The prospect of any offeror, under those circumstances, being prosecuted for a breach of that provision staggers the imagination. Why it has been put in to soothe, as I have said, the neuroses of some strident critic, one can only hazard a guess. The Opposition and I regard it as rather a foolish legislative exercise to be pandering to neuroses in such a way as to become as literally foolish as legislators appear to be when they are putting their names to these kinds of legislative provisions.

There may be a whole new pattern of draftsmanship at work in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, but I have not been aware in the past of this kind of over-exaggerated care in not offending anybody and stating the obvious in capital letters. It does tend to bring a little degree of disrepute to the legislative process on which some of us are spending a good deal of our time trying to bring it into repute and make it more intelligible and commonsensical to the layman. Those points are made simply in passing. They are clearly of no substantive significance. They simply go to matters of style.

The final Bill in the package is the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill. The amendments to this Bill simply extend some of the interpretative provisions of the parent Bill. Here again most of the provisions seem to be included simply for the purpose of clarification rather than introducing substantive changes in their own right. Probably the most important group of provisions are those identifying with a good deal more precision than was the case in the original Bill which offences are indictable, which offences on the other hand are summary and which kinds of offences are triable by either procedure. It also limits the sentences which can be passed in the context of someone being pursued before a court of summary jurisdiction in respect of an offence which is inherently triable-the notion here being to preserve the rights already enjoyed under existing State company law by those persons who are triable on indictment as that law now stands. These are technical points and I make no judgmental comment about them at this stage because none of these matters are inherently controversial.

I do make the point that this kind of provision raises indirectly the very difficult question, with which I believe the Parliament ought to come to grips at some stage, of whether jury trial, that is, the two-stage indictment process of initial committal proceedings followed by a trial before a judge and jury-a familiar vehicle for serious offences-is really ever appropriate for complex corporate crimes of the kind involving a mass of sophisticated and very detailed documentary evidence. It is a matter which causes a great deal of controversy and argument within and around the legal profession. It is not a matter that is in any way dealt with squarely by this piece of legislation. But I am beginning to form the view that it is a matter that will have to be very seriously tackled with a view perhaps to considering the possibility of the replacement of jurors by assessors where matters of very intricate corporate fraud or corporate crime are involved. It is a matter on which opinions differ and on which reasonable men and women can differ but I simply foreshadow it as a matter which demands some attention.

Finally, I repeat that whilst the Opposition does not oppose these Bills we have very serious continuing reservations about the whole legislative scheme on which the Government is here embarked. We are, whether we like it or not or whether some State Premiers like it or not, one nation. Certainly one of the most centrally important elements in our national life, whether socialists like it or not, is the operation of the private corporate sector and the securities market. The only appropriate way of regulating that sector and that securities industry activity is by national legislation undertaken by the Commonwealth in the courageous, forward-looking exercise of its own undoubted constitutional power. Until we have that, the kind of co-operative legislative scheme that is embodied here and continued here will continue to be the less than satisfactory product of very slow and very hard-won compromise. What is more and what ultimately seems to me to be the greatest worry of all is that it will always be capable of being undermined by the kind of narrow-minded, self-interested State chauvinism which has become all too unfortunately familiar in the life of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a package of what are substantially fine-tuned, if one is generous in the use of the word 'fine', amendments to the overall legislative scheme rather than matters of great substance or innovation. For the reasons that I supported the introduction of the National Companies and Securities Commission legislation and the other legislation which has been before the Senate, I support these Bills but do so with qualifications. I take the opportunity to indicate that this package of four Bills has been considered in detail by a Government members companies and securities matters committee. Whilst I do not propose to deal in detail with a whole lot of matters that were raised and considered by that committee, I indicate that there were matters about which people felt that there were questions and potential inadequacies. But for reasons which I will elaborate on in a moment, I do not regard it as appropriate at this stage to raise those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to what I see as the overall principal purpose which we are endeavouring to serve. I want to quote from a paper given by Mr Paul Espie, the managing director of BA Australia Ltd to a Financial Times Conference last October. The subject of his speech was 'Australia-The Attractions for Future Investment'. He said:
A primary objective of the financial system should be the efficient allocation of financial resources.

This implies that funds be able to flow freely between savers and borrowers without institutional impediments and that funds be allocated on the basis of price. When some interest rates are not permitted to move freely to reflect market priorities or perceived risks, and where institutional arrangements distort the free flow of funds between borrowers and savers, the financial system is less than efficient and imposes costs on the community, either directly or indirectly through the mis-allocation of real resources.

Hitherto the capital market has tended to be segmented with different groups of financial intermediaries operating under separate conditions and regulations.
