Whilst in many instances they participate in similar markets, the competition between groups of financial intermediaries has been either prevented or is inequitable.
A more freely competitive environment will ensure that the financial markets respond to changing needs, develop efficiently and operate at lower cost.

I think these are some of the things which ought to be at the forefront of the consideration given to this package of Bills, the package of Bills which has previously been before the chamber and the ones which will undoubtedly come to the chamber. The need is to have financial markets which can respond to changing needs which can develop efficiently and which can operate at a minimum cost for the function being served. I add one further thing that Mr Espie did not dwell upon and that is that they ought to operate fairly as well as efficiently to ensure that people who wish to participate are not misled and have the appropriate amount of information available to them. I am not saying that Mr Espie was unaware of that because he does refer to it in a later stage of his paper. He did not refer to it in the part I read. The point is that we can lose sight of the main purpose in the morass of detail which seems to have been built up around what was originally quite a simple concept.

I regard it as unfortunate and a matter for comment at this stage-I am speaking of the general rather than the particular detail of these Bills-that we seem to be heading for ever into more and more detailed regulation towards the stage where the free, open, fair and efficient operation of our capital markets becomes less and less likely and where people become more and more bound down by regulation and less and less clear on what are the opportunities and the obligations. It is unfortunate that the inquiry into the Australian financial system could not be a little further advanced at the time we consider aspects of the National Companies and Securities Commission legislation because I think the two things are interrelated to a substantial extent. It is foolish, as Mr Espie says, for us to look at the operation of some of the intermediaries in the market without looking at the operation of others. It is foolish for us to be looking at some aspects of the impacts on the financial system and regulating those while permitting to operate in either an unregulated way or a way in which information is not available others in relation to which there is not full accountability.

In those respects I refer to the huge differences that exist between the impact on the financial markets of Australia created as a result of the activities of the Loan Council, of the governments making up the Loan Council, the huge impacts of the activities of statutory authorities of both the Commonwealth and State in funding at incredible gearing ratios-they enjoy government guarantee and are therefore able to operate on a gearing ratio which would not be available to any other sector of the community-the distortions that this creates and the lack of published knowledge in relation to that in comparison with the knowledge which is sought and enforced, particularly as a result of the legislative package which we have before us and that to which it relates, from other sectors of the community.

I wish to make the point today that whilst we are happily looking at enforcing a system which we believe and hope will improve the standard of performance of a part of the operation of the total financial system, we should not forget the existence of the others and the need to interrelate the lot from the point of view of regulation and information. I think it would probably be reasonably well known to honourable senators that my views as to regulation are that it is far better to be able to have enforced disclosure than it is to have 50,000 penalties for breaches of a great hoard of rules which more often than not are unenforceable and unlikely to be enforced anyway. If they are enforced it takes so long and the enforcement occurs so long after the event that the effect of it is only one of punishment for breach rather than for something which moves towards the more efficient and equitable operation of the market.

I have been asked not to speak long this afternoon. I am prepared to adhere to that request. I was sorry that when the major Bills came on for debate previously-these are only amending Bills-I did not have the opportunity to speak at all. I suppose I can only say that things have improved. I understand that there is a need to try to get this legislation through this afternoon. I support that need. That is one of the points I want to make. As Senator Evans said, this whole proposal reached the stage in 1974 of a general consensus on the need for a national approach. It was unfortunate that there were differences of opinion about how to go about it and perhaps a little extremism in what was proposed by the then Government. This led to delays which in turn led to the creation of the situation which was outlined by Senator Evans of some five years of negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States. I am afraid that causes me to diminish somewhat the degree of sanguine expectation which I have as to the speed with which the whole system will be able to react in what is an extremely fast moving area of economic activity. I hope, however, that we shall be able to continue. This course has been set upon. Whilst having a different preference as to how we ought to have gone about it, I see it as desirable that we go down this track now that we are on it and part of the way down, to get it to the stage of full implementation as soon as possible.

It is with that enthusiasm that I return to what I said a moment ago. I do not wish to do anything to delay the passage of these Bills at all, but rather to encourage in every possible way their being carried into effect as soon as possible. I take the opportunity to compliment the Commissioners of the National Companies and Securities Commission, particularly the full time Commissioners, Mr Masel, Mr Coleman and Mr Greenwood, on the work that has been done so far in a number of respects in establishing and making ready the National Companies and Securities Commission for the role which is intended for it when we and the Parliaments of the States get round to giving them the legislative machinery to enable them to act. In my view, the sooner that takes place the better. I believe that they have done an excellent job, particularly from a public education point of view, of moving through the interested community ensuring that the hopes, aspirations and the principles which may be expected to apply and the objectives being sought by the Commission are understood widely by the community. I think that that is a most encouraging sign.

What is not encouraging is the inordinate delay that seems to take place where the co-operative federalism approach is adopted for something which, beyond any shadow of doubt, in my view-here I totally agree with Senator Evans-is a Commonwealth responsibility for which the Commonwealth should have assumed and asserted the responsibility from 1901. It took from 1908 to 1971, I think it was, for that to be clarified by the High Court, which went off the rails somewhat in 1908. It eventually got it back on the rails in the Rocla pipes case in 1971. Since 1971, when the matter was put beyond any real doubt-if any doubt really existed-by the High Court there has been no excuse for the ambivalence of attitude adopted. It has been claimed that co-operative federalism is necessary in this case because of some problems in constitutional law. I believe that the real problems are far more the problems of ensuring that there is co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States in enforcement and in investigation in relation to the whole area. As there were threats of a failure to co-operate by some of the States and perhaps a lower degree of enthusiasm likely for co-operation by all of the States if they were not involved, the government of the day took the decision to adopt the co-operative federalist approach. That decision has been taken and I do not see the slightest advantage for us today to go back and say: 'It would have been better to do it the other way and, therefore, it would be better to start reviewing how it has been done'. The view I would like to adopt is: Let us try to make this work and let us get on with it as soon as we can. I again refer to the comments which I made when the National Companies and Securities Commission Bill was being debated in November 1979. I do not resile from these views at all. I restate them. I said:

I believe the only difference which has occurred since the change of government in 1975 is that a different approach has been adopted which I find-I will refer to this aspect in a moment-less than the most desirable. However, it is a perfectly justifiable approach. The stance taken is to see whether the federalist approach will work. If that cannot work the Government can turn to legislating in the way Senator Evans suggested; that is, the Commonwealth going it alone. This legislation is a challenge to federalism.

I repeat and emphasise that today. It is a challenge to federalism. If it cannot be made to work more expeditiously than it has so far, the co-operative federalism approach is damning itself. I continued:

It is my firm belief that there is no real doubt that the Commonwealth has the power and the duty in this area. If the federalist approach does not work, if there is obstructionism from the States, it will be the responsibility of whatever government is in power in Canberra to ensure that this national approach is adopted. If necessary, it will have to go it alone. That is the challenge of this legislation.

I do not resile from those views. I add: Let us get on with getting them implemented as soon as we can so that we can see whether the scheme works. In conclusion, I raise one other matter; that is, the decision by the Government to exempt the stockbrokers from the area being examined by the Trade Practices Commission. The basis for that decision was apparently that the National Companies and Securities Commission would have a similar role. It seems to me that it is a further example of the problems that arise where one section of the total number of involved sections in our financial system is subjected to one form of regulation and another section is subjected to a completely different form of regulation. However, that has been decided upon. Perhaps it is not appropriate today to question it. It is appropriate to point out how essential it is to the development of Australia and the average person's opportunity to participate in the anticipated resources boom.

There is much evidence to indicate that this is well and truly under way already. Unless brokerage charges can be kept at a minimum, unless opportunity is given for the average individual to participate in the ownership of the companies which are in the major developing areas of the economy, we will have done a disservice which dissuades the average person from putting his money into national development, taking an interest and feeling that he will get a reward from the developments which will take place over the next decade or two. I believe that it is essential that steps be taken, and taken at an early stage, to review the whole way in which brokerage commissions are charged.

The question of negotiated commissions and all of the other matters which were raised in the Senate Committee's report as long ago as 1974, still appear to be matters which have not been adequately considered or dealt with. I was delighted, however, to see-this caused me to change my mind about the action which I would take-an announcement by Mr Masel just a few days ago indicating that one of the early matters being investigated is the question of brokers' commission rates, the negotiation thereof and the fixing thereof. I therefore do not propose to move any addendum to the second reading motion. I had had in mind that it would be desirable to give the National Companies and Securities Commission a clear indication of the Senate's view of the importance of this question by putting it as an addendum to the second reading motion. In view of the fact that it is already taking steps in relation to it I just pause to congratulate it on doing that and encourage it to do it as expeditiously as possible and certainly to give it a high priority.

For those brief reasons I support the Bills with the qualifications which I have outlined. I agree with much of the sentiment of what Senator Evans has said, but I do not see it as constructive to do other than simply support the legislation getting through and the whole matter being tried out as soon as possible. I therefore do not see it as productive to support the amendment. I do not propose to proceed with the amendment which I had in mind until I found out that the Commission was already doing what I had in mind it ought to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senators for their remarks in regard to the legislation. I thank them in particular for their support. Clearly the matter is in a very complex area. This Government, in a very positive example of federalism, has agreed to establish a co-operative scheme with the States which will work. The scheme certainly has the goodwill of all members in these two Houses of Parliament and I believe in the State parliaments as well. If it can be seen that the State and Federal governments can work in concert I believe we will get the most effective regulatory scheme in the companies area.
—You're dreaming.
—Well, I thought that Senator Georges would support the legislation.
—It has taken you 12 years to get to this point. That's federalism for you.

—Of course, democracy is something of a long-winded procedure but we have reached the point where the whole package of legislation will come into force. I wish to acknowledge the remarks of Senator Rae, in particular, and to apologise for the fact that he did not have an opportunity to put forward his views at an earlier time on the substantive legislation. We have noted his views today as an example of the well thought-out opinions of a man who has had a great deal to do with this sphere of legislation. I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVISORY COUNCIL FOR INTER-GOVERNMENT RELATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations-ACIR-was established by legislation in 1976 following agreement reached between the Commonwealth and the States, for the purpose of improving inter-government co-operation in accordance with the federalism policy. Membership of the Council comprises five members of the Commonwealth Parliament, one member from each of the six State Parliaments, six local government representatives and five distinguished citizens, one of whom, Professor R. C. Gates, is Chairman.

To give effect to its object of improving inter-government co-operation the Council has two principal functions. The first, which must be exercised subject to and in accordance with directions given at the Premiers Conference, is 'to inquire into and keep under consideration and review matters relating to inter-government co-operation', and to make recommendations to the participating governments and the Australian Council of Local Government Associations on these matters. The second is to inquire into, and report on, any matters relating to inter-government co-operation referred to it by a majority of the Premiers at a Premiers Conference.

Since its establishment, the Council has provided valuable advice to all spheres of government in respect of the relationships between them and such matters as interchange of staff between the various spheres of government. It is now some four years since the original Act establishing the Council was enacted. In that time the Council's operations and changes in governmental arrangements have brought to light the need for amendments to the Act. These amendments are aimed principally at reinforcing the Council's independence in the performance of its functions by providing for the Council to become a body corporate with its own bank account, to have control over its staffing arrangements, exempting the Council from Commonwealth and State taxation laws and by making it clear that the Council is not subject to direction by or on behalf of the Commonwealth. These changes require consequential amendments to ensure appropriate financial accountability in relation to auditing, accounting procedures and financial reporting.

Another important amendment provides for the change in title of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, which has observer status in the Council. There are also machinery-type amendments relating to the appointment of an acting chairman and to enable the Council to prescribe by resolution procedures for meetings and administration. The amendments embodied in the Bill have been agreed to by State Premiers, the Australian Council of Local Government Associations and the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. I also draw to the attention of honourable senators the fact that although the Northern Territory does not at present have representation on the ACIR it has sought admission as a full member of the Council on the same basis as each of the six States. The Commonwealth supports this change which will require a future amendment to the ACIR Act. We are actively seeking agreement of all States to this measure. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LONG SERVICE LEAVE (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is consequential to the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill 1981. Staff employed by authorities of the Northern Territory, other than the Northern Territory Public Service, presently derive their long service leave entitlements from the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976. Since the attainment of self-government, the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government consider that it is appropriate that staff of Northern Territory authorities should be covered by Northern Territory long service leave conditions rather than by conditions specified in Commonwealth legislation.

The purpose of this Bill is to exclude from the coverage of the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act staff of the proposed Teaching Service of the Northern Territory thereby enabling Northern Territory conditions to be applied to them. The Bill also amends the Act so as to enable staff of other Northern Territory authorities to be excluded by regulations from Commonwealth long service leave provisions. This will avoid the necessity of having to amend the Act further to exclude where it is desirable so to do, from the Commonwealth long service leave scheme staff of future Northern Territory authorities. Clause 3A has been included at the request of the Presiding Officers of the Parliament. The clause enables them to delegate their powers under the Act to grant long service leave or authorise payment in lieu of long service leave to staff of the parliamentary departments. The amendment will give the Presiding Officers the same power of delegation in respect of long service leave as they already have in relation to other conditions of employment of staff in Parliamentary departments. The opportunity has been taken to make at the same time a minor drafting amendment to the Act. Clause 4 amends section 10 of the Act to put beyond doubt the intention that the long service leave scheme does not apply to persons employed by the Commonwealth and remunerated solely by fees, allowance or commission. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill is to provide for the compulsory transfer of Commonwealth Teaching Service personnel based in the Northern Territory to the Northern Territory Teaching Service. The Bill also provides for an amendment to the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act directed at the categories of administrative staff that the Commissioner may employ. Honourable senators will be aware that up to 30 June 1979 responsibility for the provision of educational services in the Northern Territory rested with the Commonwealth. While this responsibility was transferred to the Northern Territory Government on 1 July 1979, it was decided that the Commonwealth Teaching Service would for the time being continue to provide teachers for Northern Territory schools. The Northern Territory Government has now decided to establish a Northern Territory Teaching Service and has requested the Commonwealth to transfer Commonwealth Teaching Service personnel working in the Northern Territory to this Service. Complementary legislation has been introduced in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly to set up this Teaching Service and to cover the transfer of Commonwealth Teaching Service personnel to this service. The two Bills are seen as complementary, and there has been close consultation with the Northern Territory Government on the arrangements for the transfer.

The provisions of the Bill concerned with this transfer follow, in general, similar amendments made to the Public Service Act to effect the transfer of Australian public servants to the Northern Territory Public Service. In order to ensure that the existing terms and conditions of employment of transferred officers and employees are maintained, clause 7 provides for the Minister to declare through a notice published in the Gazette that he is satisfied that the laws of the Northern Territory comply with the requirements of the Bill. The Minister may revoke this declaration if a change occurs in Northern Territory laws so that they no longer comply with these requirements. The Bill provides for the preservation of the rights and entitlements of transferred officers and employees in respect of such matters as salary, recreation and sick leave, and long service leave. The Bill also specifies the conditions under which a transferred officer may be re-appointed to the Commonwealth Teaching Service by way of transfer or promotion. Special re-entry to the Commonwealth Teaching Service is provided for in circumstances where an officer has been disadvantaged by the compulsory transfer. A Re-appointments Review Committee is to be established to determine eligibility for re-appointment to the Commonwealth Teaching Service under the conditions specified in clause 4 of the Bill.

In addition to providing for the transfer of personnel to the Northern Territory Teaching Service, clause 3 of the Bill amends Section 18 of the Act to enable administrative staff required by the Commissioner to be persons employed under either the Public Service Act or the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act. This will enable the Commissioner to secure the best qualified people for these positions. I believe that the Commonwealth Teaching Service has made a significant contribution to the development of education in the Northern Territory since its inception in 1972. The Government takes the view that it is now more appropriate that teachers in the Northern Territory should be members of the Northern Territory Teaching Service. This Bill provides for this transfer while at the same time preserving the terms and conditions of employment of the transferred officers and preserving the right of re-entry to the Commonwealth Teaching Service in appropriate circumstances for transferred officers. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Of course, as I have pointed out in this chamber on many occasions, if an honourable senator moves a substantive motion he can use any sort of language and have it accepted. We had to suffer that during our reign of office from 1972 to 1975 when honourable senators who now sit opposite, one of whom was then Leader of the Opposition, moved substantive motions in the form of amendments to the Budget and the loan Bills accusing the then Prime Minister and his Ministers of being corrupt, deceitful and dishonest and said that honourable senators who then sat on the Government back bench were of the same calibre. Of course, they got away with it. Yet when I quoted in this place a story from a newspaper which castigated the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the then Treasurer-the story that the Illawarra Mercury ran at the time dealt with taxation, from memory-and which said that what was being put about by the Government with regard to taxation was all lies, I incurred the wrath of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick). The President had to put the question and I was wheeled out of the place. The only satisfaction I got that day was that I was not wheeled out at the end of the Wilkinson sword which was introduced into this place as a publicity gimmick when Senator Magnus Cormack was President and to which I objected strongly at the time. However, I feel something ought to be done about honourable senators being allowed, by way of substantive motion, to accuse members of this chamber and of the other chamber of being corrupt, dishonest, deceitful and similar words. As a matter of fact, they have also been used in debate by Senator Carrick. I thought it was ironical that when I used the word 'lies' he moved for my suspension. When we were in government he was quite prepared during debate on the loan Bills to accuse us of being dishonest and deceitful. Yet he took umbrage when I quoted from a newspaper. There we have the double standards. I would have thought that the Standing Orders Committee, in its wisdom, would have seen fit to recommend some alteration in the Standing Orders, either to prevent the use of the types of words which I have just cited in a substantive motion or not to cause honourable senators to be expelled from this place when they use words such as 'lies'. Of course, I could quite easily have got around the situation if I had been prepared to substitute the word 'untruths' or something like that. That would have been accepted, but I could then have been accused of not quoting correctly from the newspaper I was using. I had to insist that I be allowed to use those words so I could not be accused of misquoting in this Parliament words used in a newspaper. That is past history now, but I daresay that if a similar matter occurs again and I have to use those words, I might be prepared to do so and to incur the wrath of the Senate. I would have hoped, this matter having been referred to the Privileges Committee and to the Standing Orders Committee, that something would have been done with respect to words used in a substantive motion. I am looking at Senator Withers who has just looked over at me. He was one senator who was prepared to move motions containing words accusing us of being liars and deceivers-the worst names that members of the then Opposition could lay their tongues to. Those words were not thought up on the spur of the moment. They had been given due consideration by every member of the then Opposition in the party room, otherwise they would not have got into this place in the form of a substantive motion. I say again that it is time the Standing Orders Committee gave due consideration to recommending to the Senate a Standing Order which states either that words which are offensive to some of us can be used or cannot be used even in a substantive motion. We could not object at the time because it was ruled that Standing Orders protected the movers of such amendments, but there was no Standing Order to protect an honourable senator like me when on 29 May 1979 I quoted from a newspaper. All I can say is that it is time that something was done to correct that anomaly which in my view exists in the Standing Orders.

Item 3-Presentation of Committee Reports (Recommittal)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of presentation of committee reports is a difficult one. I think many of us are worried by it. I am certainly far from satisfied with the conclusion the Standing Orders Committee has reached. We all know that when a committee report is brought down and the chairman of the committee makes his statement it is customary to have some debate on the report at that time. But there is the problem that other honourable senators have not seen the committee report. It has been suggested at times that the report should be debated at some later stage. We know that there is a considerable amount of public interest in these reports at the time they are brought down and if there is no opportunity for some debate to take place it may well be that such report of the Senate will never be noticed by the media, the public and so forth. Someone may move that the Senate take note of the paper and it may not be debated again for six to nine months, by which time the interest in and the urgency of the matter will have gone.

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Orders Committee came to this conclusion:

As was indicated during the debate in the Senate, the solution to the problem seen by Honourable Senators is not in making committee reports available before they are tabled but in being able to debate them shortly after their presentation, by agreement and arrangement.

Quite frankly, I do not think that is a solution at all. I do not read that as meaning that it is a recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee that senators should not be entitled to debate reports at the time they are brought down. It is put forward in the form of a solution. To table the report and not have any opportunity for debate on it until some later time is unsatisfactory. There will be very little interest in the report if it comes up for debate the next day and some honourable senators make some comment on it. Reports are known to the members of the committee concerned and therefore those members of the committee can open up the debate and argument and at least encourage some interest in the report if there is a debate at that time. I think it would be highly unsatisfactory if the debate were in any way to be prevented from taking place.

I recognise the fact that other senators are not in a position to enter properly into the debate. If there are other honourable senators who have a close interest in the report including, perhaps, the chairman of another committee which is doing contemporaneously some investigation of the same subject and wants to make comment on the report, I think it desirable that those senators should see the report. I do not believe that this so-called magic right of the Senate to have first knowledge of the report is something that should be absolute. Some people are aware that reports are going to be brought down and will see the tabled statements and so forth before the matter comes before the Senate, but it is important that the Senate should promote and highlight its own reports and encourage interest in them. I am afraid that this suggestion-it is not a recommendation-of the Standing Orders Committee that we should not really allow any debate at the time the report is brought down is one with which I do not agree. I think it necessary to have some debate at that time to encourage interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong unduly debate on this section of the report but I believe it is an important section. I agree that in all instances the rights of the Senate must be safeguarded but in this case I am puzzled at and indeed take some small exception to the statement that 'the prohibition on the publication of a committee report prior to its presentation to the Senate is a necessary safeguard of the right of the Senate to have first knowledge of the reports of its committees'. I question just what that statement means. What is 'the Senate' under those circumstances? Is it this room? Is it the tables and chairs? Is it the carpet? No, it is not; it is the senators. The situation with these reports is that some senators have knowledge of them and the rest do not. So, in fact, the Senate does not have first knowledge of the report of the committees; some senators have first knowledge of the report of the committees. The Senate as a whole does not have first knowledge of the reports of the committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I take Senator Missen's point and will not extend it unduly. Members of the committee in question know the content of the report. The staff know and it is possible that some other people know. It is sometimes highly pertinent, depending on what the subject of the report is, for senators to have an opportunity to comment at the time it is brought down, as Senator Missen said, particularly in the case of controversial reports. Through the media the public is made aware of the controversy of the report or the recommendations of the report. The only access by the media to the opinions of senators who have an interest in that subject is through those who are in a privileged position in terms of prior knowledge. I believe it is important that some reasonable arrangement be reached-and I understand what principles must be safeguarded-so that when a report is important other senators can have the opportunity to comment at the time.

I certainly agree with the sentiments of the Standing Orders Committee report that reports should be debated shortly after their presentation. This is highly desirable in many cases but I am afraid that pious statement does not help us at all. I question the use of a term such as 'the right of the Senate' when clearly there is a bit of muddle-headed thinking in that sentence about just what the Senate is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Martin has said. It seems to me that there are three points at which it might be said that reports are available to the Senate. The first point is the time at which the report becomes available to senators. As Senator Martin has made quite clear, there are some senators, normally the members of the committee concerned, who will have seen the report before it reaches the Senate while other honourable senators will not. The second point is the time at which the report is publicly available, in other words, when it has been tabled and distributed throughout the House and to the media. Finally, there is the point at which debate takes place on the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that once it is publicly available to the media, unless debate takes place forthwith as a media event, as a matter of publicity, the debate will be meaningless. Therefore, I support the point which I think Senator Missen was making, namely, that debate must take place immediately the report is made publicly available. But I can see no reason in principle why some members of the Senate know about this report before it is publicly tabled in the Senate. Why should the report not be available to all senators and to no one else, say, two hours before the report is due to be tabled so that those who wish to take part in the debate may be fully informed on the content of the report? So, the report is issued to all senators two hours before the report is tabled, the report is tabled, the statement on the report is made and debate immediately ensues. The debate by those who wished to take part in it would then be an informed debate. It seems to me that all purposes would be served by such a procedure. It would not be generally released until it was tabled in the Senate. It would be given to all senators two hours before the official tabling statement was made. An informed debate could take place immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say only a few words in this discussion. I should have thought that what comprised the Senate was well known. The Constitution states what the Senate shall be composed of and how its members shall be elected. That obviously means that the members of the Senate comprise the Senate. If it is desirable to debate a report immediately, some provision should be made to debate it. I think the practice has unfortunately developed in the Senate recently whereby some responsible member of the opposing party says all that he wishes to say on a matter and then seeks leave to continue his remarks later, but will never again refer to it. Everyone else who wishes to speak has to seek leave which can be refused by any person. Unless somebody has something to say in continuation we ought to drop this habit of seeking leave to continue our remarks later, and then a discussion can ensue. I should like to hear some of the legal men give us an opinion as to whether some reports might be libellous if they were distributed and debated without the protection which the Senate gives them.
—They are normally distributed to committee members before tabling now.

—Yes, but the odd occasion could arise when there was some libellous statement in a report which was not covered by privilege. Of course, it may be that there are cases of libel but that nobody picks them up or no one is inclined to proceed with them. I may be wrong on that point. We, by virtue of our office and position, would be protected from a libel action. But it is one of the things that needs to be decided. If there is the possibility of a solution to the problem about whether we could have a discussion, I think the Committee should examine the question. But there is also the other question: I think that it could disrupt government orders of the day and the carrying out of business.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators saw this morning that if there were an open discussion on the two reports which were mentioned, it would take some considerable time. We could not have discussed the Standing Orders Committee report and we would be so much poorer for not having done so.

I do not know whether the Committee could look at this matter. I take it, despite the fact that no resolutions are being made, that the Committee will at some time take note of the remarks made in this debate and review the situation should there be any alterations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Sen H.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what has been said by the previous speakers. The Standing Orders Committee report, of course, is the property of the Senate, and that is the senators themselves. Some of those senators have the advantage of knowing what is in that report, but there may be many other senators who may be interested to know what is in that report and they may wish to speak to it. They are placed at an absolute disadvantage because they first see the report when it is presented in the chamber and they have no time to speak in depth to that report. I support the suggestion that has been made that perhaps senators could be given an opportunity, say two hours before the report's presentation, to look at it. As has been pointed out by Senator Cavanagh, this could create legal problems. I do not know about that, but I suggest that we could refer this matter back to the Standing Orders Committee to enable it to have a further look at it. I know some honourable senators on that Committee have legal backgrounds. They could investigate this matter. I hope that they refer the matter back to the Senate after they have another look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: One other suggestion I make is that in order to give senators a further opportunity to peruse reports, perhaps the day before presentation, the Senate be informed of what reports are likely to be presented. That would give those honourable senators who are interested in a particular report an opportunity to have that report two hours before presentation and so make a reasonable contribution in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: -I concur in the main with what has been said, but I see one problem with the way in which the reports are tabled now and with the suggestions that have been made in respect of the future. If some devices could be found whereby honourable senators could get the report prior to its tabling in the Senate, who is to say that that report will not be picked up by the Press and commented upon before it is even tabled in the Senate? I should think a far better way of doing it would be--
—Two hours.
—Even two hours. The Budget, of course, is locked up until the Treasurer delivers it.
—It is not quite in the same class.

—But there often are recommendations in these reports, and a lot of work goes into them. Senators travel the length and breadth of Australia to take evidence and to compile a report. They give a lot of their time. I suggest that a better way of doing it would be on a given day to table the report and have the Chairman make a short statement. Then some means could be devised in the Standing Orders whereby that report must be debated in the next week of sittings. That would give the opportunity to every interested member of the Senate to participate in the debate. Presently the chairman of a committee makes in some cases, a lengthy statement and then another member of that committee seeks leave to support him.
—If he is lucky.

—If he is lucky. Then the matter goes on the Notice Paper and it may be there for any length of time. I think the present situation is that the responsible Minister is required to make a response to a report within six months. That has happened in some cases but not in all cases. Here we have a report which has been compiled by senators sitting on a standing committee. They gave much of their time during the days when Parliament was not sitting. The taxpayers have been put to a lot of expense. In the main, two people speak to the report after it is tabled and it is never called on again in the Senate for full debate. My suggestion is that reports be tabled on a given day, a short statement from the chairman be made-I do not suggest that a debate take place; just a short statement-and then the Standing Orders be altered to ensure that that report, irrespective of what the Government thinks is debated during the next week of sitting. I think that would cover all the problems with which we are faced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — What Senator McLaren has described as a possible alternative is what actually happens in many cases in respect to reports. It has already been indicated that that procedure is not considered to be satisfactory. I believe it would be possible to reach some arrangement whereby debate could take place at that time by those who were keenly interested, and then a subsequent longer debate could be undertaken at a later stage. I do not think that this recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee really comes to grips with the problem in the terms that senators would like to have seen.

SPEECH.PARA: I comment briefly on what Senator Cavanagh said. I take his point about possible difficulties in regard to libel. I am not one of the Senate's lawyers so I will not try to advance a legal argument on that point. I will seek advice from the lawyers. But while I was listening to his speech and thinking about the matter it occurred to me that he raised what is really the exception to the rule. What we ought to have is a rule which embodies the sorts of things we have been talking about with a safeguard for that exception and not let the extreme case in which there is a possibility of libel dictate the manner in which we handle all reports because that would not always be necessary. However, we should take cognisance of that sort of difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: -I am confused about Senator Martin's remarks. She said that my suggestion is already in operation in respect of some reports. I should like her to enlighten me as to when that has happened and as to what reports she is talking about. I cannot recall any Senate standing committee reports being introduced into the Parliament on any given day and then being brought forward the following week for full debate. If honourable senators look at the Notice Paper they will see that these reports languish there for any length of time. Never are they brought forward for debate the week after presentation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move as an amendment to the motion that Item 3 be noted:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add 'but the Committee requests the Standing Orders Committee to look again at the procedure for presentation of committee reports in the light of suggestions made during this debate'.

Item 5-Estimates Committees
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That Item 5 be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another item which I think reflects a very poor reaction from the Standing Orders Committee the members of which, apart from Senator Rae, are not in the chamber now to hear our criticisms. Item 5 deals with the question of whether Estimates committees should take evidence in camera. The opinion of the Committee is that they should not. The Committee points out that Estimates committees, in examining the Estimates, perform a function that was formerly carried out in the Committee of the Whole. The Committee of the Whole does not take in camera evidence. In other words, the Committee report contends that as it has not been done before it cannot be done in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not accept the mighty conservative attitude which has been adopted in the report. As I see it, it is not satisfactory that an Estimates committee, which is expected to go into more detail than the Committee of the Whole did in the past, should have to run off to the Senate if something arises which means that, in its opinion, it ought to hear evidence in camera. This question may arise suddenly, perhaps when embarrassing matters affecting privacy or commercial confidentiality need to be discussed. As Senator Rae has pointed out, such cases would be very obvious examples. I do not think that in such cases the Committee should have to refer to the Senate. The judgment of the members of the committee should be sufficient to enable them to make the decision. That suggestion is turned down by the Standing Orders Committee on the basis that it has not been done in the past and therefore should not be done in the future. That is not an argument, in my view. I will certainly vote against this item also. I have been persuaded on two occasions now to vote with more courtesy to the Standing Orders Committee for amendments which ask the Committee to consider matters again but I am certainly not prepared to vote for the attitude that we find here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to disagree with Senator Missen. I was once chairman of an Estimates committee in which a request was made by a witness to give in camera evidence. The witness was appearing on behalf of a statutory corporation which was in competition with other enterprises in the community. The corporation claimed, on the commercial confidentiality basis to which Senator Rae and Senator Missen have referred, that answering a particular question would jeopardise its competitive position in a commercial situation and requested that it be allowed to give in camera evidence to the committee. It was pointed out to the corporation that a case would have to be made to the Senate to enable the committee to take the evidence in camera.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee waited for the statutory corporation to make a case to it on why the evidence should be heard in camera so the committee could determine whether the request was one which it would put to the Senate. Having had that proposition put to it the corporation in question decided that commercial confidentiality was not of such critical importance and answered the question. Of course, we had no basis for deciding, because we did not know the answer to the question, whether commercial interests were at stake. In fact, they were not. Now, it might have just been the case of an over-nervous or over-shy witness. The request might also have been a try-on. In any case, it was not necessary for the committee to request that in camera evidence be given. I think we should bear that in mind. The committee was very conscious at the time of the fact that if it was inclined, on the basis of the case made to it, to allow in camera evidence to be given it would then have to present a recommendation to the Senate.

I do not think that Senate Estimates committees ought to be able to sit in camera without a very good reason and without the permission of the Senate. The committees are meant to represent the whole of the Senate and its interests. To make a decision like that, which would be made with no warning to the Senate, would not be in the interests of the proceedings of the Senate. It may be that the committee would choose to defer taking evidence and inform the Senate, but it may be that the committee could decide that it was important to its proceedings to give permission to proceed in camera, and do so immediately. In that case nobody other than the members of the committee or senators sitting in on the committee at that stage would have any idea that an issue of such importance had arisen. I do not think that it would be a satisfactory alternative just to say that the Senate ought to be notified that in camera evidence was going to be taken. I think that sort of evidence ought not to be allowed to be given to an Estimates committee, which is different from a standing committee or a select committee, without the Senate knowing, agreeing and giving the committee permission. I do not think that it hurts at all for a case to be made. If there is a case it can be made. It can be made by a witness, department or statutory corporation to the Estimates committee and in turn to the Senate. But I think we are more likely to find that the present sanction deters witnesses from requesting the privilege of giving in camera evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an odd exception, isn't it?
—No, I do not think it is. I think it is a sanction against requests being made.
—Why should we inhibit that?

—It is not inhibited at the moment, if there is a case for it, but I think we should seek to inhibit a move to have evidence given in private when it is not necessary. The bases on which evidence either should not be given to a committee at all or can be given in camera have been laid down by the Senate. Perhaps we could look at those bases and debate them further. I certainly support the retention of the present position until a better case is put to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Missen that a mighty conservative attitude has been taken on this question. I think what we are forgetting is that the Standing Order in question deals only with Estimates committees. The Australian Labor Party originally opposed the establishment of the Estimates committees and was given an assurance that they would not replace the Committee of the Whole, which is a public forum for inquiry. The Estimates committees are designed to investigate the expenditure of public moneys by public organisations. They are concerned not with secret organisations, but with public organisations and public money. The public has a right to know what is happening to its money. It is hard to visualise a case in which an answer may prejudice a company's commercial competitiveness with some other company, but there are occasions when the Senate could be approached.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think we would be carrying out our obligations to conduct a proper scrutiny of public money if it were done behind closed doors where no one knew about it. I think the fact that publicity is given to statements secures their truthfulness. I wonder how many companies would escape public scrutiny if we had a practice of hearing in camera evidence even when there was no need to attach secrecy to the evidence. If we understand that this is an examination of the expenditure of public money by public organisations there is no justification for secrecy in the giving of evidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has a long history. It goes back to 1972. An Estimates committee dealt with the same statutory authority to which Senator Martin referred a little while ago. I do feel somewhat sorry for that statutory authority. It did before her Committee what was suggested ought to have been done back in 1972. Be that as it may. At that time the Senate agreed that there were no matters about which a statutory authority could refuse to answer questions of a Senate Estimates committee or the Senate. It was noted that it was desirable to give some protection to the commercial confidentiality which may be otherwise breached. It was noted also that, for other good reasons, it may be necessary for the Committee to have the capacity to take evidence in camera. In 1972 the then Senator Murphy moved a motion. The motion stated:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee is of the opinion that the matter of Estimates committees meeting in private session should be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for its consideration and report to the Senate prior to the next meetings of the Estimates committees and in this regard confirms the opinion so expressed by Estimates Committee B in its report.
Estimates Committee B, in its report at that time, stated:

That the Committee is of the opinion that the matter of Estimates committees meeting in private session should be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for its consideration and report to the Senate prior to the next meetings of the Estimates committees.

Estimates Committee B made that recommendation to the Senate, with the view of ensuring that whilst we could get all evidence we could also do the fair thing and ensure that protection, where warranted, was provided. It seems to me, after this matter has been debated in this chamber for more than eight years, quite incredible to keep hearing the argument that it is better to get nothing than to receive it in camera. That is the part that I cannot understand. People continue to adopt that view which has been held by the majority of the Standing Orders Committee over the years. This matter has been referred on I think three, if not four, occasions to the Standing Orders Committee. The Senate has repeatedly resolved that it was a matter which ought to be explored with an expectation that something was going to come out of the Standing Orders Committee to provide for evidence to be taken in camera. Each time it goes to the Standing Orders Committee it comes back with a recommendation that the principle should not be adopted. It is quite a yo yo.

In the meantime many large commercial or quasi-commercial statutory authorities are placed in a most invidious position. They can be very adversely affected and prejudiced severely in their commercial undertakings by the disclosure to their competitors of confidential information which has yet to be acted upon. We do wish to assert-a very clear assertion was made in 1972, 1974 and on another occasion since then, but I have forgotten the date-the right of the Senate and its committee to obtain all information which it requires from statutory authorities. The only fair way we can possibly do that is for the Senate to give to the Estimates committees the power to take evidence in camera where they deem it appropriate. It may be that once the committee has taken the evidence in camera it will say: 'That should not remain in camera. There is no real commercial confidentiality about that. The authority has not made out a case for it to remain in camera. It will be published'. At least the opportunity is there. It may be that the matter is of overwhelming importance and the consideration of the protection of the commercial confidentiality of the authority is overridden by the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Standing committees can do this.

—Standing committees can do it and frequently do it. It seems quite extraordinary to me that we have this incredible sensitivity about an Estimates committee being able to take evidence in camera, as if it were something totally novel, when the standing and select committees can and do; yet they too are parts of the Senate and are carrying out functions.
—But they are not examining the expenditure of public funds.

—Yes, they are. The Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations does very little else. In fact, it was established as the follow-up for the Estimates committee procedure. It is one of the reasons for its existence. This is a matter about which the options are either that we are unfair to people-I do not think the Senate would wish to be unfair to people-and act in a cavalier way and disregard the rights and protection of people, which I do not think the Senate would wish to do, or else we circumscribe our opportunity to be able to obtain in the public interest and in the performance of our duty information which we have asserted we have a right to obtain. I go back to the suggestion, for the umpteenth time, that I have made in this chamber that the sooner we take the logical course and give to the Senate Estimates committees the capacity to take evidence in camera the sooner we will make the operation of the Estimates committees more effective. We will have taken an appropriate step in the interests of the protection of the rights of individuals and corporations which come before our committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -I have listened with great interest to this debate. I see some problems arising if Estimates committees are going to be given the power to take evidence in camera because Estimates committees are entirely different from Senate standing or select committees where a staff of experts is made available to give advice. Senate Estimates commitees do not have that facility. Under our present Standing Orders any senator is allowed to attend an Estimates committee hearing. Any senator is not allowed to attend a standing committee hearing if evidence is being taken in camera. Many changes will have to be made to the Standing Orders if Senate committees are going to be given the power to take evidence in camera. The Standing Orders will have to be amended to the effect that only the elected members of the Estimates committee can attend the hearing in camera. The matter that has been raised at that Estimates committee hearing may have been raised by a senator who is not an elected member of that committee, and it is his right to do so. Where will the line be drawn as to who is to attend the hearing of the Estimates committee when evidence is taken in camera? I ask Senator Rae: Has any thought been given to that problem?

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter which I wish to raise-I will mention it in regard to another issue with which this report deals-is the fact that Estimates committees are now assuming the role of the Committee of the Whole. Many matters are debated in Estimates committees about which we are prevented from debating when they come before the Committee of the Whole because the gag is applied. That is a problem which we run into just about every year now when we debate the Appropriation Bills in the Committee of the Whole. People may have an interest in a certain subject which comes before a certain Estimates committee but are not able to attend that Estimates committee hearing because they are involved in another Estimates committee. They may wish to pursue the matter in the Committee of the Whole but are prevented from doing so because the Government has taken the view that the debate is dragging on too long and puts a gag on it. Therefore, the matter cannot be explored.

That is another problem which is fast rearing its ugly head with Estimates committees. I will oppose this proposition unless I can be convinced that there is some way in which the Standing Orders can be altered so that all members who have an interest in a matter are allowed to attend the Estimates committee hearings at which in camera evidence is taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support very strongly the remarks of Senator Rae and, I gather, Senator Missen, although I am sorry I was not able to hear what he said. I add two small points. Before I do so let me say that Senator McLaren raised the question of Senate Estimates committees not having staff made available to them. In fact, we are trying to arrange, as he would know, for staff to be made available to assist them.
—You are trying to arrange it?

—I do not think Senator McLaren was present at the last Estimates committee hearings. I think he was overseas at the time. At the last Estimates hearings we did arrange for staff to be provided from the standing committees. However, in addition Senator McLaren stated there would have to be very substantial changes made to the Standing Orders to adopt this proposal. Is the argument that we would have to change the Standing Orders a reasoned argument against the changing of the rule? I do not think it is a valid argument.

SPEECH.PARA: It is said in this report that we have to remember that the Estimates committees are performing a function formerly carried out in the Committee of the Whole and that the Committee of the Whole does not take in camera evidence. Are we to be bound by a change in procedure made in 1972? Are we to be bound in 20 or 30 years time by a decision made in 1972 that Estimates committees should take over a function that formerly was carried out in the Committee of the Whole? Let there be not the slightest doubt that the Estimates committees perform a separate function altogether. That function may originally have been to take over from the Committee of the Whole but we all know how they operate at present. It is ridiculous to ignore the facts and to talk about Senate Estimate committees carrying out this function as if they were still the Committee of the Whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee of the Whole did not question witnesses.

—Thank you. Senator Hamer reminds me that the Committee of the Whole did not question witnesses. Surely we can leave the decision to the good sense of the committees-they are bipartisan committees-to make a determination at the time, as the standing committees do at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of that last remark of Senator Lewis I must say that I envy him and the committees that he has served on because not all the committees I have served on have displayed such good sense.

SPEECH.PARA: I was alarmed at a couple of the comments that have been made in this discussion. I am open to persuasion on this subject. I have found Senator Rae's arguments very persuasive but there is just one thing that did not persuade me and that is the lack of an example of when it has been necessary to take in camera evidence. I have given an example of a situation in which it was claimed it was necessary on commercial grounds. When one statutory corporation was invited to make a case-not give the evidence, but to make a case-in support of its claim as to why an answer to a question could threaten its commercial position it chose not to make out a case and instead gave the evidence and the evidence did not affect its commercial viability. The committee was being tried on. That is what it came down to.

We are told that a committee could take evidence in camera and then, having heard the evidence, could change its mind and make the evidence public. Surely that would strike terror into the heart of every public servant, including the ones who tell the truth. The witnesses would be at the mercy of the day to day whim or the judgment, as it may fluctuate, of the members of a committee, and as we know the membership of committees can change from day to day under particular circumstances. Perhaps we could have some guidelines on in camera evidence. I have not heard of any guidelines. We have the guideline of commercial confidentiality. I have given the example of an attempt to exploit this in camera provision. I have not yet heard of a genuine case having been made, although there may have been one, in which case a request could have been made for evidence to be taken in camera and that request could have been acceded to. I do not think it is at all satisfactory for the committee to say that evidence may be given in camera and then to say that it does not think it should have been taken in camera so it will make it public, although when the evidence was given it was on the understanding that it would be in camera. A case can be made out in terms of principle. At the moment the position is just too scrappy.

I support the opinion that Estimates committees are different from standing committees. There are major differences in their functions. Every senator is entitled to attend an in camera meeting of an Estimates committee. The only thing non-members of the committee are not entitled to do is vote. Every senator can attend a private meeting of an Estimates committee but when it comes to a vote in that committee only members of the committee may vote. Not every senator is entitled to attend an in camera meeting of a standing committee or of a select committee. These are very significant differences which either were not known to some of the people who have talked on this subject or the implications of which have not been considered. In camera for an Estimates committee just means that members of the Press and public are shut out. In the circumstance where all senators are entitled to attend a hearing they ought to be informed of it and given the opportunity to indicate their agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to debate the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence report on Australia and the Association of South East Asian Nations. Mr Deputy President, you will recall that this is one of the few opportunities we have had for many years to debate a report from this Committee within a short time of its being tabled in the Parliament. This has been one of the complaints of many of us. Very often when reports were to be debated events either caught up with us or passed us. This report was tabled on 4 December during the sittings prior to Christmas. This report entitled 'Australia and ASEAN' covers an area of great importance for Australia. This importance is recognised by all political parties. Australia's relationship with ASEAN is a challenge to Australia's ability to manage its international relations. The Committee endorses the views of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, and also the expressed views of the Department of Foreign Affairs. On page 26 of the Committee report the views Mr Hayden put before the Committee are shown. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: ASEAN is the touchstone of Australia's performance in international relations; if we cannot manage our relations successfully on this front, there must be severe reservations about our prospects on others.
He went on to say:

Our ASEAN relationships cover the field. They proceed from a long-established basis of amity and recognise strong mutual interests. At the same time, however, it has become increasingly clear that they must accommodate competitive pressures and political differences that often go to the heart of our perceived national interests.

The Department of Foreign Affairs in its submission to the Committee raised the point that our relationship with ASEAN was the greatest challenge to Australian foreign policy. On page 29 of the report the Department's view is stated as follows:

The co-ordination and pursuit of policy towards ASEAN and the ASEAN countries has become a task of special significance. It is a task, and a set of circumstances, which Australia has not been required to confront in its external relations before the present decade.

These views have been examined by the Committee and reported. There is an increasing tendency for ASEAN to act as a group. In the report we deal at some length with this problem. Since the formation of ASEAN the region has experienced major changes. These changes were examined by the Committee. On page 24 of the report the Committee's view sets out in some detail the changes as we see them. Of course, these changes would not be exclusive ones. The Committee report states:
In the period since ASEAN was formed the region has experienced major changes that have affected the Association's members' and Australia's policies. These changes include:
the emergence of three communist Indo-China states and the decline of the United States military role in South East Asia;
an international economic recession bringing a reduction in growth rates and a swing to protectionist policies in developed countries, including major ASEAN market countries;
changes in major powers' relationships e.g. China and the United States, China and Japan; progressive economic development in ASEAN countries in spite of increasing energy costs; and
growing doubts about the regional security situation created by the Chinese invasion of Vietnam, Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea and Vietnamese incursion into Thailand.

The rapidly changing regional situation has required Australia and ASEAN to adapt their policies to meet these changes. Australia was also presented with the requirement to adjust, by the mid-1970s, to a situation of dealing with a revitalised ASEAN. The growing international acceptance of ASEAN as a cohesive group has brought with it repercussions for Australia's relations with the Association.

A point has now been reached where Australia's relations with ASEAN encompass most aspects of Australia's international relations and many of these issues increasingly impinge on Australian domestic policies.

It is quite significant that whilst the Committee received a variety of views on the relationship and whilst opinions differed on the state of the relationship and the knowledge we have of one another, no witness questioned the need for close Australia-ASEAN co-operation. In the Committee's view the knowledge and perceptions we have of each other are totally inadequate. Indeed one witness summed up the situation in the following manner:
Australian ignorance of its neighbouring states and people is considerable and regrettable. Their ignorance of us is almost overwhelming and could at some future time react seriously against us.

The Committee stresses that there is an urgent need to develop a greater knowledge and appreciation of each other's social, cultural, economic and political systems, languages, problems, aspirations and value systems. The Committee also stressed that understanding is not a one-way business. Whereas there is a challenge to Australia to understand these factors in our relations with the ASEAN countries, it is equally important that those countries learn to understand Australia, our political systems and our society. In other words, understanding is a two-way business.

The Committee acknowledged that the ASEAN record of achievement has been great, notably from the mid-1970s following the situation in Indo-China. There has been an impressive record of development in the Association. Nevertheless, ASEAN is still in its formative stage, as indeed are Australia's relations with the Association. The Committee acknowledges that economic issues, both government and private, bi-lateral and multilateral, have developed as the focal, if not the dominant, point of the relationship. In its report the Committee makes a number of observations in relation to economic policies. Some of these economic policies go beyond the simple ASEAN relations. The Committee refers to its report which was tabled some time ago on the implications for Australia of proposals for a new international economic order. On page 30 of this report the Committee draws attention to this. In dealing with the economic relationship the Committee states:

In addition to their impact on Australian-ASEAN relations, economic matters have wider implications for Australia, mainly in the context of proposals for a new international economic order and relations generally with the Third World countries. The ASEAN countries identify themselves as Third World members and in this respect the Committee's observations in its report The New International Economic Order-Implications for Australia, page 45, are relevant:
Page 45 of the report should also be read. It states:

Australia's attitudes must continue to take into account that the Asian countries are its neighbours and that the ASEAN group in particular has a cohesion and solidarity which is significant, one which is shaped importantly by the Group of 77 philosophy . . .
That is to be interpreted in that context. The report continued:

Consequently, Australia's actions and responses will be closely examined from that aspect. They will affect political relations with the region and the countries in it and this itself will affect relations with the developing world generally. Consistent with their interests, the ASEAN countries have at times had a moderating influence in developing countries forums.

I think this highlights the fact that economic relations with the ASEAN group have implications which may well go beyond that and affect our relations with the Third World in general. The report also deals at length with our cultural and educational relations. I commend those aspects of the report to those who are interested. This highlights, I think, the broadening of our relations with these countries which, as we said earlier, encompasses the whole of our relations. It covers the fields of culture, education and the media. The report deals with all of these aspects.

I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to some of the conclusions and recommendations of the Committee. I know that other members of the Committee would like to deal with other matters. I am trying to be fairly brief. The Committee warns-I think this is an important element-against regarding Australia's relationship with ASEAN as a special relationship and one which should be fostered. The Committee, on page 24, makes reference to this. There has been a feeling in some sections of the community-I do not think it has been reflected in Government policy but certainly it has been felt in some sections of the community-that ASEAN and Australia have a special relationship. The Committee notes that this, of course, raises grave dangers because it nurtures false hopes and expectations and also ignores our relations with other countries in the Asian-Pacific region. It might be a matter of interest to the Senate that a few weeks ago I was in Singapore. This report was widely commended by senior officers of the Singapore foreign ministry who thought it was most objective and sensible. They referred to this aspect and said how wise we were to warn against this feeling that there was, between Australia and ASEAN, some special type of relationship. So the Committee's views have been endorsed by at least one member of ASEAN and I expect it will also be commended by others. Perhaps I should read what the Committee had to say about this special relationship. Having warned against it we did say that we should pursue a long term relationship based upon mutual respect. The report stated:

A relationship of this type can nurture false hopes and expectations which cannot always be fulfilled and can be construed by others as discriminatory in the context of Australia's overall foreign relations. It must be accepted that there are occasions when Australia and ASEAN act to serve their own interests in a manner which may be opposed to the other's interests.

That, I think, is a realistic approach. The Committee also drew attention to another matter. I am not aware of anyone else previously drawing attention to this matter. In the next decade new leaders will emerge in the ASEAN countries whose perceptions may well be different from those of the present leaders. On page 24 the Committee drew attention to this. It states:

When considering Australia's approach to ASEAN it is salutary to recognise that within this decade a new generation of political leaders will emerge in the member states. They will be leaders whose attitudes were not moulded by colonial experience. It is possible that their attitudes will differ from present attitudes towards Australia and ASEAN. The Committee concludes that Australia's approach to ASEAN and its members must take into account these changes and must recognise that Australia's response to these developments is crucial to sound long-term relations.
On page 28 we also drew attention to another factor which, I suppose, is a sensitive factor but one which no committee considering Australia's ASEAN relation can ignore. The Committee states:

The frequently expressed Australian desire for a peaceful and prosperous region is shared by the ASEAN countries and the Committee agrees with the accepted view that the evolution of ASEAN has been a contribution to regional stability.

I add that these areas of internal stability are common to all Third World and developing countries. It would have been foolish for any committee to ignore the possibilities of change due to internal stability within the ASEAN countries with whom we have such close relations. Again, the Committee drew attention to the problems of policy co-ordination. I think this has been one of the difficulties in our relations because domestic policies are impinging more and more-not only with regard to ASEAN but also other countries, but particularly ASEAN-upon foreign policy considerations. Let us look at one example. I do not think the rights or wrongs matter. With the International Civil Aviation Policy dispute there was a domestic policy consideration and little consideration was given at the time to the foreign policy implications of it until they became serious.

This raises serious problems, not only with our relations with ASEAN but also with international relations altogether. We have to consider the proper co-ordination of domestic policies and the impact they may have upon our foreign relations.
