At least when we make decisions, they are made on the basis that we understand the implications on foreign policy. I suspect that too often this aspect has been given too little consideration. Departments, following their own policies, are placing too little consideration upon the effect such policies have on international relations. ICAP is just one of the cases. The recent decision to prosecute Singapore Airlines within Australian law-no one is going to argue about that-probably could have been done in a way where explanations could have been made first. The facts, properly understood by the Singapore Government, might have caused less problems. This is a lesson which we seem terribly slow to learn.

There is very little excuse for this, because the Committee in its 1979 report 'Australian representation overseas-the Department of Foreign Affairs' commented on the increasing complexity of domestic and international issues, their interdependence and effect on policy co-ordination. The Committee, in its latest report, stated:
The Committee considers the requirement for effective policy co-ordination is vital to furthering relations with the Association and its members and therefore recommends that:
(i) priority be given to developing policy-making processes to effectively co-ordinate the interdependent elements of domestic and foreign policies;
(ii) consultative procedures in policy co-ordination should be broadened to promote close liaison with the non-government sector when the issues involve them; and

(iii) to meet the growing demands of Australian-ASEAN relations, Australia's diplomatic missions in the region be provided with adequate staff and resources to ensure that policies are effectively implemented.

I think everyone would acknowledge that some efforts have been made to overcome this problem. An Australian-ASEAN research group has been set up to try to look ahead and plan for the problems that may arise. There seems to us still to be an urgent need for a proper co-ordination between departments, and between domestic policies and foreign policy implications. The Committee again draws attention to the urgency of this. The Committee also referred to our immigration policy and the fact that we are still considered in some areas to be a European outpost in an Asian region. Senator McIntosh and Senator Primmer will recall that when we visited the ASEAN countries together we had considerable discussions on this aspect. We put forward a view that there is an urgent need to project an Australian identity, not a European identity, in the region. The report continues:

The Committee believes it is imperative for Australia to remove this impression and recommends that the Government concentrate on projecting Australia's identity which is evolving through the changing structure of its society. The Committee also recommends the further development of immigration policy along the lines recently adopted, a humanitarian approach to the needs of refugees and the intensification of efforts to finalise reunion in Australia of families from East Timor.

One of the more encouraging signs is the growing business co-operation between Australia and ASEAN countries. We have the Australian-Indonesian Business Co-operation Committee, the Australian-Philippines Co-operation Committee and the ASEAN-Australian Business Council. The Confederation of Australian Industry is now developing close relations with similar organisations in ASEAN countries. The Committee commends the efforts by private industry to develop these relationships which are an important element, apart from government relationships.

The Committee also draws attention to the importance of cultural and educational considerations in our relationship and makes a number of recommendations. We are concerned at the growing lack of interest in the study of Asian languages. This is a terribly complex matter because they are difficult languages and unless students can see something for the future they do not wish to study these languages over a number of years. We cannot come up with any clear-cut recommendations because of these problems. We believe it is absolutely essential that there be a greater understanding in Australia of Asian languages and through that the cultures and traditions of the people with whom we are close neighbours. Australia is playing an important role in the teaching of English in many of the Asian countries particularly those countries, apart from Singapore, Malaysia and the Philippines, where English is not and has never been a language which has been well known. There is a demand in Indonesia, for example, for the teaching of English. I think we can do a lot more than we are doing now to meet these requirements. The Committee makes recommendations on these matters also.

The Committee believes the future relations with the ASEAN countries would involve a multitude of multilateral and bilateral considerations and external events will have a bearing on their relationship. On page 28 of the report we give examples of possible influences. I will mention just a few. They are:
The effect of regional and major power rivalries in the area;
Changes of leadership and of government in Australia and the ASEAN countries;
The state of Australian-ASEAN economic issues.
One cannot stress too much the importance of economic issues in our relationship. The examples continue:
Differing concepts of human rights . . .
The implications of proposals for a Pacific Basin Community;
Continuing difficulties with the ASEAN countries over Australia's International Civil Aviation Policy; and
Sea bed boundary negotiations with Indonesia.

Australia faces a number of challenges in its relationship with the ASEAN countries. We cannot expect relations to be always smooth. Australians must and will always act in defence of its own national interests, as member countries of ASEAN must and will. Where differences occur we must broaden our relationships and create a greater understanding between ourselves and the ASEAN countries of our respective cultures, traditions and valued systems. This is something I stressed when I visited these countries. Senator McIntosh will recall that we stressed that these countries have an obligation to understand our different systems and our more open society. As I said earlier, it is a two-way business. I believe that this report is a valuable contribution to Australian-ASEAN relations. This report has been well received by ASEAN countries-I mentioned Singapore earlier-as an objective and sensible approach to problems. I commend the report to the Senate.

Finally, on a slightly personal note, this will be the last occasion when I will speak in the Senate on a Senate standing committee report. I express my appreciation to my colleagues on the Committee-Senator Primmer, the Deputy Chairman, Senator McIntosh, Senator Sibraa, Senator Knight, Senator Scott and finally Senator Collard and to other members who have served in the past for their friendship and co-operation over a large number of years. I believe that we have been a very happy committee and that we have worked together as a team in the interests of the Senate and Australia. I will look back in the future with a good deal of appreciation and gratitude for the work the Committee has done which, in due modesty, I think has been significant in Australia's relations with other countries. This is acknowledged widely overseas. I say 'thank you' to my colleagues for their friendship and support over quite a number of years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -I welcome this debate on foreign affairs tonight and I am pleased to be able to follow Senator Sim, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I will say something more about the role that he has played in the Committee but I will leave that to my concluding remarks. I think that too often discussion on foreign affairs in the Senate has been restricted, for example, to ministerial statements. The Leader of the Opposition replies to such statements, and that is the end of the debate. When an important report, such as the report entitled 'Australia and ASEAN' that we are debating tonight, is tabled in the Senate the Chairman of the relevant committee and maybe one senator on the Opposition side, if we are lucky, speaks to it. After the honourable senator speaking seeks leave to continue his remarks the matter is put on the Notice Paper and, as often happens, when eventually we get round to debating the report it is irrelevant and not a lot can be said. In this instance the opposite applies. The report is important, as Senator Sim has said.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly I will refer to some remarks made by my colleague, Senator Primmer, when speaking on the report on 4 December. He raised the very important issue of the right of committees to travel. I think there has to be an appropriation for committees to travel on special occasions. I believe that this was one of those occasions and that this was a very special committee. There was a complete refusal by the Government to assist in any way though there were many ways it could have helped. I do not think it is right that I should tonight go into the discussions that we had with the relevant people except to re-emphasise the point that there were many ways in which the Government could have helped our Committee to travel through the region of the Association of South East Asian Nations. In my view it was absolutely essential that, for the report on ASEAN to be a success, committee members had a first-hand knowledge of the area especially in view of the fact that very few submissions came from the ASEAN region itself.

We were extremely fortunate that three members of the Committee-Senator Sim, Senator Primmer and Senator McIntosh-were able to make a private visit as a delegation. They used their own resources. The visit greatly assisted the Committee with its work and deliberations. It was a valuable visit. The honourable senators met important people. However, they did not receive the access that an official visit would have rated. If it had been an official visit they could have demanded access to leaders of the Opposition parties and trade union leaders whom the particular governments in the ASEAN countries would not have wanted them to meet. But on a private visit, no matter how governments looked after them, they were not able to demand the sort of access that an official visit would have rated.

Of course, some of the countries the honourable senators went to extended hospitality. I believe that the Malaysians treated the delegation as if it were there on a state visit. The Malaysians were amazed that an Australian parliamentary committee investigating relations between Australia and ASEAN was in fact paying its own way and travelling on the cheap. I think there was a danger, as my colleague Seantor Primmer said, of a loss of face whereby some of the countries might have felt that they were being slighted or downgraded by the very circumstances surrounding the Committee's visit. In view of some remarks made by Senator Sim, I think it is important to mention that the itinerary, the ticketing and the arrangements for the visit were made by Singapore Airlines Ltd. The Committee members were not able to receive concessions from Qantas Airways Ltd, and Qantas was quite within its rights. In view of some of the actions that have occurred since, it is interesting to note that the members had to go to Singapore Airlines. I intend to spend more time on that matter later. I will deal with some of the Committee's recommendations. One of the important recommendations concerns narcotics control. The report states:

The Committee fully supports any programs and proposals aimed at effective narcotics control and it recommends that particular emphasis be given to such endeavours and that any initiatives or opportunities to assist international efforts in this field should not be hampered by arbitrary decisions on staff restraints or budgetary limitations.
The report also states:
On a multilateral basis Australian participation in anti-narcotics measures includes:

a contribution of $1 million to the United Nations Fund for Drug Abuse Control over the 1979-81 period; membership of the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs along with all ASEAN countries; membership of the Commission's Heads of National Narcotic Law Enforcement Agencies; and attendance at Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting Working Group on Illicit Drugs.

Australia has narcotics officers stationed in a number of ASEAN countries. They co-operate with local authorities, but staff restraints or budgetary limitations must not be allowed to hamper their work. No one condones the activities of drug traffickers, and young Australians leaving this country are warned on the dangers of drug possession. The system of justice and punishment in a number of ASEAN countries leaves a lot to be desired. My concern is that many young Australians' lives are wasting away today in ASEAN gaols-in some instances because of possession of what we would call minor or soft drugs-while the ring leaders, the drug traffickers responsible for young Australians being in gaol, enjoy the good life in Australia. I have correspondence from parents whose children have been found guilty of the possession of cannabis and who have received sentences of life imprisonment. Not only are the sentences too harsh in some cases but also the time between arrest and sentence is far too long. It is absolutely essential that in the trial of Australians, English speaking interpreters are available. In some instances, of course, the Australian embassies or high commissions supply such people but in other instances this is not possible. The system is just not goood enough.

I refer to the case of three Australians, Hayward, Fellows and Sinclair, who have been in custody in Thai gaols for two and a half years. Their trial has lasted for 22 months but there has still been no judgment. In no way am I supporting the actions of Hayward, Fellows or Sinclair, but I am indebted to a New South Wales State Liberal member of parliament Mr John Dowd, who recently returned from Thailand where he visited the three people I have referred to. He said in a radio interview in Sydney, after he had visited them, that conditions in the gaols they were in were horrendous and that it was absolutely essential that they receive outside financial support to be able to survive. He was also critical of the Thai court procedures. I certainly support the main point that he made in that interview; that is, there must be talks between the two governments so that Australian prisoners can finish their terms of imprisonment in Australian gaols or receive parole concessions equivalent to those they would receive in Australia had they been sentenced by an Australian court.

I know that there are faults in that argument. I know that many people would say that that would encourage young Australians to risk drug trafficking because they would be able to spend part of their sentence in an Australian gaol. I know there are faults in that point of view, but the present system is bad and there must be a start somewhere. There certainly have to be talks between the Australian Government and the Thai Government. It is also absolutely essential, as we mention in this report, that we have in Bali a Consul-General who can provide consular services. This Committee and other committees have been talking about it for a long time. The Department of Foreign Affairs keeps saying that something will be done, but continually young Australian tourists are getting into difficulties and finding that they have no consular representative to go to.
Another important area that the committee dealt with was labour relations. One of our recommendations was as follows:

The Committee supports the proposal for a Labour Attache, with the appropriate background and qualifications, in the ASEAN region and recommends that the Government, in consultation with industry and the ASEAN governments, should examine the proposal.
The Committee took evidence on this matter and wrote in the report:

To achieve a better appreciation within ASEAN of Australian industrial relations the Confederation of Australian Industry has suggested the appointment of an Australian Labour Attache to serve the ASEAN group of countries . . . the concept met with approval including support from the Australian Council of Trade Unions . . .

The recommendation is supported by the Confederation of Australian Industry and by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I strongly support the appointment of a labour attache in the ASEAN region. If it proves successful, and I think it will, we should appoint more than one. If the Committee made a mistake, it was that we recommended that the Government should examine the situation. We should have been stronger; we should have recommended that an appointment take place straightaway. We should have been more insistent, especially in light of the fact that a labour attache has now been appointed to Japan and the Japanese Government has appointed a labour attache to Australia. A labour attache in the area would be able to explain our industrial relations system. He would be on the spot to help with any troubles that might arise. For example, I remind honourable senators of the dispute when the Malaysian Airlines System DC10 was grounded in Sydney. I do not think many people in the ASEAN region knew why it was grounded and I am sure that many people in Australia did not know why it was grounded. It was grounded because of actions that were being taken by the Malaysian authorities against Malaysian trade unionists. That was a particularly important point. A labour attache on the spot would have been able to explain to the Malaysian Government-it would not have mattered to me whether it understood-why that action was being taken. He would be responsible for providing up to date information to us on ASEAN trade unions. They range, as Senator Sim knows, from the fairly sophisticated apparatus in Singapore, the National Trade Union Congress, to outright repression of trade union movements in some of the other ASEAN countries.

The ASEAN region needs a democratic trade union system. It needs it because it is a barrier against extremists of the Right and of the Left. Yesterday Senator Hearn, in her maiden speech, made the very important point that whenever dictators, whether from the Left or the Right, take over, one of the first institutions they try to put down is a democratic trade union movement. I give an example. In the Philippines, Marcos has lifted martial law. Despite that his Government continues to harass and to arrest trade unionists. A prominent Filipino trade union leader was arrested seven months ago. He was arrested supposedly by the police, but nobody really knows whether it was the police. He is still missing. Apparently his main crime was to urge the workers in the place he was working to stand up to the factory managers and to seek an increase in their wages of 22c a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was his name?

—I have not got his name, but I can get that information for Senator Teague because it is a well documented case. Senator Sim spoke about political instability in the ASEAN region. There is no doubt in my mind that the Government in the Philippines at the moment is not stable. As I said, martial law has been lifted, but I believe that the Marcos regime is in trouble. I believe the relationship between the Government and the clergy is fragile. I think the Pope's cautioning of the clergy to stay out of politics will be ignored because the clergy in the Philippines is too involved in the issue of human rights and has the support of the majority of the people in the Philippines. Whilst I say that the Government is not stable, I do not believe it will be overthrown by actions of groups such as the Muslim separatists in the south. I do not believe there will be a communist takeover in the Philippines. In fact at the moment the most articulate spokesmen against the Marcos regime are resident in the United States and the majority of them are certainly seen, in Asian terms, to be political moderates. It was disturbing recently to hear that an Australian aid officer had been killed there. I think all members of the Committee would agree that the situation has deteriorated since this report was written and since it was presented to the Senate last December.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly support the remarks of Senator Sim about Asian studies and I strongly support the Committee's recommendation that the Government set up an Asian studies council to promote Asian studies at all levels. One thing noted in the report is that there are few employment opportunities for Asian studies graduates and that with the unemployment situation as bad as it is a school leaver has to choose a course of study that will guarantee a job. Gone are the days when students could study interesting and exciting subjects and still be assured of employment. Consequently, the future of Asian study courses is in jeopardy because of the dwindling number of students. As the report noted, there should be employment prospects in the Department of Foreign Affairs, in the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and in other aid agencies, but unfortunately at the moment there are not. I believe the Government should take a stand on this matter and make it a policy to employ each year a certain number of Asian study graduates whose knowledge, qualifications and enthusiasm could only improve and strengthen our ties with the ASEAN region. Then aid agencies and big private companies, we hope, would follow the Government's example and employ more Asian studies graduates.
I now want to refer to the role of Radio Australia and the media in the region. On this matter the Committee recommended:

The Committee is concerned that the Indonesian Government refused to renew a visa for the Australian Broadcasting Commission's journalist in the country. This situation can only be harmful to bilateral relations and the Committee recommends that the Government initiate further discussions with the Indonesian authorities to ensure that Radio Australia has a correspondent in Indonesia.
The Committee also noted:

In the ASEAN countries governments have more control of the media and can direct its operations. The respective situations are understood at government levels but not generally throughout the community. As a result of sensitivities and varying interpretations on topics presented in the media, accusations of bias and lack of balance recur.

There is no ready solution to this problem. The Australian media is independent and much of it is commercially motivated. Government funded radio and television services, including Radio Australia, operate as separate entities and are not an instrument of government policy. Radio Australia maintains an independent editorial policy seeking to provide an impartial, balanced service. It is mindful of Australia's image and foreign relations and liaises with the Department of Foreign Affairs to ensure that its broadcasts are not damaging to these considerations.

Radio Australia is terribly important. It provides a large number of people in the region with the only contact that they have with Australia. But apparently in some ASEAN nations this is one contact too many. The Indonesian Government is extremely sensitive. It has been estimated that between 30 million and 36 million Indonesians listen to Radio Australia. Therefore it is extremely unfortunate that Warwick Beutler's visa was not extended in June. But it is not surprising in view of what has happened since because it is now becoming apparent that Indonesia is determined that Australia will not be able to receive any first hand information in the future. I refer to the failure of the Indonesian Government to extend the visa of Peter Rodgers, and I would think that that would come as a shock to all honourable senators. Apparently his crime, the one thing he did wrong, was to uncover for the world the fact that widespread starvation existed in East Timor in late 1979. It was Peter Rodgers who smuggled out the banned photos to prove his claims. We all saw the photos that he brought out of East Timor of the starving children. For so doing he received the Australian Journalist of the Year award, an award made for first class investigative journalism. But now the Indonesians have given him their own award. They have expelled him from the country.

What has this Government done about that? It has asked the Indonesian Government to reconsider its decision. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, has said in statements that the Government was disappointed and that it deeply regretted the action. It is no wonder that the Indonesians did not take our so-called protests seriously. There are a number of much tougher diplomatic actions that the Minister could have taken but in fact he has done nothing. Of course on the issue of airline tickets or when we are dealing with an airline of one of the ASEAN countries we know how to get very tough indeed. Australia was taught a very hard lesson when it came to negotiate with the ASEAN countries over Australia's International Civil Aviation Policy-ICAP. The Committee refers to this on page 28 of its report. It says:

The ICAP experience also demonstrates the need for Australia's policies to be carefully explained and presented only after all their elements have been fully considered and co-ordinated. The Committee is aware from previous inquiries that the policy co-ordination system has deficiencies and is becoming increasingly complex as more domestic policies affect foreign policy. The relevance of long-term effective policy co-ordination in the Australian-ASEAN context is obvious and the Committee emphasises that Australian policies should only be presented after comprehensive consideration and agreement at the inter-departmental level, in consultation with the non-government sector where involved, and where necessary, decision at the Cabinet level. This should be supported by intensive diplomatic activity and detailed explanation at every possible point of contact.

Of course the big political lesson that we received regarding Singapore Airlines was that even though some of the ASEAN carriers would no doubt have benefited from the Australian ICAP policy, they closed ranks behind Singapore. One of the ASEAN countries was being discriminated against and even though, as I say, some of the ASEAN countries would have benefited, they closed ranks to protect Singapore. The Department of Foreign Affairs was brought in to help solve the problem but as far as I am concerned it was brought in far too late, after the damage was done. We now have the Department of Transport rushing in and harassing airline travellers who have the good fortune to be able to purchase a cheap ticket. Again, the airline involved is Singapore Airlines.

Once again, the actions we have taken will damage our relationship with the ASEAN countries. I wonder how many honourable senators opposite believe that the Department of Transport has the right to intercept a passenger who is boarding a flight, whether or not his ticket was cheap. If a person buys a ticket to travel on Singapore Airlines and Singapore Airlines is prepared to take that person on the flight, I wonder how many honourable senators opposite would be prepared to say that the Department of Transport had the right to intercept that passenger between the ticketing desk at the airport and the plane. I suggest there would be very few indeed.

Members of the Australian Journalists Association must be quite bemused by this Government's sense of priority. Apparently it is worth fighting about cheap airline tickets and it is worth upsetting ASEAN nations and on this issue it is worth taking legal action against ASEAN carriers. But let us contrast that with the Government's actions over the expulsion of a highly regarded Australian journalist who, as I said earlier, exposed the plight of the starving people in East Timor. Perhaps the Australian Journalists Association should ask the Department of Transport to work on its behalf. Maybe that Department would be able to find out what happened to the five Australian journalists who were killed in East Timor.
On the subject of Indonesia, I wish to refer to a newspaper article in today's Australian that caused me a great deal of concern. It reads:

Senior officials of the Foreign Affairs Department are worried at the decision by the former Ambassador to Indonesia, Mr T. K. Critchley, to go into business in Jakarta as a lobbyist for Australian companies.
The article went on to say:
Mr Critchley recently made headlines when he criticised Australian news coverage of events in Indonesia following the expulsion of two Australian journalists from Jakarta.

I think this raises a very important question, namely, how can an Australian Ambassador be objective if he is using his position and his contacts to further a business career in the country to which he has been accredited? When this debate was first brought on Senator Primmer said that he believed that Ambassador Critchley had been in Indonesia too long and too often saw things through Indonesian eyes. I suggest that when we read of his decision to set up as a lobbyist in Jakarta we know why he took it.

I believe this is a good report. I believe the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is a good committee. There is no doubt that after 30 June we will certainly miss the chairmanship of Senator Peter Sim. Senator Sim and I, together with other honourable senators on this side of the chamber, have a number of differences over human rights. However, we realise that Senator Sim is one of those people who are not hypocrites on this issue of human rights. He realises, say on the particular issue of China, that not everything in China is perfect but that not everything in Taiwan is perfect. Too often we hear people in foreign policy debates saying that everything in the Philippines is bad but that everything in Singapore is good or, to use the example I have just used, that everything in China is good but that everything in Taiwan is bad.

We appreciate Senator Sim's point of view. He looks at issues objectively, especially sensitive issues such as the Middle East and South Africa. Members of our Committee, along with Senator Sim, have been able to develop strong bipartisan positions on those two issues. It is a position that members of the Committee from this side of the Parliament appreciate. We hope that it is not the last report on which Senator Sim has a chance to speak but if it is, on behalf of my colleagues on the Committee from this side of the chamber, we wish him well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I should like to begin my remarks this evening by drawing attention to one of the other items that I think has not been referred to so far but which is before the Senate this evening, and that is item 10, General Business, relating to the law of the sea. Far too little is known in Australia about what has been occurring with the development of the convention on the law of the sea over the past several years, in particular the benefits that have been gained for Australia in that process by Australian negotiators in what is undoubtedly one of the most complex international negotiations conducted in many decades. I refer particularly to the ambassadors who have been involved over a number of years-Mr Keith Brennan and Mr Ralph Harry. Mr Keith Brennan has led the Australian negotiating team for about the past four years.

SPEECH.PARA: During the time that a draft convention was under preparation and was getting close to finalisation a number of gains were made in Australia's interests, and its national interest has been very well served by those negotiators. For example, in the draft convention as it now stands coastal states are given jurisdiction over their off-shore resources, and the traditional freedoms of navigation and overflight of the sea have been confirmed and strengthened, thereby facilitating commercial shipping operations and effective naval and air services and mobility.

It is obvious that those sorts of matters are of great importance to Australia as a nation with 12,000 miles of coastline. It is important that those matters should now be close to receiving firm international recognition and standing in international law, and it is obviously in Australia's interest that that should be so. More recently, Ambassador Brennan led the Australian delegation to the conference to prepare a treaty on Antarctic marine living resources. Again, the process thus far has been notably to Australia's advantage and in its interests, and indeed under the prepared convention the proposed Antarctic marine living resources commission is to be located in Australia, in Hobart. I know that all those involved in the delegation to that conference-I was one of them, although I was unable to attend as often as I would have liked-would confirm the importance of the role of Ambassador Brennan and his patience and skill in negotiation.

I point out that the draft convention on the law of the sea is nearing finalisation. There will be a conference next month in New York which, it is hoped, will be the final negotiating session, although I understand there may be some slight difficulties at the last minute because the Reagan Administration in the United States, as the new administration, may want to have a closer look at what is a tremendously complex international convention and one that has significant implications and, as I have suggested, in many respects will serve Australia's interests well. I therefore want to draw to the Parliament's attention and to the attention of Australians generally the very significant role played by Mr Ralph Harry and by Mr Keith Brennan in leading Australia's delegations to these complex and often for them, no doubt, wearying negotiations in many parts of the world over many years. In doing so they have served the country's interests well.

I refer to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which has been discussed already by Senator Sim and by Senator Sibraa. With them, I am a member of the Committee. I shall refer to a few aspects of that report which I think are of particular significance. They are aspects that have already, in one way or another, been touched upon or referred to by Senator Sim and by Senator Sibraa but there are other aspects of those matters to which I should like to draw some attention in the course of this discussion.

First of all, I refer to the decline that has occurred in Asian studies in this country in the recent past. The Asian Studies Association of Australia has undertaken a study of this matter and its report has indicated the magnitude of the decline that has occurred and has suggested some of the implications of that decline for Australia and has made some recommendations as to how the problems might be overcome. The Asian Studies Association inquiry looked at a number of areas of particular concern; for example, career prospects for graduates with an Asian emphasis in their studies; tertiary education in general, with emphasis on universities; schools and teacher education; and education beyond formal institutions through the media, libraries, information services, and so on. The inquiry came up with some recommendations as to what might be done about the problems that have emerged with the decline of Asian studies in this country and the dangers with respect to the potential lack of understanding in this country of our Asian neighbours and the misjudgments that may well occur in the future.

One of its most important recommendations was that an Asian studies council should be established in Australia to promote Asian studies at all levels. The report went into some detail as to the nature of the work of such a council. I simply draw attention to the fact that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence recommended that the Government should implement the proposal of the Asian Studies Association to establish an Asian studies council. I hope that as the Government examines its response to this report it might pay particular attention to that recommendation because in many respects it is fundamental to any improvement in our relations and to the further development of Australian understanding of its Asian neighbours. That understanding is essential to good relations between those countries and Australia and to our capacity to make proper judgments about what is occurring in that part of the world.

Another significant element and one which I think bears even closer consideration is the fact that there is very little interest in Australia in South East Asian countries-the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations. We ought not to delude ourselves into thinking that the decline of Asian studies in Australia is the only important element. There has not been a decline in Australian studies in the South East Asian countries because there were virtually no Australian studies to start with, and there seems to be little chance of any change in that situation. In the course of evidence the Curriculum Development Centre, for example, which is based here in Canberra and which is involved in work with educational innovation or development, particularly in the ASEAN countries, expressed some concern about Australia's image, even in text books used in those countries. It stated:
At present, Australia is often loosely lumped in with 'Commonwealth Studies' or 'Oceanic Studies' with a consequent blurring of our image.

That blurring occurs to the extent that Australia has any image at all in those countries. I suggest that we need, as a nation, to give some attention to how we might promote some interest in Australia in those countries-some interest in Australian studies-so that not only can our judgment of Asian countries be balanced and informed but also so that their judgments of us might be equally balanced and, I hope, informed.

Mr Acting Deputy President, there has been some discussion and controversy in the last year or two about Asian students in Australia and about the benefits provided for such students. In 1979 some changes were made to impose charges and fees on private students studying in Australia, but I emphasise that this decision did not affect sponsored students. I hope it will open the way to our providing more assistance for more sponsored students from Asia. Quite frankly, I have no hesitation in supporting that position because, clearly, many of the private students from Asia who come to this country come from the existing elites in those countries. I would prefer to see our sponsorship being utilised to assist students who come from less elitist backgrounds in those Asian countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although drawing from all.

—Indeed, drawing from all, but I would like to see more attention being given to those students from families and circumstances where the need is greatest. I think that would mean greater benefits for Australia and would certainly spread the benefits within those societies of our development assistance, which takes that form in some cases. I think it is worth quoting from the words of one witness, because those words in a sense encapsulate what I have been saying in the last few minutes. The witness said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian ignorance of its neighbouring states and peoples is considerable and regrettable. Their ignorance of us is almost overwhelming and could at some future time react seriously against us.

I simply stress those last few words. That is the point I have been making. That ignorance on their part could at some future time react seriously against us. It is in our interests that they understand us rather better and it may be up to us to do a little more about it.

Senator Sibraa referred to the need for labour attaches in some of these countries and to the fact that since our report was tabled the Government has announced that a labour attache will be appointed to the Australian Embassy in Tokyo. The appointment to Tokyo is important, as is the Japanese appointment of a labour attache to Canberra. There is an obvious and great need for more understanding between Australia and Japan of the nature of industrial relations in the two countries. It is important from our point of view to have someone in Tokyo who can explain and what is going on in this country with respect to industrial relations when, for example, disputes here disrupt our trade with Japan. That is often a very perplexing experience for them and often undermines confidence. But if we have someone in Tokyo who understands and can explain clearly what is going on I think it will assist our cause.

I suggest that whilst that is important in Japan it is equally important in parts of South East Asia: In one or two of the ASEAN countries I think there is an equally strong case for a labour attache to be appointed. I hope that once again the Government will give close consideration to that recommendation when it is considering its response to that report.

There are, of course, many facets to Australia's relationships with the ASEAN countries. In most respects our relations are close and friendly, both at the bilateral and the multilateral levels. The most volatile and potentially harmful area of our relationships with these countries, as with many others, including Japan, is the area of economic, particularly commercial, relationships. I think it has to be recognised-perhaps we ought to be a little more honest with ourselves, a little more frank with one another-that the ASEAN countries are an economic bloc. They will negotiate, when it suits them, to deal as an economic bloc with outside countries. That has been quite noticeable in their dealings with Australia. They are out to get the best possible deal for the ASEAN countries. They can at times be quite ruthless in the pursuit of their interests. They will use Australia, as they have done on many occasions, as a whipping post. If we do not recognise that and respond accordingly, the Government will not be protecting Australia's interests.

There are vast differences amongst the ASEAN countries, to which this report refers, but when they get together on a particular issue they act as a very effective international lobby, and Australia has to respond accordingly. They have been very critical of Australia with respect to trade and the imbalance of trade, but they frequently and conveniently overlook or discount the invisibles involved in the commerce and trade between Australia and the ASEAN countries. They have been very critical of our tariffs but have been silent about tariffs between the ASEAN countries, some of which are more injurious in their terms, to them, than are ours. There are many internal differences, many barriers, between the ASEAN countries in this respect, but when it suits them they will lash Australia. Particularly will they do so as a group. They say, for example, that we should reduce many of our tariffs, import quotas or other trade barriers. We ought to ask them not only privately but also publicly whether they are prepared to act precipitately against their national interest. We as a country have made it clear that we recognise the problems that our tariffs pose. I do not think we ought to apologise for our situation, our attitudes and our policies. Whilst we ought to be acting to assist those countries wherever we can and to introduce change, I do not think we should apologise.

Air fares and international civil aviation issues have already been mentioned by Senator Sibraa. Once again, I think he was suggesting that the controversy between Australia and ASEAN has really been between Australia and Singapore. It suited the ASEAN countries, as a group, to lash Australia. They have acted as a group. We have not had great differences with Garuda Indonesian Airways or with Thai Airways International. The problems have been with Singapore. The ASEAN countries have behaved as if there have been problems with the whole group. There have been some, but not to that extent. Some of their statements have been unreasonable and I think our responses have at times been less than adequate.

The economic relationship between Australia and the ASEAN countries is a critical one. I wish to refer to a statement in the report in which the Committee referred to evidence from the Confederation of Australian Industry. I quote from the report:

. . . the ongoing activities of the business sector and the formal links 'are essential ingredients in improving Australian-ASEAN relations, and in enabling Australian industry to participate in the future development of the region'.

That is right. Those countries benefit in many respects from our participation and our investment. I do not think that we should continue always to wear the velvet glove when the ASEAN countries choose to wear knuckledusters. I think we should stop being so apologetic in the face of what is often quite unrestrained, unjustified and public criticism of Australia from these countries. One has only to remember most recently, to put it politely, the unrestrained language of Prime Minister Lee of Singapore at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in New Delhi. Australians have been very restrained in referring, for example, to Singapore's response or Malaysia's response to refugees. We could have said some very harsh things about those two countries and what they did to the boat people, but we have not done so. The Government certainly has not done so. When Mr Lee and some of his colleagues from the ASEAN countries behave and express themselves in the way he did one must ask whether we should be so restrained.

It is in this context that I refer particularly to Indonesia. The sort of problem to which I have been referring is sometimes not so obvious but probably is much more substantial with respect to Indonesia than the other ASEAN countries. It is often not so directly related to the sorts of commercial issues to which I have been referring, which affect Singapore, the Philippines and Malaysia, for example. It is rather trite to say that we want to have good relations with our big neighbours to the north. Indonesia is our closest neighbour. It is a very large country with a massive population that will double before the end of the century. It will probably reach a quarter of a billion people within the next 20 years. I do not think we should act at any time at the expense of our national integrity or our international standing. If we are going to avoid that, or even the suggestion of it, in my view we will have to be rather more forceful and direct in our relationships with Indonesia.

Indonesia is influential. We have to recognise some of the harsh facts of international life. It is an influential member of the Third World nations and the non-aligned nations. It is closely associated with the Muslim nations and with the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries. It is obvious from those facts that Indonesia has some weight in the world. This was demonstrated to us pretty emphatically in the case of East Timor because when Australia sought to muster some international support for action in the United Nations against Indonesia over its invasion of East Timor in 1975 that international support simply was not forthcoming. Indonesia's weight in that respect has to be recognised and we have to acknowledge the constraints that exist when dealing with it.

When one looks at the stand that was adopted with respect to East Timor one will see that such a strong stand is not always adopted. I think we have to be very careful about the consequences of that because in many respects it weakens us, not only in the eyes of the Indonesians, but also in the eyes of many other nations. As with other ASEAN countries, but more significantly with Indonesia, we are too often apologetic. We have to state our position and not qualify it heavily. If we think that Indonesia has erred in throwing out of that country an Australian journalist I do not see why we should we should qualify that by saying it is Indonesia's right to do so. Everyone knows that. The point is that we regard it as an unwarranted action, an action that restrains the flow of information on Indonesia to this country and an action that can only sour relations between our two countries. We should tell Indonesia that. We should state it publicly and not qualify it. The Indonesians should know clearly what our stand is.

I will not go into the rights and wrongs of what various journalists did and did not do. The principle of the matter is important as is the strength of our response which is critical to our standing in the eyes of many nations, but Indonesia in particular. I believe we now have to be concerned about the impact of that sort of approach. We should reconsider it.

We have to ensure that the Indonesians are clear about our position. We ought to stop talking about our special relationship with ASEAN, Indonesia or anyone else for that matter. The relationships are not special. In our report we referred to the fact that the rhetoric of the 'special relationship' has worn out anyway. We use it too often. We have so-called 'special relationships' with Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific, ASEAN and Japan. Such a statement does not mean anything. We ought to make it clear to ASEAN particularly Indonesia, that they are just like any other nation and that our relations with them will be conducted accordingly and we will not make special concessions or kowtow because of some 'special' and mystical aspect of that relationship which remains undefined.

It is because of this that I believe we now run the risk of a major anomaly developing in our foreign policy. This emerges especially from our relationship with ASEAN but more particularly Indonesia. It emerges partly from the rhetoric of the 'special relationship' because that means that others question their place in our foreign policy at the same time as they wonder about the concessions we may make in such a 'special relationship' with someone else. It also means that we run the risk of being blinkered to some extent with respect to other countries and regions. We should not be. We must not, for example, neglect our relations with southern Asia, the Middle East and the South Pacific, and more particularly Africa and South America, which are great gaps in our foreign policy.

Whilst ASEAN is important and the area is nearby, it must be made clear to those nations that they are no more 'special' than anybody else and that we do not intend to back off our national interest simply because they choose to use unrestrained language in public about one or other action of ours. As I said at the outset, it is important that they know more about us. For them to know more about us we need to be much clearer in our attitude and our policies towards them. They need to know we are not so weak that we will back off on every issue or qualify our stand. I return to the statement made by a witness which, as I said earlier, encapsulates the importance of this point. The witness stated:
Australian ignorance of its neighbouring states and peoples is considerable and regrettable. Their ignorance of us is almost overwhelming and could at some future time react seriously against us.
I think we should all ponder that.

I would like to conclude my remarks by paying a tribute to my colleague Senator Sim, who will be retiring from the Senate at the end of June this year. Senator Sim has been the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence throughout the time I have been a member of it since 1976. I have no doubt that all members of the Committee would agree that his chairmanship has been superb. He has provided a clear sense of direction for the Committee and has presided over its hearings with skill and tact. He has presided over the preparation of reports with even greater skill and tact because such properties are probably even more necessary in those circumstances. In the time that I have served under Senator Sim, the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee has produced a number of reports; on refugees, the Indian Ocean, the South Pacific, the Department of Foreign Affairs and now on ASEAN-matters that have considerable substance. Much of that is due to his chairmanship of the Committee. I have no doubt that when he leaves this place he will be missed in many respects, but particularly as Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. However, he can go knowing that we all feel, and acknowledge, that he has made a very significant contribution in his role as Chairman of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheeldon Sen The Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cognate debate which we are having this evening is a rather wide one. It ranges from Zimbabwe to the Association of South East Asian Nations and from disarmament to the law of the sea. It would seem, therefore, to embrace practically every aspect of foreign policy that one could imagine. I propose to follow the example which has been set in linking these various reports in order to speak in rather more general terms than those who have spoken before me. Before doing so I should like to say that I do feel very appreciative of the work which the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has carried out with regard to the report which it has presented on ASEAN. I believe it is an admirable report. As previous speakers have done, I should like to express the warm feelings which I think all of my colleagues in the Opposition share-certainly those who have served on one or other of the various parliamentary committees on foreign affairs with Senator Sim-for Senator Sim's diligence, objectivity and very great understanding of these matters and the very considerable contribution that he has made to the debates of this Parliament. I do not wish to confine myself to ASEAN but to speak rather more generally.
—Might I suggest that as you move from report to report you identify each?

—I did not realise that was required but if you insist, Mr Deputy President, then I shall say that all of my remarks will relate to disarmament. Australia, like many other countries, over the next days will have to make quite a dramatic reassessment of its foreign policy as a result of the very stupendous changes which have recently taken place in the United States with the election of Mr Reagan as President of the United States of America. One might say that in fact a form of revolution has taken place in that country. There is now a President who is committed to pursuing quite different policies from those of all of his predecessors since Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected in 1932. Compared with President Reagan, even President Nixon would have been, I think, part of the mainstream of mid-twentieth century liberal American political thought. Totally new concepts are now being advocated by President Reagan and his Administration. Some of the most important parts of the policies to which the new United States Administration is committed relate to its domestic policy. Doubtless we shall be very interested to see what happens about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly very great difficulties will be facing the United States Republican Administration in carrying out many of those policies to which it is committed. But I think the changes which have been forewarned by Mr Reagan and by those people who were close to him during his presidential campaign in respect of foreign policy so far as we in this country and other people outside the United States are concerned are even more significant. The difficulties which an administration has in carrying out foreign policy are quite insignificant compared with the difficulties facing an administration in respect of domestic policy. Domestic policy does not require legislation or a majority in the Senate or the House of Representatives as most of it relates to administrative action. Now that the Reagan Administration is in office it can carry out those things which it said it would do.

I believe the cornerstone of the new foreign policy of the United States of America is a rejection by the new government of the concept of detente, as it has been called, and a rejection of the assumptions which even President Nixon followed in his meetings with the leaders of the Soviet Union and China and which have been prevalent in the United States ever since the settlement of the Cuban missiles crisis of 1962. The assumptions which previous American administrations followed despite the upheavals caused by the war in Vietnam were, if I understand them correctly, that the leadership in the Soviet Union and in the United States were both composed of sensible, reasonable men who did not want a third world war or a holocaust, that if the leaders were to talk together they would be able to reach some sort of an agreement about a reduction in arms, that both sides were committed to peace, and that negotiations, if they were pursued in an equitable manner, would be fruitful and would lead to general disarmament and the preservation of world peace.

I do not think the new United States Administration believes these things and I do not think a majority of the American people, or at least those who take sufficient trouble to vote in presidential elections, believe it either. I think they believe that despite what has been said about detente over recent years they are living in a situation in which they are faced with a very hostile foe, that they need to combat that foe, that while they have been disarming their counterparts in the Soviet Union have not been disarming, and that there has been an expansion of Soviet power and Soviet influence throughout the world. Whether or not certain missiles were being made, the fact remains that a war other than a war of ideas, other than a war of debate, was taking place and the United States was losing that war. As I understand it, it is the intention of the new United States Administration to put to an end that sort of policy and to see that the United States is at least breaking even in that war.

I think there are a number of reasons why in 1980 the American people agreed with what Mr Reagan was saying whereas in previous years they had not agreed with what people like Mr Reagan and Senator Goldwater had said. I think events in the quite recent past have caused what John Foster Dulles used to call an agonising reappraisal to be made of America's position in the world and America's relationship with the Soviet Union. I shall just mention a few of them. One-most conspicuously-has been the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan; the virtual seizure of that country by the Soviet Union. It was an action which, if taken by any Western power, particularly in the nineteenth century, would have been described quite simply as colonialism or imperialism. I do not think there would have been any discussion about the merits or otherwise of President Karmal and the others. It would have been regarded as the seizure of a part of Asia by a European power as part of that country's colonial policy. I think the example of Afghanistan is particularly disturbing to a great many people other than those in the United States Administration because it occurred right in the middle of the celebrations connected with the completion of part of the strategic arms limitation talks and right at the height of the euphoria about detente.

It is fairly obvious that a great many Americans and others would have believed that even if the Soviet Union did feel that it was under threat from the various countries which it enumerated as being the supporters of the brigands in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Israel, China, Saudi Arabia, and all the other countries that it named as being involved in the conspiracy-this strange concatenation of forces-and if it were really serious about detente it would at least have consulted the United States and given some forwarning to the United States of the difficulties in which the Soviet Union claimed to find itself and not have acted unilaterally in the way in which it did in invading a neighbouring weaker country. The Soviet Union has shown no sign of moving from Afghanistan despite decisions of the United Nations whose decisions it has often commended to others.

Likewise the American people have been very disturbed by the Vietnamese quasi-colonial invasion of Cambodia, and this includes a number of people who were extremely active in their opposition to America's participation in the war in Vietnam. Many people believed-I think correctly; I was certainly one of them-that the United States and other Western countries had no business interfering in the affairs of Indo-China, certainly not people who have a record of hostility to the Indo-Chinese people in general or the Vietnamese people in particular and who believe that what Vietnam has done in regard to Cambodia is again an act which could be described, and would be described in other circumstances, as an act of imperialist aggression.

Likewise there is concern about the activities of the Soviet Union in Ethopia and the activities of close associates of the Soviet Union, such as Cuba and East Germany, in other parts of Africa where large number of their forces are engaged in conflicts which seem to be no more their business than any conflict in Vietnam was the business of the United States of America. Similarly, one finds that the Cubans are particularly active in other parts of Latin America. Outside of their own territory they are engaging in the provision of weapons and indeed the provision of soldiers in support of causes which, however virtuous they may be, are not the domestic business of Cuba. The wrath of many people would certainly be aroused were the United States to have its marines behaving in the same way that Cuban forces are behaving in Latin America.

Similarly, in Poland no military intervention has so far taken place by the Soviet Union but certainly Mr Brezhnev and spokesmen of the Soviet Union have made it clear that they regard it as part of their right, in accordance with what has become known as the Brezhnev doctrine, to interfere in the internal affairs of Poland if what they describe as socialism is being threatened by domestic activities in Poland. They have claimed for themselves a right, which so far fortunately they have not exercised, to act in Poland in a certain way. I think most people would find it completely unacceptable if, for example, the United States were to claim a similar right in respect to Canada or Mexico.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Cuba.

—Or Cuba, or anywhere else for that matter; but certainly adjoining neighbours such as Canada and Mexico. Something else which has concerned Americans and others has been what appears to be-one does not want to sound paranoiac about these matters-a consistent pattern of destabilisation occurring in a number of Western countries. One finds a remarkable similarity not only in the activities but also actually in the weapons that are used by organisations such as the Provisional Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, the Basque separatists in Spain, the Red Brigades and others in Italy and various people in Turkey.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it is not very long ago, only a month or so ago, that the President of Italy, Mr Pertini-certainly not a person whom anyone could describe as belonging to the extreme Right or as being an agent of the Central Intelligence Agency; he is a veteran socialist, one of the leaders of the Italian anti-fascist resistance and a leading member of the Italian Socialist Party, which has enjoyed in the past and which I think still enjoys a very close association with the Italian Communist Party-said quite clearly that he believed that the Soviet Union was responsible in some way or another for the pattern of destabilising activities by various terrorist organisations in a number of countries, including his own. Added to that in the case of the United States-although it did not in any way directly concern the Soviet Union, the other principal party to detente-is what has happened in Iran. The Americans found themselves placed in the humiliating position of having to negotiate what was virtually ransom for the return of diplomats and other people who had been seized by the new regime in Iran quite contrary to all international law.

All of these matters have caused almost a 180 degree turn in the foreign policy of the United States. The emphasis is no longer on negotiation with another well-meaning party but on building up the strength of the United States and resisting what it regards as the aggressive activities of the other side. I think that the new attitudes are epitomised in the statements which are being made by President Reagan's new appointee as permanent representative of the United States to the United Nations. The view and the policy which she has put forward-which are important not only because of their relationship to detente but also because of the change which they signify in the policy President Carter was following on human rights in various countries with which the United States had a close association-and which appear to be embraced by the new American Administration-are that the United States of America should be cautious in removing or undermining an autocracy which is sympathetic to the United States and to the West in order to replace it with another equally or even more odious autocracy which is aligned with the Eastern bloc.

One can only speculate as to where this will lead the United States. I think that one ought to comment on this matter. I think it is perhaps not quite as simple as has been expressed by the newly appointed permanent representative. My own feeling would be that the rather difficult situation in which the United States has found itself in Latin America and countries such as Iran is, to a very large extent, part of its own creation. Its difficulties did not arise because it pursued a policy of human rights initially. If the United States had not been openly supporting people such as Somoza in Nicaragua, Romero in El Salvador and the Shah in Persia and had not, as it quite freely admits, undermined the democratically elected Government of Dr Mossadegh in Iran in the 1950s and assisted in installing a dictatorship conducted by the Shah, it would not have had any of the problems which have subsequently occurred.

It seems fairly obvious that sooner or later the chickens will come home to roost with regard to Chile where, although I think some people have exaggerated the role played by the United States in the removal of the Allende Government, it could well be that as a result of the present very oppressive military dictatorship in that country there will not be ultimately a return to a democracy, but there could be the establishment of a Cuban-type regime in that country directly as a result of the destruction of the long-established democratic parliamentary system within Chile.

Whatever the causes may have been, whatever may have happened in the past and however foolish previous American administrations may have been, the fact remains that the United States will be pursuing new policies. No longer will it be looking for agreement with the Soviet Union as the primary objective of its foreign policy. It will be looking for ascendancy over the Soviet Union as the primary objective of its foreign and military policy. The United States is clearly quite committed now, at the very least, to equality and, one imagines, superiority in military strength over the Soviet Union. If that means that there is no international disarmament agreement and that the SALT II agreement is abandoned and perhaps not even renegotiated, that is a price which I believe people such as President Reagan and General Haig will be quite prepared to accept.

The question which I think Australia and other countries will have to face is: Where do we fit into all this? Clearly the powers of a country such as Australia are very limited. But if there is going to be a third world war it can take place only if the United States and the Soviet Union are involved in it. It would be the sort of war in which we would be involved willy-nilly, whether we wished to be or not. It is probably only by way of influence on either of those countries that we can play any role whatsoever. But I suggest that at the same time we ought perhaps to pay some attention to some of the positions which the United States has taken.

I do not believe-and I agree with the senators who have spoken previously this evening-that we advance our own cause, humanity, democracy or civilisation by adopting a weak, wishy-washy attitude toward Indonesia when five of our journalists are apparently murdered in an area under the authority of the Indonesian military. I do not believe that we advance any cause which is worth while serving, if we do not continue to object-even if, as Senator Knight I think correctly said, very few countries except perhaps Portugal support us-to the quite immoral seizure of East Timor by Indonesia. That is in no way to be preferred to what the Soviet Union has done in Afghanistan. If we are going to condemn one action we have to condemn both. I think that if one is going to take positions on these questions one at least has to have some semblance of consistency about what one is saying, otherwise one will be branded, properly, as a humbug.

I certainly do not think we shall lose anything by being critical of Indonesia. I do not suggest that we declare war on it. I do not suggest that we engage in trade sanctions or embargoes. But I do suggest that we continue to tell the Indonesian Government, at the very least, that we strongly disapprove of what it has done in East Timor and make it clear to Indonesia that we do not believe it is entitled to go around seizing other people's countries whatever its motives may or may not be. At the same time, I do not think either for reasons of morality or for reasons of self-interest that we should be prepared to withhold criticism of oppressive, torturing governments such as those in Chile and the Argentine.

If it were to become accepted that somehow we believed that the sorts of things that General Pinochet is doing in Chile and the new junta is doing in the Argentine-dragging people out of their beds in the middle of the night who then vanish and whose bodies are subsequently discovered-is a proper way to conduct a Western democracy, obviously our credibility would vanish. We are in the fortunate position that we can insult the Argentine and Chile as much as we like without it doing us any harm whatsoever. We are not quite as free to do that with regard to Indonesia but I certainly think that we are more important to Indonesia than Indonesia is to us. I do not think there is anything whatsoever to be lost by making our position perfectly clear. At the same time, we ought to show some caution when we select for the attention of our wrath countries which may be imperfect but nonetheless are better than some of those with which they are contending.

I know we do have some criticisms of Singapore. I am not now referring to any dispute about Singapore Airlines Ltd. At the same time, surely an examination of other countries of Asia would show that Singapore is one of the least undemocratic countries of the whole area. At least elections are held there. At least in those elections a number of parties are able to stand for election. No satisfactory evidence has ever been presented to me that they have not been bona fide elections. I know it is a little startling for any of us in the Australian Labor Party to imagine anybody winning all the seats in any parliament. I do not think that the fact that a person is popular necessarily makes him evil.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no such things as political prisoners either.

—Well, if Senator Evans would listen, I did not say there were no such things as political prisoners. There are people who are on charges in Singapore. I was aware of that without his prompting. I was saying that it was imperfect. What I was also saying was that it is one of the least undemocratic countries of Asia. I suggest that per thousand of population we would find many, many more political prisoners in the People's Republic of China than we would in Singapore. I think we would find many more prisoners within North Korea than we would in Singapore. I think we would find many more political prisoners in Vietnam than we would in Singapore. It is not so very many years ago that the entire executive of the Trotskyite organisation in North Vietnam was taken out and shot.
—I didn't know that morality had quite these quantitative dimensions.

—No, but I am just suggesting, Senator Evans, if I could try to make it clear to you what I am saying, is that if one is going to be critical of one country, one ought to see how bad it is compared with the others. There are some people whom I have heard who are critical of Singapore. Apparently Senator Evans feels he falls into that category. I had not particularly had him in mind. I had not been thinking of him at all until he attracted my attention. Senator Evans apparently feels I am directing my remarks towards him. If so, I am happy to do so. What I am saying is that those who are critical of Singapore-I have heard some people who are critical only of Singapore-ought to recognise the fact that there are many more elements of democracy in Singapore than there are in North Korea. I feel that I can speak freely on North Korea because I speak in my capacity as President of the Australia-Democratic People's Republic of Korea Committee. Despite holding that high office I am nonetheless firmly convinced that there is much more democracy in Singapore. I am convinced also that there is much more freedom of dissemination of information, of coming and going, of assembly, of trade union rights and of all sorts of political activities in Singapore than there is in most countries in Asia. I stand by that. I am not quite sure what Senator Evans thinks about that. Doubtless he will explain it later, but I stand by that position.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that a campaign is now developing with regard to El Salvador. I think it is very largely a misinformed campaign. It is a campaign to the effect that a rather brutish right wing dictatorship is imposing its will on the innocent peasantry. I do not doubt that there is an element of truth in this. I do not think it is a very good administration in El Salvador. If the present so-called civilian military junta was to run a team in the next Senate election in Western Australia I doubt that it would get my vote; it would not get very high preferences either.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a close run thing, though.

—It depends on who the other candidate was. I think anybody who has been following what has been happening in El Salvador knows that there was a singularly oppressive right wing military dictatorship under General Romero. General Romero has been removed. A civilian military junta has now been formed in that country. It is a mixed group of people. It is a group which is opposed by the supporters of General Romero, the old extreme right wing. It is engaged in acts of terrorism against the present government in El Salvador, which has opponents on both sides. It has opponents of the old extreme right, the supporters of the regime which has been been removed, and it has opponents who are supported by Cuba. I do not believe Cuba is a democracy. I think Cuba is anything but a democracy. I think the Cuban society is one of the most oppressive in the world. Despite its rather extraordinary occupancy of its chair at the non-aligned conference, it is the most extraordinarily aligned non-aligned country that one could imagine. I should have very great suspicion, I may say, of anybody conducting a campaign against a government with the support of Cuban arms and Cuban personnel. I would have very great suspicion indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: This government in El Salvador is struggling against very great difficulties. The president of El Salvador has a name which I know would immediately spring to the mind of Senator Evans, Dr Jose Napoleon Duarte. He was, for many years, a prisoner of the previous regime of General Romero. He was a refugee and has really only recently returned from exile in Venezuela. He has been a committed democrat all his life. He is dealing with a pretty hopeless crowd of colleagues in a very difficult situation. I suggest that the proper course for any of us who are interested in securing some sort of democracy and any sort of justice in Latin America would be to encourage the present government in El Salvador-I know it is a tiny country, but we seem to be hearing about it every day; that is why I mention it-to continue at a faster rate with the reforms which it undertook to introduce and which it has been rather sluggish in introducing. We should certainly not support the overthrow of that regime and replace it with a regime of the Cuban variety. That is what the alternative really has come to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should we encourage President Reagan to give it military aid?

—If Senator Evans is asking me, I would not discourage President Reagan from giving military aid. I shall be quite frank. As long as Cuba is giving military aid to a group of people committed to overthrowing that government I think the United States has at least as much right to provide military aid to one of the sides in El Salvador as Cuba has.
—Would you encourage him to send in military advisers?

—Yes, indeed, I would encourage him to send in military advisers. As long as Cuba is sending in military advisers, I believe the United States of America also has the right to send in military advisers.
—Would you encourage him to send in troops?

—If there are troops there, yes. If there is an act of aggression being undertaken by Cuba against another country in Central America I think if it is in accordance with an appropriate treaty the United States of America is entitled to come to the assistance of that government. Perhaps Senator Evans could save all this argument for later because there are some other things which I would like to deal with. I think by now honourable senators have my general position on the matter. I imagine that the rest of it would follow, perhaps like Aristotle's theory of the universe, from what has already been stated.

SPEECH.PARA: Similar campaigns of an equally spurious nature are taking place against alleged remnants of colonialism. A campaign is being undertaken at the present time to acquire independence for Puerto Rico. We are being told that a number of heroic people have been incarcerated in various places because of their struggles against United States oppression and that the United States is trying to prevent these people from obtaining that freedom which they all want.
