It is rather curious that when the election was held in Puerto Rico last year-I mention this only because this is one of the many sorts of issues which come before us all the time-one of the major parties had as its platform a continuation of the present commonwealth status with the United States of America and the other party wanted complete statehood, complete incorporation of Puerto Rico into the United States. Between them the two parties got well over 90 per cent of the votes that were cast in that election. Nonetheless we still hear organisations like the World Peace Council and people who support those organisations advocating independence for Puerto Rico whether the people of Puerto Rico want this so-called independence or do not want this so-called independence.

Closer to our own shores, and even closer to us than some parts of the Association of South East Asian Nations, we find a not dissimilar situation in New Caledonia. There are a number of people, including a number of very prominent people, who have said that we ought to be working for the immediate independence of New Caledonia. The situation in New Caledonia is a very complicated one. It is one of the so-called overseas territories of France. This means that New Caledonia has a constitutional status whereby it has direct representation in both houses of the French Parliament. The people who live there all have French citizenship. They have a territorial assembly which administers a number of the local matters specifically of a New Caledonian nature. I do not think anyone now looking back on the history of the nineteenth century would say that it was right that France should have taken New Caledonia when it did in the 1850s. None of us now would support European colonialism of that kind. It was an act of colonialism which caused New Caledonia to become a French possession. The same could be said about Australia being taken by the British in 1788. Whether it should have happened or should not have happened, the fact is now that in New Caledonia the indigenous Melanesian population is only 44 per cent or 45 per cent of the total population. The majority of the people who live in New Caledonia are of European descent; they are either French or people from other parts of the former French empire who have now settled there. I know one prominent New Caledonian trade unionist, a member of the Caledonian socialist party whose grandfather settled in New Caledonia in 1890 at the age of 21. He and his father were both born in New Caledonia and have lived there all their lives.

To suggest, as some people are now suggesting, that people like that should not be entitled to a vote in the New Caledonian elections and that only the Melanesians should be entitled to a vote is like suggesting that only the American Indians should be entitled to vote in the American elections and only Aborigines should be entitled to vote in Australian elecitons. If we were to apply to Australia the same demands as some people are making on New Caledonia, the only member of this Parliament who would be entitled to vote in the Australian elections would be Senator Bonner. That would be the consequence. This is a very complicated situation. The French Government has made it clear time and time again that if there is a majority vote in New Caledonia for independence it will evacuate the country. The French certainly do not want to get themselves involved in a colonial war. In the elections which have taken place in New Caledonia a very substantial majority have voted for a continuance of the present association with France.

I do not believe that we ought to be devoting hours and hours to worrying about New Caledonia. But it is a country which is very close to Australia. It is a country where there is a very complicated situation. It seems to me to be quite irresponsible for us to say that in a complicated situation the side which we ought to take is the side which is most likely to be opposed to our interests and those whom we ought to oppose are those who are most likely to be in support of our interests. I do not think anybody could deny that having the French presence in the Pacific is an advantage to Australia. I do not doubt that there are many people within the Senate who would not agree with me. It is to our advantage for one of the major European powers to have some presence in the Pacific. If it is not there oppressing a group of people who do not want to be under its domination, but there because a majority of the people in the small territory want it to be there, I think it is to our advantage. It is only if it is clear that the majority of the people who live in that country, whether of indigenous origin or otherwise want the French to go, that we should in any way suggest that they should go.

One of the major difficulties which faces Australia and countries similar to Australia is that we tend to bob around like a cork in the ocean waiting for every new current and wave that hits us. If one has the experience, as I have, of attending the United Nations General Assembly one will realise that there are all sorts of associations of nations. Many of them are not so powerful or so coherent as they appear to be. They might have some of the characteristics of what Chairman Mao in one of his happier moments described as a paper tiger. Nonetheless, there are organisations such as the Organisation of African Unity, the various Islamic states and the countries of the Warsaw pact which work together as blocs. Not many countries have a democratic form of political system, whatever their economic system may be. Those countries do not work with any sort of cohesion. If we believe that democracy is important and ought to be supported, it would seem to me that those countries which do support the democratic system ought to act together with the same cohesion as those who would like to destroy the democratic system.

Constantly in the United Nations countries such as Australia are defending themselves from the criticisms and attacks of all sorts of other people, but are themselves very seldom raising matters which could be of importance in the field of human rights. Just how absurd the United Nations is was shown on one occasion in the General Assembly last year. The delegate from Democratic Kampuchea announced that Democratic Kampuchea had become a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and it was put that because Democratic Kampuchea was an adherent to this fine document it showed how highly respected civil and political rights were in that country and how contemptible was the record with regard to civil and political rights of countries such as the United States and Australia which had not adhered to it. This is the sort of nonsense which constantly takes place in those chambers in New York.

At the same time, although it may be nonsense, it indicates that there is a consistent, coherent course of action by some of those forces who were represented there, with no countervailing force coming from Western countries. I do not think it ought to be our purpose to save capitalism or to save any economic system in these debates. What should be of the greatest concern to us is the fact that those of us who believe in a democratic system, a liberal, tolerant political society, do not act together to defend those societies which subscribe to the same doctrines and do not act to extend those values in the same way as those who subscribe to contrary values act to extend them.

In any event, the fact remains that we are faced with a totally new situation in regard to the relationship between the two major powers. We have to face the fact that the era of detente is over. We have to face the fact that no longer does our major like-minded country, the United States of America, believe that it is possible to secure peace merely by negotiation; that it can be achieved only if the United States greatly increases its strength. This places greatly different burdens and greatly different requirements upon us, whatever one's opinion may be of some of the other views I have expressed during what I was just saying. Things are not what they were before the elections of last November; they are now quite different and Australia will have to find a way to accommodate itself and to influence the new course of events.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that more than one report comes within the compass of this debate this evening. I want to say something about the report relating to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs which was tabled at the end of the last session. A report such as this is normally presented. It is extensively produced and full of very important detail. The matter of movements of peoples in the world in this part of the twentieth century is much more than the movement of people from one country to another. Today's migrant is in the intercontinental class and he is able to move from one country to another and back again and still work out a lifestyle which will be of satisfaction to himself and which will have some influence on the community into which he moves.

SPEECH.PARA: A program of immigration today is much more than a program of numbers. As the report says, it is a program of ethnic affairs and, as such, it involves social welfare, education, employment, housing, new industries and, of course, the whole world of cultural affairs and human relations. The report which is on the Notice Paper for review tonight indicates quite strongly something of the change that is taking place in this whole area of immigration and ethnic affairs. It indicates that the first year of the 1980s is a watershed in the history of the Australian Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. During the year under review major immigration policy initiatives have been undertaken; an Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs has been established; the recommendations of the Galbally report are being implemented; and there have been other important initiatives.

Those of us who have been interested in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, or the Department of Immigration as it was known for a very long time, will have noted one or two changes in the personnel of the Department. As the report reminds us, this new decade sees the departure of many senior, experienced officers who have served this Department faithfully and well over many years. May I, not only as one who has been interested in it, but also as one who has served within it as the Chairman of the Commonwealth Immigration Advisory Council for a number of years, pay tribute to officers from the Department of Immigration. They have served this country in many parts of the world under varying circumstances and during times when we were needing more migrants than we are taking now, at times when we were in need of a range of skills and at times when there were population movements in the world which were quite different from those that are in existence now. These people brought to their jobs not only great skills but also extensive areas of human understanding. They brought with them a capacity to recognise technical skills and cultural capacity all of which have made a tremendous difference to our lifestyle as well as to our economic growth. Indeed, the report reminds us that there are still some officers whose experience extends back to the days of the Second World War though within a few years all of them will have retired and so there will be a decrease in the number of officers whose experience has spanned the period of large scale immigration that took place in the post-war years.

It is true that we are the beneficiaries of this skill and understanding of the people who have undertaken this work professionally. However, in dealing in the field of human endeavour, understanding and movement there is really, after all, nothing that can take the place of experience. The experience of these people who served the Department of Immigration in the post-war years has been of tremendous benefit not only to the Department but also to this country. As the report points out, the subject of immigration can arouse a whole range of feelings and passions. It is an area in which many avenues exist and which must be constantly reviewed and reformed from time to time.

The report is significant insofar as it points out that overseas there is a marked resurgence of interest in coming to Australia. Further evidence of this recovery from the lower levels of intake during the 1970s is already in existence. There is a significant reference to the movement of what we call the trans-Tasman migrant. The report states that both migration inquiries and applications were up 30 per cent on the previous year. More than 38,000 migrants arrived in Australia in the first six months of 1979-80. This was a 12 per cent increase over the first six months of the previous year.

The report, in its opening pages, deals with a number of what it calls significant events. It then goes on to detail not only those significant events but also a whole range of important events. The first significant event to which I refer is the appropriation in the Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) which increased funds for the Department by more than $11m to around $73.4m. Another significant event that took place during the year under review was the development of the Australian Population and Immigration Council. During the period membership of the Council was increased quite considerably. As a result its expertise on international relations, its attitudes to and its relationships with local government and with the whole range of industry have been strengthened.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it does not have the link with this Parliament any more.

—If it does not have links with this Parliament any more, Senator Mulvihill, I suggest it is the role of this Parliament and the Government to ensure that the links are restored. The Council is a very important body and is still the principal advisory body on population and immigration policy. It advises the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) on a whole range of matters including the monitoring of research into population change and the ways in which immigration intakes can be planned to complement the planning of other national organisations. I suggest that at present this is a very important area concerning immigration. Immigration is not only a means of building a population content which might meet the needs of industry but also it has a close relationship to and influence upon the size and nature of the Australian population. The size and nature of the Australian population is all important for international relations-a subject which occupied so much of our time earlier tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Other areas to which the Australian Population and Immigration Council has devoted its attention include family reunion, assisted passages and other matters of that kind. As I said, the importance of this body is not limited to its advisory role to the Minister or indeed to its advisory role to the Government. Its advice can have an influence upon government policy. The work carried out by the Council flows through into other fields. As I said earlier, it assists employers, industry and local government to plan ahead by making available and investigating the various Australian demographic and population patterns. It needs to take into account not only the number of people which the country can take but also the age of various segments of the population. We have plenty of evidence that Australia is approaching the time when its population will be aged. This will be of some significance not only for our lifestyles but also for social service payments, sustenance and maintenance.

I have selected only one or two of the significant events contained in the report. I will now examine the establishment of the Australian Refugee Advisory Council which is also given some considerable attention in this report. That Council has a range of purposes which includes the reception and resettlement of refugees. It looks closely at the needs of displaced persons within this country and at the important matter of development of resettlement procedures and resources for refugees. What we did in this area some 20 or 30 years ago no longer necessarily applies because there are now new situations and conditions with the refugees. One of the important areas to which the Council is giving its attention deals with ways of informing the Australian community about refugees and their resettlement program. For the first time in its history Australia has had to come to terms with refugees from neighbouring countries arriving on its shores and in its communities. The Council takes time to deliberate and to provide greater understanding and a better community attitude toward refugees and better relationships between refugees and the host communities.

Early in the Council's program it set out a comprehensive plan to assist refugees to settle in Australia. It has provided for schemes which enable community based groups and other organisations to provide personal interest and direct assistance to refugees, particularly the Indo-China refugees. The first four families settled in Australia under this scheme came to Whyalla in my own State of South Australia. In 1979-80 some 800 refugees were resettled under the scheme. I think it is important to point out in looking at any report on immigration and ethnic affairs and the intake of people into the Australian society that the world refugee situation is still critical although, fortunately, there have been some improvements in recent months. I made it my business and had the opportunity to visit refugee settlements and camps in a number of countries over a good many years. These include camps in Europe, the Middle East, Vietnam and, more recently, in the South China Sea. I refer to the island of Paulo Bidong, Hong Kong and elsewhere. These camps contained the people who vote with their feet. They are the product of today's international turmoil. I suppose refugees have always been part of history. Their arrival has influenced history in one way or another, and for the first time in our history refugees are a significant ethnic movement in the Australian population growth and in this part of the world. They are already part of our migrant intake. They are part of the work force, they are part of the social scene and they are part of the cultural blend. The report draws attention to Australia's involvement in this development in our part of the world. Early in the report there is a photograph of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs with the 300,000th refugee to come to Australia since the Second World War. The Minister states in the report that Australia has benefited from the talents and energy of refugees. I think we have to recognise this development in our immigration program and in our approach to ethnic affairs and hold in balance its influence on our refugee intake as well as on our humanitarian concepts.

The third and only other significant event referred to in the report to which I wish to refer concerns the development of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. The word 'multiculturalism' has been used in a wide variety of ways and I think we tend to get carried away with it. Nevertheless, in a society such as ours it is something we must constantly hold up for examination and review; and the establishment of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, which is referred to in the report, is of some particular significance. It was established in response to a definite need for information on this aspect of our social development in our changing society. As honourable senators know very well, over the past 30 years something like 3.5 million people have come to Australia from well over 100 different countries. As evidence of our changing lifestyles, the Australian-born population has shown itself in very large measure to be capable of adapting and accepting many of the new cultural values which have been introduced from overseas without any significant racial antagonisms and without the significant tensions which somehow seem to have marred life in other countries. This changing nature has been identified by the Galbally Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services for Migrants.

The report we are debating emphasises that Australia is at a critical stage in its development of a cohesive and united society. Whilst there is a need to assist the development of a multicultural society on the basis of skilled research, at the time of the establishment of this Institute of Multicultural Affairs not much research had been done and not much information was available. I think this Institute of Multicultural Affairs has already done a signal service to the country and it will continue not only to furnish reports to the Minister but also to make information available to the Australian community and to provide a repository of literature and other material which will help us understand the diverse cultures of our Australian community. Having said that, I think we must always be mindful of the importance of the central nature of the host Australian society.

As an aside to that I draw attention to the comments of the head of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs of only a few weeks ago when he drew attention to the need for Australians to develop skills in languages and to his call for every child in Australia to learn a second language as part of its normal education. He says that we have most physical resources but that we seem to be very careless of language resources. Of course, Mr Menadue, who is head of the Department, has a considerable number of capacities in the area of languages. He says that they are needed to bridge the gap in understanding between different ethnic communities within Australia. It is all part of the development of the multicultural society about which we speak.

Another development related to this is the establishment of the Australian Ethnic Affairs Council, sometimes called the successor to the Commonwealth Immigration Advisory Council. The Australian Ethnic Affairs Council was established in 1977 to advise the Minister on a number of matters. It has been reviewed and was re-established in January of last year. My distinguished friend Professor George Zubrzycki, the Polish-born Foundation Professor of Sociology at the Australian National University, is its chairman. Its assignments include advising the Minister and the Government on the integration of migrants into the community and the position of migrants in relation to health, welfare, housing, education, employment and a whole range of other matters.

At the end of the report there is a rather lesser item to which I draw attention. There appear a number of photographs in which migrants and others are featured, but in the background of those photographs there is the recurring portrait of Her Majesty the Queen which is the same as that which hangs in King's Hall and which, if my memory serves me correctly, dates back to 1953 or 1954. I would have thought-indeed, I have expressed this hope-that in contemporary Australian society, when we have so much pride in our head of state and head of the Commonwealth whose portrait and photograph appear in so many offices and on so many documents which relate to immigration and ethnic affairs, we might very well take up the idea of up-dating this portrait so that the migrants who receive documentation at least have on that documentation a portrait of the head of state which is as contemporary as they are.

Finally, immigration is accepted, I think, by the Australian community as an important factor in the attainment of a wide range of national goals. We have experienced its role in the supply of labour, and that must be a continuing dimension of our policy. But we see also other dimensions in the pursuit of other national objectives-a larger domestic economy; the transfer to Australia of new technologies; the maintenance of a relatively young population despite the falling birthrate; the importation of new cultures and different social and political perspectives to help us to understand not only other people and other nations but also ourselves; a humanitarian response to human need; the development through population growth of a more enduring relationship with other countries; and a substantial national industrial and communications system. All told we are a nation which is growing and making considerable advances in development. We will make those advances in development only through a strong body of people, of families, working and living together in harmony and understanding. So I commend to the Senate the Review of Activities of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and wish that Department every success as it undertakes its diverse activities on behalf of the nation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1980 (Hansard, page 208), Senator McIntosh asked Senator Carrick, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning the staffing of hospitals in Western Australia. Senator Carrick indicated he would refer the question to the Minister for Health who has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the hospital cost sharing arrangements, the Commonwealth meets 50 per cent of the agreed net operating costs of recognised (i.e. public) hospitals in Western Australia. The outlays for this purpose in 1980-81 are estimated at $145m, an increase of about 12 per cent over the previous year. Although the Commonwealth makes this significant contribution to the States' hospital operating costs, allocation of these funds and the administration and provision of hospital services are entirely the States' responsibility.

I understand that trained nurses in Western Australian public hospitals were granted by the Western Australian Industrial Commission a 5 per cent salary increase, effective from the first pay after 1 October 1980. It is expected that the increase will involve additional payments of about $5m in 1980-81, and $7m in a full year.

The Commonwealth's policy in relation to salary increases is that it is prepared to cost share those salary increases that fall within the wage indexation guidelines. Provided that the Commonwealth is assured that the recent nurses' award increase in Western Australia comes within these guidelines, the Commonwealth is prepared to meet, under the current hospital cost sharing arrangements, its share of the increased salary costs for trained nurses in Western Australia.
